{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2016}} {{Use British English|date=October 2016}} '''Monika Konrad Hildegard Hellwig''' (10 December 1929 – 30 September 2005) was a [[Germany|German]]-born [[United Kingdom|British]] academic, author, educator and theologian, who spent much of her life in the United States. A former [[Religious Sister]], she left her community to pursue her academic career, becoming a professor at [[Georgetown University]] and later being named as President/Executive Director of the [[Association of Catholic Colleges and Universities]] (1996–2005).
==Early life and education== Hellwig was born in 1929 in [[Breslau]], Germany, to a German Catholic father and a Dutch Jewish mother, who was a noted sculptor. When the [[Nazi]]s came to power, the family moved several times to avoid arrest. First the family moved to the Netherlands. Later, after the German invasion of the Netherlands, the eight-year-old Hellwig and her sisters, Marianne and Angelika, were sent to a boarding school in Scotland by their parents. Her father was later killed by the Nazi authorities. She was briefly reunited with her mother in 1946, only to see her die a few days after that reunion. That same year, aged 15, she began her higher education at the [[University of Liverpool]], from which she received degrees in law (1949) and social science (1951).<ref name=WP>{{cite journal|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/10/05/AR2005100502300.html|first=Patricia|last=Sullivan|work=Washington Post|date=6 October 2005|title=GU Theologian, Catholic Activist Monika Hellwig Dies}}</ref>
Hellwig left England and moved to the United States in the early 1950s, where she joined the [[Medical Mission Sisters]], a Roman Catholic [[religious institute]] of women based in [[Philadelphia]], [[Pennsylvania]], which had been founded to provide medical care to the poor of the world. After her [[novitiate]], she attended [[The Catholic University of America|Catholic University]] for her master's degree in theology, which she received in 1956. She returned to that university for a doctoral degree in theology (1966).<ref name=WP />
==Career== In 1963 Hellwig was sent to [[Rome]], where she served as a research assistant to a Vatican official during the [[Second Vatican Council]], one of the few women allowed unfettered access as an observer at Council sessions. Fourteen years after she took her vows, in order to pursue better her work, she requested a [[Dispensation (Catholic Church)|dispensation]] from her vows by the [[Holy See]], which granted her this. Thereafter, in addition to lecturing at many universities, Hellwig taught for more than three decades at [[Georgetown University]], including six years as the Landegger Distinguished Professor of Theology.<ref name=WP />
Hellwig wrote many books, including ''Understanding Catholicism'' (1981), ''Jesus, the Compassion of God'' (1992), and ''The Eucharist and the Hunger of the World'' (1976).<ref name=WP /><ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.spiritualitytoday.org/spir2day/843615hellwig.html|last=Hellwig|first=Monika K.|work=Spirituality Today|title=Christian Spirituality for the Single Parent|date=Spring 1984|volume=36|number=No. 1|pages=47–55|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120918235753/http://www.spiritualitytoday.org/spir2day/843615hellwig.html|archivedate=18 September 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> While serving as President of the [[Catholic Theological Society of America]], in 1986 she co-signed a controversial letter in support of [[Charles Curran (theologian)|Charles E. Curran]], a Catholic priest and professor at the [[Catholic University of America]], who "had been stripped of his authority to teach in Catholic universities because of his dissent from the church's teachings on such issues as contraception and homosexuality."<ref name=WP /> In 1996 she became president and executive director of the Association of Catholic Colleges and Universities, retaining the position until a few months before her death.<ref name=WP /> She was also a senior research fellow at Georgetown's Woodstock Theological Center at the time of her death.
==Personal life== Hellwig adopted two sons and a daughter, who survived her. She retained her British nationality while working and living in the United States.<ref name=WP />
==Death== Hellwig died on 30 September 2005, aged 75, at Washington Hospital Center from a [[cerebral hemorrhage]]. Following her death, the ''[[National Catholic Reporter]]'' referred to Hellwig's "near encyclopedic knowledge of Catholicism, which might be expected of the coauthor of the ''Modern Catholic Encyclopedia''."<ref>[http://www.encyclopedia.com/doc/1G1-138058740.html] Excerpt from the ''[[National Catholic Reporter]]'' obituary for Hellwig {{dead link|date=April 2013}}</ref>
==Education== * [[University of Liverpool]] - law degree (1949), social science degree (1951) * [[Catholic University of America]] - master's degree in theology (1956), doctorate
==See also== {{portal bar|Biography|Catholicism|England|United States}}
==References== <references/>
==External links== *{{worldcat id|id=lccn-n50-25946}}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Hellwig, Monika}} [[Category:1929 births]] [[Category:2005 deaths]] [[Category:People from Wrocław]] [[Category:Silesian Jews]] [[Category:Jews who immigrated to the United Kingdom to escape Nazism]] [[Category:Naturalised citizens of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of Liverpool]] [[Category:British Roman Catholic religious sisters and nuns]] [[Category:Participants in the Second Vatican Council]] [[Category:Catholic University of America alumni]] [[Category:Former Roman Catholic religious sisters and nuns]] [[Category:Georgetown University faculty]] [[Category:British expatriate academics in the United States]] [[Category:British Christian theologians]] [[Category:British women writers]] [[Category:Disease-related deaths in Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:People from the Province of Lower Silesia]] [[Category:Women religious writers]]

{{Infobox person | name = Suzanne Capper | image = Suzanne Capper.png | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = Suzanne Jane Capper | birth_date = [[circa|c.]] 1976 | birth_place = [[Manchester]], [[England]] | death_date = {{Death date|1992|12|18|df=yes}} (aged 16) | death_cause = [[Multiple organ dysfunction syndrome]] arising from [[thermal burn|burns]] | death_place = [[Withington Community Hospital|Withington Hospital]], Manchester, England | body_discovered = Compstall Road | parents = Elizabeth Capper }}
The '''murder of Suzanne Capper''' was committed in [[Greater Manchester]], [[England]] in December 1992.<ref name="sharratt">{{Cite news|title=Girl, 16, critical after kidnap|work=[[The Guardian]]|location=London|date=16 December 1992|first=Tom|last=Sharratt}}</ref> Sixteen-year-old Suzanne Jane Capper died in [[Withington Community Hospital|Withington Hospital]] on 18 December 1992, from [[Multiple organ dysfunction syndrome|multiple organ failure]] arising from 80% [[Thermal burn|burns]] after she was deliberately set on fire on 14 December.<ref name="foster">{{Cite news|title=Petty grudges settled by torture spree then murder|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/petty-grudges-settled-by-torture-spree-then-murder-suzanne-cappers-short-life-ended-in-horror-at-the-hands-of-friends-who-lived-an-equally-bleak-existence-1468189.html|accessdate=28 September 2010|first1=Jonathan|last1=Foster|first2=David|last2=Connett|work=[[The Independent]]|location=London|date=18 December 1993}}</ref><ref name="faux">{{Cite news|title=Coroner told how 16-year-old girl was tortured and burnt|work=[[The Times]]|location=London|date=9 January 1993|first=Ronald|last=Faux}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Burnt girl, 16, found naked at golf course|first=David|last=Connett|date=15 December 1992|accessdate=16 October 2010|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/burnt-girl-16-found-naked-at-golf-course-1563604.html|work=The Independent|location=London}}</ref> Before her death, Capper related that she had previously been kidnapped and kept prisoner for seven days at a house in [[Moston, Manchester|Moston]], [[Manchester]], where she was beaten and tortured.<ref name="times1">{{Cite news|title=Burns girl politely thanked her rescuers|work=The Times|location=London|date=18 November 1993}}</ref> She was taken from the house by car, driven into the countryside and forced out of the car virtually naked into a wood at [[Werneth Low]] where petrol was poured over her and she was set alight.<ref name="regina">{{cite web|url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/ld200506/ldjudgmt/jd050728/dudson-1.htm|accessdate=16 October 2010|title=Regina v. Secretary of State for the Home Department (Respondent) ex parte Dudson (FC) (Appellant) and one other action|year=2005|work=[[House of Lords]]}}</ref> The torture and murder arose from the "avenging [of] trivial grievances: a sexual insult, infection with [[pediculosis pubis|pubic lice]] and the loss of a pink [[duffel coat]]."<ref name=ward />
Detectives conducting the inquiry said that "for sheer mindless brutality" the crime ranked alongside the torture inflicted on children by the [[Moors murders|Moors murderers]].<ref name=wilkinson /> The case went to trial in November 1993, but received "comparatively little publicity" as it coincided with the trial of Robert Thompson and Jon Venables for the [[murder of James Bulger]].<ref name="davis">{{Cite book|title=Sadistic Killers: Profiles of pathological predators|first=Carol Anne|last=Davis|year=2007|publisher=Summersdale Publishing|location=Chichester|isbn=978-1-84024-581-3|authorlink=Carol Anne Davis|pages=298–304}}</ref> On 17 December 1993, Jean Powell, aged 26, her ex-husband Glyn Powell, aged 29, and Bernadette McNeilly, aged 24, were sentenced to [[life imprisonment]] for their parts in the murder. Jeffrey Leigh, aged 27, was jailed for twelve years for [[false imprisonment]]. Jean Powell's brother Clifford Pook, aged 18, was sentenced to fifteen years in a [[Her Majesty's Young Offender Institution|Young Offenders' Institution]] for false imprisonment and conspiracy to cause [[grievous bodily harm]]. Anthony Michael Dudson, who was 16 years old at the time of the murder, was also found guilty of murder and sentenced to be detained [[at Her Majesty's pleasure]] under section 53(1) of the [[Children and Young Persons Act 1933]].<ref name="ward">{{Cite news|title=Four jailed for sadistic death by torture of girl, 16|work=The Guardian|location=London|date=18 December 1993|first=David|last=Ward}}</ref><ref name="wilkinson">{{Cite news|title=Four given life after girl tortured and burnt alive|work=The Times|location=London|date=18 December 1993|first=Paul|last=Wilkinson}}</ref>
==Background== Capper, described as "a gentle and easily influenced girl," had been [[babysitting]] for Jean Powell since she was ten years old.<ref name="wilkinson2">{{Cite news|title=Gentle teenager was fatally attracted to 'house of evil'|work=The Times|location=London|date=18 December 1993|first=Paul|last=Wilkinson}}</ref> In 1990 she had spent time in the care of the local authority after her mother, Elizabeth Capper, and her stepfather separated, after which Suzanne and her older sister Michelle stayed with their stepfather.<ref name=wilkinson2 /> Around this time Capper began to [[Truancy|truant]] from Moston Brook High School, and her attendance during the final two years of schooling was described as "erratic."<ref name=sharratt /> Capper increasingly spent her time at Powell's house. Powell lived at 97 Langworthy Road, Moston, a small [[Victorian era|Victorian]] [[terraced house]], where she also dealt drugs and was involved with the handling of stolen motor vehicles.<ref name=davis /><ref name=wilkinson2 /><ref name="ward2">{{Cite news|title=Sadistic death went beyond belief|work=The Guardian|location=London|date=18 December 1993|first=David|last=Ward}}</ref> Michelle Capper had briefly lived with Powell, but moved out in August 1992 because she did not like the "evil new friends" Powell was associating with, particularly Bernadette McNeilly, who had recently moved in three doors away at number 91.<ref name=wilkinson2 /> McNeilly, who had three children, subsequently moved in with Powell and her three children, where the two shared a bed in the downstairs dining room because the bedrooms were "full of children."<ref name=ward /> Capper continued to stay regularly even though Powell and McNeilly frequently bullied her. Her sister said: "It was not that she was scared of them, it's just that she would do anything for them. She pampered their every whim."<ref name=wilkinson2 />
Powell was separated from her husband Glyn, although the two remained friendly and he would visit regularly from his nearby home. McNeilly's boyfriend was 16-year-old Anthony Dudson, who was also having sexual intercourse with Powell. Powell was sexually involved with Jeffrey Leigh, a regular visitor to the house as a purchaser of [[amphetamine]]s. Another frequent visitor to the house was Powell's younger brother, Clifford Pook.<ref name=ward /><ref name=davis />
==Events leading to murder==
===Kidnap=== {{Location map many|Greater Manchester|label=Moston|position=left|lat=53.515637|long=-2.184762|label2=Werneth Low|pos2=left|lat2=53.43377|long2=-2.05415|float=right|caption=Map of Greater Manchester showing the locations of Capper's imprisonment ([[Moston, Greater Manchester|Moston]]) and burning that led to her death (Werneth Low).}} At trial, it emerged that Capper had been kidnapped for "insubstantial, even trivial" reasons: Jean Powell claimed that Capper had tried to persuade her to sleep with a man for money; McNeilly and Dudson had contracted pubic lice which they believed were from a bed that Capper had also used; and McNeilly believed that she had taken a pink duffle coat that belonged to her.<ref name=wilkinson /> In November 1992, when Dudson had contracted pubic lice and had his pubic hair shaved, McNeilly told him she thought that he had caught them from Capper. Dudson believed otherwise, and said later: "I told Jean [Powell] I thought I got them from Bernie [McNeilly]."<ref name=indy1 /> On 7 December 1992, Capper was lured to Jean Powell's home, where Glyn Powell and Dudson were already waiting. She was grabbed as soon as she arrived and held down while Glyn Powell shaved her head and her eyebrows and then made her clean up the hair and place it in a bin. Then he placed a plastic bag over her head and walked round her while hitting her on the head.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Youth says death victim was lover|work=The Guardian|location=London|date=1 December 1993|first=David|last=Ward}}</ref> She was then kicked by Jean Powell and McNeilly as she lay curled up on the floor and both women took turns beating her with a three-foot-long (1 m) wooden instrument and a belt.<ref name=davis /><ref name=ward3 /> She was then taken to the bathroom and forced to shave off her own pubic hair as "ritual humiliation in revenge for having caused, as they claimed, Dudson and McNeilly themselves to be shaved."<ref name="ward3">{{Cite news|title=Trivial gripes 'led to torture death'|work=The Guardian|location=London|date=17 November 1993|first=David|last=Ward}}</ref> Afterwards Jean Powell locked her in a cupboard overnight.<ref name=davis /> The following morning she was taken upstairs and locked in another cupboard.<ref name=ward3 /> On 8 December she was transferred to McNeilly's house because of concern that Powell and McNeilly's six children were disturbed by Capper's crying. There she was tied [[Spreadeagle (position)#Bondage activity|spreadeagle]] to an upturned bed with [[Power cable#Electrical cables|electrical flex]] in a downstairs back room.<ref name=wilkinson /><ref name=davis />
===Torture=== Over the next five days Capper was subjected to a series of violent acts, "increasing in severity and brutality as the time passed."<ref name=wilkinson /> She was regularly beaten and injected with amphetamines, burned with cigarettes, and had [[rave]] music—in particular ''Hi, I'm [[Chucky (Child's Play)|Chucky]] (Wanna Play?)'' by 150 Volts, featuring [[Sampling (music)|samples]] from the movie ''[[Child's Play (1988 film)|Child's Play]]''—played at maximum volume through headphones.<ref name=davis /><ref name="horrortape">{{Cite news|title=Horror tape played to victim was linked to Bulger case|work=The Times|location=London|date=18 December 1993}}</ref> McNeilly would commence each torture session with the phrase "Chucky’s coming to play" and soon the words themselves were enough to make Capper scream.<ref name=davis /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/chucky-films-defended-1468498.html|accessdate=16 October 2010|title=Chucky films defended|first=Helen|last=Nowicka|date=19 December 1993|work=The Independent|location=London}}</ref> At some point during the week Pook and Leigh called at the house and were shown Capper, blindfolded and gagged, tied to the bed. By this time, Capper had been lying in her own urine and feces for several days and was placed in a bath containing concentrated [[disinfectant]] and scrubbed with a stiff brush with sufficient force to remove skin.<ref name=faux /><ref name=davis /><ref name="murray">{{Cite news|title=Six are accused of burning girl alive to disguise torture|work=The Times|location=London|date=17 November 1993|first=Ian|last=Murray}}</ref> Pook then used pliers to extract two of her teeth, which police later found at his house "like some kind of macabre trophy."<ref name=murray /> Dudson said: "I was stood at the doorway with Jeanie [Powell] and Bernie [McNeilly]. Cliff [Pook] took her gag off. He told her to open her mouth. He said: 'Right, I'm going to rip your teeth out'. He started hitting her teeth with the pliers. He got the pliers on and started pulling it out. But it just snapped and chipped. Then he hit them a few more times. He put the pliers on again and really, really pulled. He pulled Suzanne's head forward until there was a snap and he had the tooth in the pliers. He did the same again and he was laughing."<ref name="ward5">{{Cite news|title=Girl set on fire 'lit up whole forest'|work=The Guardian|location=London|date=20 November 1993|first=David|last=Ward}}</ref>
===Missed opportunities for rescue=== David Hill, 18, was asked to "sit in" at the house, and while there heard Dudson shout "Shut up, you slag!" in the back room.<ref name=ward4 /> When he asked what was going on, Leigh had shown him Capper. He said: "She had a sort of cloth over her face, from just above the eyebrows and covering her nose. She had a bit of dried blood on her lip. She had no hair." Hill also said he had heard them talking about "dentistry work. It was something about pulling her teeth out with a pair of pliers."<ref name="ward4">{{Cite news|title=Touch unbearable to burns victim, murder trial told|work=The Guardian|location=London|date=18 November 1993|first=David|last=Ward}}</ref> Later, he was left alone in the house with Capper, who pleaded with him to untie her. He said: "She asked me if I could help but I told her I couldn't. I asked her who she was. She said her name was Suzanne. She asked me if I could untie her. I said I couldn't do anything." He later claimed that he was too afraid of Leigh to intervene or raise the alarm, saying: "I thought they would batter me. If I'd said [anything] they'd all have got me, wouldn't they? I didn't know what to do. I was too shocked to do anything."<ref name=davis /><ref name=ward4 /> While Capper was being held in the house, Leigh and Dudson met up with her sister's fiancé Paul Barlow to help him repair his car. Barlow said: "They could have told me there and then. The door would have been kicked down and I would have got Suzanne out. I did not think they were capable of such savagery. Now all I want is ten minutes with them in a back room."<ref name=wilkinson2 />
==Murder== [[File:Fiat Panda front 20071205.jpg|thumb|left|A Fiat Panda similar to the one used by Capper's murderers to convey her from Moston to Werneth Low.]] The six finally agreed that Capper had to be removed from the house after Michelle Capper told them her stepfather was going to report her to the police as a [[missing person]].<ref name="indy1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/woman-sat-numb-as-girl-burned-court-told-of-teenagers-screams-1464583.html|accessdate=16 October 2010|title=Woman 'sat numb as girl burned': Court told of teenager's screams|date=1 December 1993|work=The Independent|location=London}}</ref> In the early hours of 14 December 1992, Capper was forced into the [[Trunk (car)|boot]] of a stolen white [[Fiat Panda]] car and driven 15 miles (25 km) to a narrow lane at Werneth Low near [[Romiley]], on the outskirts of Stockport. In the car were McNeilly, the Powells and Dudson. McNeilly "giggled" as they made the journey.<ref name="ward6">{{Cite news|title=Murder case woman 'played horror film doll'|work=The Guardian|location=London|date=19 November 1993|first=David|last=Ward}}</ref> Capper was pushed down an embankment into a patch of [[bramble]]s and then McNeilly poured petrol over her.<ref name=davis /><ref>{{Cite news|title=Woman 'poured petrol' near girl tortured and burned to death|work=The Guardian|location=London|date=24 November 1993}}</ref> Powell stated: "Suzanne was still wobbly and fell over. Bernie [McNeilly] said 'Get up.' Bernie pushed her down the hill and poured petrol on her."<ref name=ward5 /> When McNeilly had difficulty getting the petrol to ignite, Glyn Powell asked Dudson for some paper, who handed him a folded envelope which Powell then attempted to light and use as a taper. After three failed attempts, Dudson said: "In the end he just went up to her with a lighter and lit her. He lit her on the back. She went straight up in flames and was screaming. The flames lit up the whole forest."<ref name=ward5 /> McNeilly began to sing "Burn baby burn! Burn baby burn!" from [[The Trammps]] song ''[[Disco Inferno]].''<ref name=ward2 /><ref name="pithers">{{Cite news|title=Teenage girl 'subjected to brutal regime of torture': Court told how 16-year-old burnt to death |work=The Independent|location=London|date=17 November 1993|accessdate=16 October 2010|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/teenage-girl-subjected-to-brutal-regime-of-torture-court-told-how-16yearold-burnt-to-death-1504790.html|first=Malcolm|last=Pithers}}</ref> Believing Capper to be dead, the four returned to Jean Powell's house, stopping to buy canned drinks on the way.<ref name=ward2 /> Both Leigh and Pook were at the house when they arrived and Dudson stated: "Cliff [Pook] asked Glyn [Powell], 'Have you done it?' Glyn said 'Yes' and he was laughing. He gave Cliff his lighter back."<ref>{{Cite news|title=Laughter after girl set alight, jury told|work=The Independent|date=2 December 1993|location=London|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/laughter-after-girl-set-alight-jury-told-1464738.html|accessdate=16 October 2010}}</ref>
===Naming attackers before death=== [[File:Werneth Low.jpg|thumb|Werneth Low, where Capper suffered burns that led to her death.]] Capper had not died immediately as her murderers believed, and after they left she managed to scramble back up the embankment and stagger along the lane for approximately a quarter of a mile (400 metres) to Compstall Road before being found at 06:10 by Barry Sutcliffe and two of his colleagues on their way to work.<ref name=ward2 /> She told them: "Over there, in the field. They burnt me, they put petrol on me." They immediately took her to a nearby house and roused the residents, Michael and Margaret Coop, to call for an ambulance.<ref name=sharratt /><ref name=times1 /> Michael Coop said: "Both her hands appeared like ash. Her legs were just like raw meat and her feet appeared to be badly charred. I was struck by how polite the victim was. She was constantly thanking my wife for her assistance." Margaret Coop said: "I instinctively went to put my arms around her but she pulled away because she could not bear to be touched. Her head was shaved and there were recent, not new, cuts to her head. Her face was almost featureless. Her hands were red raw and black at the fingertips. Her legs were red from top to bottom. She couldn't bear anything near her legs."<ref name=ward4 /> Capper drank six glasses of water, but was unable to hold the glass herself because of the injuries to her hands. Margaret Coop said: "She looked like the victim of an attack in the [[Vietnam War|Vietnam war]]. But I felt she would survive. I had this theory that, now she had got to somewhere she could be helped, she would live."<ref name=ward2 /> Capper was rushed to the hospital and was able to give the names of her six assailants and Powell's address before falling into a [[coma]]. The extent of her burns was such that her mother and stepfather were unable to recognise her, and she was positively identified by a partial fingerprint from her thumb, the only part of her hands not severely burned.<ref name=faux /><ref name=ward2 /><ref>{{Cite news|title=Burned girl identified by fingerprints|work=The Guardian|location=London|date=9 January 1993}}</ref> She died on 18 December 1992, without regaining consciousness.<ref name="wilkinson3">{{Cite news|title=Murder charge is due as tortured girl dies|work=The Times|location=London|date=19 December 1992|first=Paul|last=Wilkinson}}</ref>

===Arrests=== The inquiry was led by [[Detective Inspector]] Peter Wall of [[Greater Manchester Police]]. At 07:30 on 14 December, he instructed officers to attend 97 Langworthy Road and arrest everyone that they found there.<ref name=ward2 /> Jean Powell and McNeilly laughed and joked with each other as they were arrested. Initially, all six denied involvement. Under questioning, Dudson, who had been urged by his father to tell the truth, began to talk. D.I. Wall said of Dudson's statement: "As the story began to unfold, we just couldn't believe it. I kept asking myself how one human being could do this to another." Police officers "wept as the extent of Suzanne's suffering was revealed," and together with civilian staff at the station the police collected cash to send flowers to her at the hospital.<ref name=ward2 /> On 17 December 1992, the six accused appeared before [[Magistrate#United Kingdom|magistrates]] in Manchester and were [[Detention of suspects#Detention after charge|remanded into custody]] charged with kidnapping and attempted murder.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Six accused in burns case|work=The Guardian|location=London|date=18 December 1992}}</ref> Following Capper's death they were charged with her murder on 23 December 1992.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Six charged with girl's murder|work=The Guardian|location=London|date=24 December 1992}}</ref>
===Inquest=== The inquest was opened by Leonard Gorodkin at Manchester Coroner's Court on 8 January 1993. Dr William Lawler, a Home Office pathologist, testified that Capper had suffered 75–80 per cent burns consistent with having had petrol thrown over her and set alight, and that her chance of survival had been minimal. "It was clear from the outset that Suzanne was unlikely to survive. She suffered widespread burns that led to several complications internally." Death was due to complications caused by these burns. The coroner said: "It is clear that this young girl must have suffered a great deal of pain and had no chance of survival. But she did fortunately survive long enough to give information which led to the people mentioned being charged with her death." To Capper's mother and stepfather the coroner said: "I offer you, not just on my behalf but on behalf of the whole nation, my very deepest sympathy and condolences at this tragic happening to your young daughter."<ref name=faux />
==Convictions== The [[trial]] commenced on 16 November 1993, and lasted 22 days. All six denied murder and in their testimonies each defendant tried to minimise their part in the crime.<ref name=davis /> On 24 November, Clifford Pook was cleared of murder on the directions of the judge Mr. Justice Potts.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Murder acquittal|date=25 November 1993|work=The Independent|location=London|accessdate=16 October 2010|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/murder-acquittal-1506480.html}}</ref> The jury began their deliberations on 16 December 1993, and took nine hours and fifty-two minutes to reach their verdicts.<ref name="midgley">{{Cite news|first=Simon|last=Midgley|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/four-guilty-of-torture-killing-simon-midgley-1468211.html|title=Four guilty of torture killing|date=18 December 1993|accessdate=16 October 2010|work=The Independent|location=London}}</ref> Mr Justice Potts said: "Each of you has been convicted on clear evidence of murder which was as appalling a murder as it is possible to imagine."<ref name=wilkinson />
===Verdicts and sentences=== ;Bernadette McNeilly *guilty of [[Murder in English law|murder]] – [[Life imprisonment in England and Wales|life imprisonment]] with a minimum tariff of 25 years *guilty of conspiracy to cause [[grievous bodily harm]] – 20 years *pleaded guilty to [[false imprisonment]] – 20 years
;Jean Powell *guilty of murder – life imprisonment with a minimum tariff of 25 years *guilty of conspiracy to cause grievous bodily harm – 20 years *pleaded guilty to false imprisonment – 20 years
;Glyn Powell *guilty of murder – life imprisonment with a minimum tariff of 25 years *guilty of conspiracy to cause grievous bodily harm – 20 years *guilty of false imprisonment – 20 years
;Jeffrey Leigh *pleaded guilty to false imprisonment – 12 years *acquitted of murder *acquitted of conspiracy to cause grievous bodily harm
;Anthony Michael Dudson *guilty of murder – [[at Her Majesty's pleasure|detained indefinitely]] with a minimum tariff of 18 years *guilty of conspiracy to cause grievous bodily harm – 15 years *pleaded guilty to false imprisonment – 15 years
;Clifford Pook *pleaded guilty to conspiracy to cause grievous bodily harm – 15 years *pleaded guilty to false imprisonment – 15 years *acquitted of murder
As the sentences were announced two jurors wept and there were cries of "Yes! Yes!" from the public gallery, which was filled with relatives of the victim.<ref name=wilkinson /> In a statement to the press after the sentencing D.I. Wall said: "Psychological Reports say that these are absolutely sane individuals. It's frightening that they are such ordinary people. There is nothing special about any of them."<ref name=ward />
===Appeals=== Leigh appealed against his sentence, which was reduced from 12 years to 9 years on 4 November 1994.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Capper sentence cut|work=The Guardian|location=London|date=5 November 1994}}</ref> In 2002, Dudson's minimum tariff was cut from 18 years to 16 years.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Jail-cut hope for torture youth|work=[[Manchester Evening News]]|location=Manchester|date=30 January 2002|first=Keith|last=Foot}}</ref> Dudson appealed again, arguing that the reduction was insufficient and that the Lord Chief Justice "had failed to reflect the continuing obligation to have regard to Dudson's welfare." Lord Justice Kennedy and Mr Justice Mackay dismissed this second appeal on 21 November 2003.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Teenage killer loses freedom bid|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/manchester/3227710.stm|work=[[BBC News]]|date=21 November 2003|accessdate=21 November 2003}}</ref> He was moved to an [[open prison]] in 2009.
Jean Powell and McNeilly were granted leave to have the lengths of their minimum sentences reviewed at the Court of Appeal in June 2012. McNeilly's sentence was reduced by one year.<ref name="Appeal ">{{cite news | url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/news/greater-manchester-news/woman-who-tortured-suzanne-capper-691651 | title=Woman Who Tortured Suzanne Capper Has Sentence Cut After Court Hears She Is A Model Prisoner | work=[[Manchester Evening News]] | date=24 July 2012 | accessdate=25 November 2015}}</ref>
===McNeilly prison controversy=== While she was incarcerated at [[HM Prison Durham]], a routine security check in 1996 uncovered letters which revealed McNeilly had been having an affair with the prison governor, Mike Martin. The married officer resigned his position before disciplinary action could be taken. McNeilly, who was sharing a wing with [[Rosemary West]] and [[Moors murders|Myra Hindley]], was immediately transferred to [[HM Prison New Hall]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4161/is_19960128/ai_n9700544/|accessdate=16 October 2010|title=Sex with 'Chucky' killer|work=[[Sunday Mirror]]|location=London|date=28 January 1996|first=Matthew|last=Bel}} {{Dead link|date=April 2012|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
===Releases from prison=== Leigh was freed early from his sentence in 1998, as was Pook in May 2001. Both were released on licence.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://menmedia.co.uk/middletonguardian/news/s/1417277_keep-killer-away-from-family |title=Keep killer away from family – Manchester Evening News |publisher=Menmedia.co.uk |date=2011-04-06 |accessdate=2014-02-07}}</ref> McNeilly was released from prison in December 2014.<ref>http://www.dailystar.co.uk/news/latest-news/418304/CHUCKY-killer-is-back-on-the-streets-with-secret-new-identity</ref>
==Reactions== ===Social environment=== There was wide commentary in the news media about the social situation in and around Moston. Writing in ''The Times'', Jon Ronson focused on Manchester's apparent economic imbalance, pointing out that while "superficially, it is a city of growth"—hosting international environmental conferences in 1993 and bidding to host the [[2000 Summer Olympics|2000 Olympic Games]]—this could not disguise the realities of the poor quality of "built-to-collapse" housing, the city council's policy on [[homelessness]], poverty, street violence and [[drug culture]], all of which played parts in the events leading up to Capper's murder. The city, he said, had violent 'no-go' areas, where "you can expect to be mugged," created through drug abuse and hopelessness, and populated by people who "don't work, have no money, and rarely leave the houses that they find themselves living in before dark."<ref name="ronson">{{Cite news|title=A walk on the wild side|work=The Times|location=London|date=23 December 1992|first=Jon|last=Ronson}}</ref> Ronson highlighted a city of contrasts, where "expensive [[waterway|canal-side]] cafes are springing up faster than you can count them: the joke around town is that you can sip [[cappuccino]] all day and gaze out at the corpses floating past." David Ward, writing in ''The Guardian'', similarly drew attention to the housing policies, and quoted an older Moston resident as saying: "These people are moving in and out every three months. They're illiterate half of them—just [[sexual intercourse|shagging]] and having kids."<ref name=ward2 /> ''[[The Daily Mail]]''—in what Barker and Petley called "ideological overdrive"—described Capper's killers as "the product of a society that tolerates petty crime, the break-up of families and feckless spending... Most of Suzanne's tormentors were on [[social security]] ... [and belong to] an [[underclass]] which is a grave threat to Britain's future."<ref name="baker">{{Cite book|title=Ill Effects: The media/violence debate|year=2001|publisher=Routledge|location=London|isbn=978-0-415-22513-7|first1=Martin|last1=Barker|first2=Julian (Eds.)|last2=Petley}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Evil that defies belief|date=18 December 1993|work=[[Daily Mail]]|location=London}}</ref> Author [[Carol Anne Davis]] agreed that when looking for answers about how this crime came about one need only "look at the upbringings of these women who were single parents to three children by their mid twenties, had teenage boyfriends who were barely legal and who supported themselves through drug dealing and theft."<ref name=davis />
==="Moral panic"=== Davis also noted the unusual situation in that "a gang was involved and that two females were the sadistic leaders."<ref name=davis /> Following the convictions of Powell and McNeilly, there was wider press speculation about "girl gangs" and the rise in violent crime committed by young women, and "the [[probation service]] and ex-offender organisations found themselves bombarded with requests from journalists seeking out case histories to illustrate this apparent explosion of LA-style girl-gang culture on the streets of Britain."<ref name="weale">{{Cite news|title=Violence in Britain: Girlz 'n' the Hood|first=Sally|last=Weale|work=The Guardian|location=London|date=19 September 1995|page=6}}</ref> Mary Barnish, a senior probation officer at the Inner London Probation Service Women's Centre, dismissed the notion, saying: "One woman does something somewhere and immediately there's a great [[moral panic]]. People think there's an epidemic of it." However, statistics and research produced by the National Association of Probation Officers did show "an increase in the number of women jailed for offences involving violence."<ref name=weale /> The association's assistant general secretary Harry Fletcher said that, like the women involved in the Capper murder, the group is "characterised by neglect, personal abuse, drug or alcohol abuse and low self-esteem. Many have themselves been the victim of violence. The problem needs help rather than incarceration."<ref name=weale /> In one of the "starkest signs of change" there was evidence that "in the 15–17 age group, girls are more likely to take pleasure in violence than boys, an indication we may face far more female violence in the future as these girls grow up."<ref>{{Cite news|title=Move over baby doll, the Tank Girl is here|work=[[The Sunday Times]]|location=London|date=24 September 1995|first1=Geoff|last1=Mulgan|first2=Helen|last2=Wilkinson|page=1}}</ref> Despite the focus on the female perpetrators around the time of the crime and trial Davis pointed out that, in cases like this which involved female and male sadists, "the female's role is invariably forgotten over time. This was apparent when Dudson's appeals were reported in the national press. Manchester newspapers named all of the killers involved, but most less-localised reports simply referred to the 'violent gang' he belonged to, and it probably wouldn't have occurred to newer readers that this gang included two merciless female sadists who thought that an allegedly stolen duffle coat was an excuse to torture someone to death."<ref name=davis />
==="Video nasties"=== The moral panic was not confined solely to the gender of the murderers, but also the role played by so-called "[[Video nasty|video nasties]]".<ref name="lowe">{{Cite news|title=The curse of Chucky|work=[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]|url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/news/2623743/Sick-film-Childs-Play-has-been-linked-to-various-crimes.html|accessdate=16 October 2010|location=London|first =David|last=Lowe|page=12|date=5 September 2009}}</ref> The news media immediately made a connection between the [[murder of James Bulger|Bulger murder trial]] and the Capper murder trial when the horror movie ''[[Child's Play 3|Child's Play 3: Look Who's Stalking]]'' was mentioned as part of the testimonies. D.I. Wall said "throughout interviews with the accused there was no suggestion that the reason Suzanne was killed had anything to do with "''Child's Play''" but this was overlooked by more sensationalist headlines (''Demonic doll Chucky links the horror crimes''; ''The curse of Chucky'').<ref name=lowe /><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1211089/The-case-young-attackers-chilling-echoes-James-Bulger-sadists.html|accessdate=16 October 2010|title=Demonic doll Chucky links the horror crimes|work=[[Daily Mail]]|location=London|date=4 September 2009|first=Arthur|last=Martin|page=6}}</ref> Neither Powell or McNeilly owned a video recorder, and the ''Child's Play''-inspired music that had been used to torture Capper was a popular track at the time, taped direct from Manchester's [[Piccadilly Magic 1152|Piccadilly Radio]].<ref name=horrortape /><ref>{{Cite news|title=U.K. Proposes Rules, Penalties On Rental Of Violent Videos|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|location=New York|date=23 April 1994}}</ref> Broadcaster [[David Elstein]] called the video connection "a false story... branded into the consciousness of the media," and questioned the news media's fascination with the film: "There is no reason to believe that Suzanne Capper would be alive today if the audiotape had instead contained the torture scene from ''[[King Lear]]'', or a catchphrase from [[Bruce Forsyth]] ... But the ''Child's Play'' hare has been running ever since the last day of the James Bulger murder trial."<ref name="elstein">{{Cite news|title=Demonising a decoy|work=The Guardian|location=London|date=22 December 1993|first=David|last=Elstein}}</ref> Elstein argued that the film was simply a [[Scapegoating|scapegoat]] which the press "made a three-course meal out of." ''The Guardian'' reported that 21,000 four- to nine-year-olds watched each of [[Sky UK|BSkyB]]'s two transmissions of ''Child's Play 3''—but Elstein explained the figure was "simply a projection based on an average of just two actual viewers from [[Broadcasters' Audience Research Board|BARB]]'s reporting panel, and that the [[margin of error]] means even the two may have been just one. But why spoil a good running story by asking what the figures mean?"<ref name=elstein />
In April 1994, Professor Elizabeth Newson published ''Video Violence and the Protection of Children'' (the "Newson Report") which attracted huge media interest due to its claims that it had "definitively established the long sought-for link between screen violence and the real-life variety," and which cited the Capper murder as an example.<ref name="briggs">{{Cite book|title=The media: an introduction|first1=Adam|last1=Briggs|first2=Paul|last2=Cobley|year=2002|publisher=Pearson Education|location=Harlow|isbn=978-0-582-42346-6}}</ref><ref name="brooke">{{cite web|url=http://www.screenonline.org.uk/film/id/591456/index.html|title=The Newson Report|first=Michael|last=Brooke|accessdate=2 October 2010|work=[[British Film Institute]]}}</ref> Despite its support by the press, however, the report failed to demonstrate any definitive link, "merely drawing inferences from ... often highly speculative accounts in the press rather than independent first-hand research."<ref name=brooke /> Newson was called to give oral evidence to the House of Commons Home Affairs Select Committee on Video Violence, where she asserted: "The Suzanne Capper case is another example of very explicit imitation of video and the use of video and that was ''Child's Play 3''." The chairman of the committee, Sir Ivan Lawrence had to point out to Newson that this was incorrect, and that both the police and the [[British Board of Film Classification]] had ruled out any connection between the movie and the murder.<ref name=briggs />
The link between the murders and ''Child's Play 3'' by the news media directly led to the delay of the release certification for both ''[[Natural Born Killers]]'' and ''[[Reservoir Dogs]]''.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Media ethics: a philosophical approach|first=Matthew|last=Kieran|isbn=978-0-275-95634-9|publisher=Praeger|location=Westport, CT|year=1997}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Murder of Shanda Sharer]] *[[Murder of Kelly Anne Bates]] *[[Murder of James Bulger]] *[[Murder of Jennifer Daugherty]] *[[Sadistic personality disorder]]
==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}}
{{Good article}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Capper, Suzanne}} [[Category:1992 crimes in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Deaths by person]] [[Category:1992 in England]] [[Category:20th century in Manchester]] [[Category:Kidnappings in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Murder in 1992]] [[Category:Murder in Greater Manchester]] [[Category:Torture in England]] [[Category:December 1992 events]] [[Category:1993 in England]]

Corrected spelling of 0Ⅹ (zero times Roman ten), added reference.
revision.text:
'''Of Man and Manta''' is a trilogy of [[science fiction]] novels written by [[Piers Anthony]]. It consists of the three books: '''''Omnivore''''' (1968), '''''Orn''''' (1970), and '''''{{underline|{{overline|0Ⅹ}}}}''''' (1975).
''Omnivore'' has as its frame the investigation of the deaths of eighteen travelers from Earth to the distant planet Nacre. Nacre is seen through the eyes of three surviving scientist-explorers: Cal, Veg, and Aquilon.
The planet Nacre's dominant species are [[fungus|fungi]], including the intelligent ''mantas''. The mantas are soft-bodied creatures capable of high speeds and flight, superficially resembling [[manta rays]]. They are carnivores who farm the one extant herbivore species by protecting them from the voracious omnivore species. The planet is notable for its thick atmosphere, which allows flight to be performed with less energy, and permits the existence of air-borne [[phytoplankton]]. The herbivores eat the plankton, and the omnivores eat anything they can. The human characters' diets play an important role in their interaction with the native species. Aquilon eats a normal human diet—she is an omnivore. Veg is a vegetarian. Cal is forced to drink blood to survive, due to a medical condition.
''Orn'' involves travel by the scientists and ''mantas'' into a parallel dimension they dub Paleo, resembling the distant past of Earth, where they encounter dinosaur species and an intelligent flightless bird called ''Orn''. Orn has the ability of genetic memory, able to remember anything that happened to an ancestor prior to the time of their reproduction. Much of the plot conflict stems from the love triangle between the protagonists and the mysterious motives of a cybernetically-augmented government agent sent along to monitor their progress.
''{{underline|{{overline|0Ⅹ}}}}'' involves the three scientists attempting to return to Earth from another dimension inhabited by hostile machines. Interlopers from other realities (using technology similar to that of the scientists' government) guide and hamper the explorers. A secondary story tells of a multidimensional [[cellular automaton]] energy being named {{underline|{{overline|0Ⅹ}}}}<ref>{{cite book |last=Anthony |first=Piers |date=1978 |title=0Ⅹ |url=http://www.mundania.com/book.php?title=OX |location=England |publisher=Avon |page= |isbn=9781594260704 |author-link=Piers Anthony |quote=...{{underline|{{overline|0Ⅹ}}}} defines himself as the code designation of Zero X, or Arabic numeral nothing multiplied by the Roman numeral ten...}}</ref> and its attempts to share living space with an infant human male, a fledgling creature of Orn's species, and one of the manta-carnivores; their developing relationship leads to attempts to learn the reasons for their strange isolation from others of their kind, which eventually ties into the story of Cal, Veg, and Aquilon.
==Reception== [[Lester del Rey]] found ''Orn'' to be "the most enjoyable book by Anthony" to date (1972), an improvement "in many ways" over ''Omnivore''.<ref>"Reading Room", [[If (magazine)|''If'']], June 1972, p.116.</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * {{isfdb series|id=2889|title=Omnivore}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Of Man And Manta}} [[Category:Piers Anthony sequences]] [[Category:American science fiction novels]] [[Category:Science fiction book series]] [[Category:Cellular automata in popular culture]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Pancho Daniel | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = | birth_place = | death_date =1858 | death_place =Los Angeles, California | death_cause = Lynching | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | residence = | known_for = | education = | employer = | occupation =Bandit | title = | salary = | networth = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | boards = | religion = | spouse = | children = | parents = | relatives = | box_width = }} '''Pancho Daniel''' (?-1858) was a [[Californio]] [[bandit]], leader of the [[Flores Daniel Gang]] who was [[lynched]] in November 1858 while awaiting trial for his involvement in the murder of [[Los Angeles County Sheriff]] [[James R. Barton]].<ref name=Pfeifer>{{cite book|last=Pfeifer|first=Michael|title=The Roots of Rough Justice: Origins of American Lynching|year=2011|publisher=University of Illinois Press|pages=52–54}}</ref>
==Biography== Together with [[Juan Flores]], Pancho Daniel led a band of fifty robbers in California.<ref name=Gonzales>{{cite book|last=Gonzales-Day|first=Ken|title=Lynching in the West, 1850-1935|year=2006|publisher=Duke University Press|pages=190–198}}</ref> In 1857, the gang was reported to have robbed and murdered a German shopkeeper named George W. Pflugardt. Sheriff James Barton investigated the murder and, despite being warned against pursuing the band, he began to search for them. They were ambushed by the gang and Barton was killed, along with four of the men with him. Pancho Daniel was eventually captured in January 1858, and brought to Los Angeles to await trial.<ref name=Gonzales/>
Daniel's defense attorney, Captain Cameron E. Thom, was dissatisfied with the jury that had been appointed for Daniel's trial, on the basis that he considered them unable to deliver an impartial verdict. When Judge [[Benjamin Ignatius Hayes]] dissolved this jury and appointed a new one, Thom insisted that the judge dissolve this one as well. Upon examining the third jury, Thom asserted that no jurors from [[Los Angeles]] would be able to be impartial in the case and requested for a trial in [[Santa Barbara County]].<ref name=LoriLee>{{cite book|last=Wilson|first=Lori Lee|title=The Joaquin Band: The History Behind the Legend|year=2011|publisher=University of Nebraska Press|pages=237–238}}</ref>
On 30 November 1858, a group of citizens of Los Angeles County gathered at the Los Angeles jail where Daniel was being held, dissatisfied with the delay in bringing Daniel to justice. Obtaining the keys from the jail keeper by force, some individuals brought Daniel out and hanged him from the cross beam of the jail gate.<ref name=LoriLee/> At the inquest, the judge returned a verdict of 'death from strangulation, by a crowd of persons to the jury unknown'.<ref name=Gonzales/>
California Governor [[John B. Weller]] labelled this lynching as a 'barbarous and diabolical execution', issuing a reward of $1000 for the arrest of the perpetrators.<ref name=LoriLee/> Despite this, those responsible were never identified.<ref name=Gonzales/><ref name=LoriLee/>
==Further reading==
See Gold Dust and Gunsmoke: Tales of Gold Rush Outlaws, Gunfighters, Lawmen, and Vigilantes (1999) by John Boessenecker.
==References== {{Reflist}} {{Lynching in the United States}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Daniel, Pancho}} [[Category:1858 deaths]] [[Category:Lynching deaths in California]] [[Category:Outlaws of the American Old West]] [[Category:Criminals from California]] [[Category:Year of birth missing]] [[Category:Racially motivated violence against Hispanic and Latino Americans]] [[Category:Deaths by hanging]]

page.title: Periodic points of complex quadratic mappings

revision.comment: Bot: [[User:KolbertBot|HTTP→HTTPS]] (v481)
revision.text:
This article describes [[periodic point]]s of some [[Complex quadratic polynomial|complex quadratic map]]s. A '''map''' is a formula for computing a value of a variable based on its own previous value or values; a [[Quadratic equation|quadratic]] map is one that involves the previous value raised to the powers one and two; and a '''complex''' map is one in which the variable and the parameters are [[complex number]]s. A [[periodic point]] of a map is a value of the variable that occurs repeatedly after intervals of a fixed length.
These periodic points play a role in the theories of [[Fatou set|Fatou]] and [[Julia set]]s.
==Definitions==
Let
:<math>f_c(z)=z^2+c\,</math>
be the [[complex quadratic polynomial|complex quadric mapping]], where <math>z</math> and <math>c</math> are [[Complex number|complex-valued]].
Notationally, <math> \ f^{(k)} _c (z) </math> is the <math>\ k</math> -fold [[Function composition|composition]] of <math>f _c\,</math> with itself—that is, the value after the ''k''-th [[Iterated function|iteration of function]] <math>f _c.\,</math> Thus
:<math> \ f^{(k)} _c (z) = f_c(f^{(k-1)} _c (z)).</math>
Periodic points of a complex quadratic mapping of [[Frequency|period]]<math>\ p</math> are points<math> \ z</math> of the [[phase space|dynamical plane]] such that
:<math> f^{(p)} _c (z) = z,</math>
where<math>\ p</math> is the smallest positive integer for which the equation holds at that ''z''.
We can introduce a new function:
:<math> \ F_p(z,f) = f^{(p)} _c (z) - z,</math>
so periodic points are zeros of function <math> \ F_p(z,f) </math>: points ''z'' satisfying
:<math> F_p(z,f) = 0,</math>
which is a polynomial of degree <math> 2^p.</math>
==Stability of periodic points (orbit) - multiplier== [[File:Multiplier4 f.png|right|thumb|Stability index of periodic points along horizontal axis]] [[File:Mandelbrot set Components.jpg|right|thumb|boundaries of regions of parameter plane with attracting orbit of periods 1-6]] [[File:Critical orbit 3d.png|right|thumb|Critical orbit of discrete dynamical system based on [[complex quadratic polynomial]]. It tends to weakly [[Attractor|attracting]] [[Fixed point (mathematics)|fixed point]] with abs(multiplier)=0.99993612384259]]
The '''[[Multiplication|multiplier]]''' (or eigenvalue, derivative) <math>m(f^p,z_0)=\lambda \,</math> of a rational map <math>f\,</math> iterated <math>p</math> times at cyclic point <math>z_0\,</math>is defined as:
:<math> m(f^p,z_0)=\lambda = \begin{cases} f^{p \prime}(z_0), &\mbox{if }z_0\ne \infty \\ \frac{1}{f^{p \prime} (z_0)}, & \mbox{if }z_0 = \infty \end{cases} </math>
where <math>f^{p\prime} (z_0)</math> is the [[Complex quadratic polynomial|first derivative]] of<math> \ f^p</math> with respect to <math>z\,</math> at <math>z_0</math>.
Because the multiplier is the same at all periodic points on a given orbit, it is called a multiplier of the periodic [[orbit (dynamics)|orbit]].
The multiplier is: *a [[complex number]]; *invariant under conjugation of any rational map at its fixed point;<ref>Alan F. Beardon, Iteration of Rational Functions, Springer 1991, {{ISBN|0-387-95151-2}}, p. 41</ref> *used to check stability of periodic (also fixed) points with '''stability index''' <math>abs(\lambda). \,</math>
A periodic point is<ref>Alan F. Beardon, ''Iteration of Rational Functions'', Springer 1991, {{ISBN|0-387-95151-2}}, page 99</ref> * attracting when <math>abs(\lambda) < 1; \,</math> ** super-attracting when <math>abs(\lambda) = 0; \,</math> ** attracting but not super-attracting when <math>0 < abs(\lambda) < 1; \,</math> * indifferent when <math>abs(\lambda) = 1; \,</math> ** rationally indifferent or parabolic if <math>\lambda \,</math> is a [[root of unity]]; ** [[Siegel disc|irrationally indifferent]] if <math>abs(\lambda)=1 \,</math> but multiplier is not a root of unity; * repelling when <math>abs(\lambda) > 1. \,</math>
Periodic points * that are attracting are always in the [[Classification of Fatou components|Fatou set]]; * that are repelling are in the Julia set; * that are indifferent fixed points may be in one or the other.<ref>[http://www.ijon.de/mathe/julia/some_julia_sets_1_en.html Some Julia sets by Michael Becker]</ref> A parabolic periodic point is in the Julia set.
==Period-1 points (fixed points)==
===Finite fixed points=== Let us begin by finding all [[Wikt:finite|finite]] points left unchanged by one application of <math>f</math>. These are the points that satisfy <math>f_c(z)=z</math>. That is, we wish to solve
: <math>z^2+c=z,\,</math>
which can be rewritten as
: <math>\ z^2-z+c=0.</math>
Since this is an ordinary quadratic equation in one unknown, we can apply [[Quadratic equation|the standard quadratic solution formula]]:
: <math>\alpha_1 = \frac{1-\sqrt{1-4c}}{2}</math> and <math>\alpha_2 = \frac{1+\sqrt{1-4c}}{2}.</math> So for <math>c \in C \setminus [1/4,+\infty]</math> we have two [[Wikt:finite|finite]] fixed points <math>\alpha_1 \,</math> and <math>\alpha_2\, </math>.
Since : <math>\alpha_1 = \frac{1}{2}-m</math> and <math>\alpha_2 = \frac{1}{2}+ m</math> where <math>m = \frac{\sqrt{1-4c}}{2}</math>
then <math>\alpha_1 + \alpha_2 = 1</math>.
Thus fixed points are symmetrical around <math>z = 1/2</math>.
[[File:JuliaRay3.png|thumb|right|This image shows fixed points (both repelling)]]
====Complex dynamics==== [[File:Fixed.png|right|thumb|Fixed points for c along horizontal axis]] [[File:Julia0bb.jpg|thumb| [[Fatou set]] for F(z)=z*z with marked fixed point]]
Here different notation is commonly used:<ref>[http://www.math.nagoya-u.ac.jp/~kawahira/works/cauliflower.pdf On the regular leaf space of the cauliflower by Tomoki Kawahira Source: Kodai Math. J. Volume 26, Number 2 (2003), 167-178. ] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717033213/http://www.math.nagoya-u.ac.jp/~kawahira/works/cauliflower.pdf |date=2011-07-17 }}</ref>
: <math>\alpha_c = \frac{1-\sqrt{1-4c}}{2}</math> with multiplier <math>\lambda_{\alpha_c} = 1-\sqrt{1-4c}\,</math>
and
:<math>\beta_c = \frac{1+\sqrt{1-4c}}{2}</math> with multiplier <math>\lambda_{\beta_c} = 1+\sqrt{1-4c}.\,</math>
Using [[Viète's formulas]] one can show that:
:<math> \alpha_c + \beta_c = 1 .</math>
Since [[Complex quadratic polynomial#Derivative with respect to z|the derivative with respect to z]] is
:<math>P_c'(z) = \frac{d}{dz}P_c(z) = 2z ,</math>
then
:<math>P_c'(\alpha_c) + P_c'(\beta_c)= 2 \alpha_c + 2 \beta_c = 2 (\alpha_c + \beta_c) = 2 . \,</math>
This implies that <math>P_c \,</math> can have at most one attractive fixed point.
These points are distinguished by the facts that: * <math>\beta_c \,</math> is: **the landing point of the [[external ray]] for angle=0 for <math>c \in M \setminus \left \{ \frac{1}{4} \right \}</math> **the most repelling fixed point of the Julia set ** the one on the right (whenever fixed point are not symmetrical around the real axis), it is the extreme right point for connected Julia sets (except for cauliflower).<ref>[http://www.ibiblio.org/e-notes/MSet/Attractor.htm Periodic attractor by Evgeny Demidov] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080511195806/http://www.ibiblio.org/e-notes/MSet/Attractor.htm |date=2008-05-11 }}</ref> * <math>\alpha_c \,</math> is: ** the landing point of several rays **attracting when <math>c</math> is in the main cardioid of the Mandelbrot set, in which case it is in the interior of a filled-in Julia set, and therefore belongs to the Fatou set (strictly to the basin of attraction of finite fixed point) **parabolic at the root point of the limb of the Mandelbrot set **repelling for other values of <math>c</math>
====Special cases====
An important case of the quadratic mapping is <math>c=0</math>. In this case, we get <math>\alpha_1 = 0</math> and <math>\alpha_2=1</math>. In this case, 0 is a superattractive [[Fixed point (mathematics)|fixed point]], and 1 belongs to the [[Julia set]].
====Only one fixed point====
We have <math>\alpha_1=\alpha_2</math> exactly when <math>1-4c=0.</math> This equation has one solution, <math>c=1/4,</math> in which case <math>\alpha_1=\alpha_2=1/2</math>. In fact <math>c=1/4</math> is the largest positive, purely real value for which a finite attractor exists.
===Infinite fixed point===
We can extend the [[complex plane]] <math>\mathbb{C}</math> to the [[Riemann sphere|Riemann sphere (extended complex plane)]] <math>\mathbb{\hat{C}}</math> by adding [[Point at infinity|infinity]] :
:<math>\mathbb{\hat{C}} = \mathbb{C} \cup \{ \infty \}</math>
and extending [[Complex quadratic polynomial|polynomial]] <math>f_c\,</math>such that <math>f_c(\infty)=\infty. \,</math>
Then [[Point at infinity|infinity]] is : *superattracting *a fixed point of [[Complex quadratic polynomial|polynomial]] <math>f_c: \,</math><ref>[[Robert L. Devaney|R L Devaney]], [[Linda Keen|L Keen]] (Editor): Chaos and Fractals: The Mathematics Behind the Computer Graphics. Publisher: Amer Mathematical Society July 1989, {{ISBN|0-8218-0137-6}} , {{ISBN|978-0-8218-0137-6}}</ref>
:<math>f_c(\infty)=\infty=f^{-1}_c(\infty).\,</math>
==Period-2 cycles== [[File:Bifurcation1-2.png|right|thumb|300px|Bifurcation from period 1 to 2 for [[complex quadratic polynomial|complex quadratic map]]]]
Period-2 cycles are two distinct points <math>\beta_1</math> and <math>\beta_2</math> such that <math>f_c(\beta_1) = \beta_2</math> and <math>f_c(\beta_2) = \beta_1</math>.
We write <math>f_c(f_c(\beta_n)) = \beta_n:</math>
: <math>f_c(f_c(z)) = (z^2+c)^2+c = z^4 + 2cz^2 + c^2 + c.\,</math>
Equating this to ''z'', we obtain
:<math>z^4 + 2cz^2 - z + c^2 + c = 0.</math>
This equation is a polynomial of degree 4, and so has four (possibly non-distinct) solutions. However, we already know two of the solutions. They are <math>\alpha_1</math> and <math>\alpha_2</math>, computed above, since if these points are left unchanged by one application of <math>f</math>, then clearly they will be unchanged by more than one application of <math>f</math>.
Our 4th-order polynomial can therefore be factored in 2 ways:
===First method of factorization===
: <math>(z-\alpha_1)(z-\alpha_2)(z-\beta_1)(z-\beta_2) = 0.\,</math>
This expands directly as <math>x^4 - Ax^3 + Bx^2 - Cx + D = 0</math> (note the alternating signs), where
: <math>D = \alpha_1 \alpha_2 \beta_1 \beta_2, \,</math>
: <math>C = \alpha_1 \alpha_2 \beta_1 + \alpha_1 \alpha_2 \beta_2 + \alpha_1 \beta_1 \beta_2 + \alpha_2 \beta_1 \beta_2, \,</math>
: <math>B = \alpha_1 \alpha_2 + \alpha_1 \beta_1 + \alpha_1 \beta_2 + \alpha_2 \beta_1 + \alpha_2 \beta_2 + \beta_1 \beta_2, \,</math>
: <math>A = \alpha_1 + \alpha_2 + \beta_1 + \beta_2.\,</math>
We already have two solutions, and only need the other two. Hence the problem is equivalent to solving a quadratic polynomial. In particular, note that
: <math>\alpha_1 + \alpha_2 = \frac{1-\sqrt{1-4c}}{2} + \frac{1+\sqrt{1-4c}}{2} = \frac{1+1}{2} = 1</math>
and
: <math>\alpha_1 \alpha_2 = \frac{(1-\sqrt{1-4c})(1+\sqrt{1-4c})}{4} = \frac{1^2 - (\sqrt{1-4c})^2}{4}= \frac{1 - 1 + 4c}{4} = \frac{4c}{4} = c.</math>
Adding these to the above, we get <math>D = c \beta_1 \beta_2</math> and <math>A = 1 + \beta_1 + \beta_2</math>. Matching these against the coefficients from expanding <math>f</math>, we get
: <math>D = c \beta_1 \beta_2 = c^2 + c</math> and <math>A = 1 + \beta_1 + \beta_2 = 0.</math>
From this, we easily get
:<math>\beta_1 \beta_2 = c + 1</math> and <math>\beta_1 + \beta_2 = -1</math>.
From here, we construct a quadratic equation with <math>A' = 1, B = 1, C = c+1</math> and apply the standard solution formula to get
: <math>\beta_1 = \frac{-1 - \sqrt{-3 -4c}}{2}</math> and <math>\beta_2 = \frac{-1 + \sqrt{-3 -4c}}{2}.</math>
Closer examination shows that :
:<math>f_c(\beta_1) = \beta_2</math> and <math>f_c(\beta_2) = \beta_1,</math>
meaning these two points are the two points on a single period-2 cycle.
===Second method of factorization=== We can factor the quartic by using [[polynomial long division]] to divide out the factors <math>(z-\alpha_1)</math> and <math>(z-\alpha_2), </math> which account for the two fixed points <math>\alpha_1</math> and <math>\alpha_2</math> (whose values were given earlier and which still remain at the fixed point after two iterations):
:<math>(z^2+c)^2 + c -z = (z^2 + c - z)(z^2 + z + c +1 ). \,</math>
The roots of the first factor are the two fixed points. They are repelling outside the main cardioid.
The second factor has the two roots
:<math>-\frac{1}{2} \pm (-\frac{3}{4} - c)^\frac{1}{2}. \,</math>
These two roots, which are the same as those found by the first method, form the period-2 orbit.<ref>[http://www.ibiblio.org/e-notes/MSet/Attractor.htm Period 2 orbit by Evgeny Demidov] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080511195806/http://www.ibiblio.org/e-notes/MSet/Attractor.htm |date=2008-05-11 }}</ref>
====Special cases==== Again, let us look at <math>c=0</math>. Then
: <math>\beta_1 = \frac{-1 - i\sqrt{3}}{2}</math> and <math>\beta_2 = \frac{-1 + i\sqrt{3}}{2},</math>
both of which are complex numbers. We have <math>| \beta_1 | = | \beta_2 | = 1</math>. Thus, both these points are "hiding" in the Julia set. Another special case is <math>c=-1</math>, which gives <math>\beta_1 = 0</math> and <math>\beta_2 = -1</math>. This gives the well-known superattractive cycle found in the largest period-2 lobe of the quadratic Mandelbrot set.
==Cycles for period greater than 2==
The degree of the equation <math> f^{(n)}(z)=z</math> is 2<sup>''n''</sup>; thus for example, to find the points on a 3-cycle we would need to solve an equation of degree 8. After factoring out the factors giving the two fixed points, we would have a sixth degree equation.
[[Abel–Ruffini theorem|There is no general solution]] in [[Nth root|radicals]] to polynomial equations of degree five or higher, so the points on a cycle of period greater than 2 must in general be computed using [[Root-finding algorithm|numerical methods]]. However, in the specific case of period 4 the cyclical points have lengthy expressions in radicals.<ref>[https://arxiv.org/abs/0802.2565 Gvozden Rukavina : Quadratic recurrence equations - exact explicit solution of period four fixed points functions in bifurcation diagram]</ref>
In the case ''c'' = –2, [[trigonometry|trigonometric]] solutions exist for the periodic points of all periods. The case <math>z_{n+1}=z_n^2-2</math> is equivalent to the [[logistic map]] case ''r'' = 4: <math>x_{n+1}=4x_n(1-x_n).</math> Here the equivalence is given by <math>z=2-4x.</math> One of the ''k''-cycles of the logistic variable ''x'' (all of which cycles are repelling) is
:<math>\sin^2\left(\frac{2\pi}{2^k-1}\right), \, \sin^2\left(2\cdot\frac{2\pi}{2^k-1}\right), \, \sin^2\left(2^2\cdot\frac{2\pi}{2^k-1}\right), \, \sin^2\left(2^3\cdot\frac{2\pi}{2^k-1}\right), \dots , \sin^2\left(2^{k-1}\frac{2\pi}{2^k-1}\right).</math>
==References== {{Reflist}}
== Further reading == *Alan F. Beardon, Iteration of Rational Functions, Springer 1991, {{ISBN|0-387-95151-2}} *Michael F. Barnsley (Author), Stephen G. Demko (Editor), Chaotic Dynamics and Fractals (Notes and Reports in Mathematics in Science and Engineering Series) Academic Pr (April 1986), {{ISBN|0-12-079060-2}} *[http://www.math.sunysb.edu/cgi-bin/thesis.pl?thesis02-3 Wolf Jung : Homeomorphisms on Edges of the Mandelbrot Set. Ph.D. thesis of 2002] *[http://hdl.handle.net/10090/3895 The permutations of periodic points in quadratic polynominials by J Leahy]
==External links== {{Wikibooks|Fractals }} *[http://cosinekitty.com/mandel_orbits_analysis.html ''Algebraic solution of Mandelbrot orbital boundaries'' by Donald D. Cross ] *[http://www.mrob.com/pub/muency/brownmethod.html ''Brown Method'' by Robert P. Munafo] *[https://arxiv.org/abs/hep-th/0501235 arXiv:hep-th/0501235v2] V.Dolotin, A.Morozov: ''Algebraic Geometry of Discrete Dynamics''. The case of one variable.
{{DEFAULTSORT:Periodic Points Of Complex Quadratic Mappings}} [[Category:Complex dynamics]] [[Category:Fractals]] [[Category:Limit sets]]

revision.text:
[[File:The Mythology of all races (1918) (14760898654).jpg|thumb|Funerary pyre of a Buddhist monk in the early 20th century]] '''Phongyibyan''' ({{lang-my|ဘုန်းကြီးပျံ}}; also spelt '''pongyibyan''' or '''phongyibyan pwe''') is a [[Burmese language]] term for the ceremonial [[cremation]] of high-ranking [[Buddhist monk]]s, in particular monks from Myanmar's largest Buddhist order, the [[Thudhamma Nikaya]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=|title=Buddhist Funeral Cultures of Southeast Asia and China|last=Robinne|first=François|last2=|first2=|date=2012-04-26|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=|isbn=9781107377998|editor-last=Williams|editor-first=Paul|location=|pages=|language=en|chapter=Theatre of death and rebirth: monks’ funerals in Burma}}</ref> Controversy has surrounded the expenses involved in financing such expensive ceremonies.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://religionnews.com/2015/03/02/buddhist-monks-cremation-ceremonies-break-bank-impoverished-myanmar/|title=Buddhist monks' cremation ceremonies break the bank in impoverished Myanmar|last=Myint Naing|first=|date=March 2, 2015|website=Religion News Service|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-05-04}}</ref>
== Regional observances == [[File:Burmese monk funeral.JPG|thumb|A Burmese ceremonial hearse featuring the [[hamsa|hintha]] bird.]]
Phongyibyan is widely observed by Buddhists throughout [[Myanmar]], including the [[Bamar people|Bamar]], [[Mon people|Mon]], [[Rakhine people|Rakhine]], and [[Shan people]]s. Similarly elaborate cremation ceremonies, congruous with those in Myanmar, are also held by the [[Northern Thai people]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hall|first=Rebecca S.|date=|title=Onward toward Heaven: Burning the Nok Hatsadiling|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.3998/ars.13441566.0044.010|journal=Ars Orientalis|volume=44|pages=|via=}}</ref> Among the Shan and Lanna peoples, the ceremony is known as '''''poy law''''' (ပွႆးလေႃ or ปอยล้อ),<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.mcu.ac.th/En/thesiscontent_desc.php?ct=1&t_id=864|title=Value of Poi-Law in Lanna: A Case Study of Phrakrugaroonyathamniwas (Laung Poolaung Katapunyo)|last=Phramaha Veerachone Akkadhammo (Khomsonphan)|first=|date=July 29, 2012|website=Mahachulalongkornrajavidyalaya University|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> which literally means "ceremony of the cart,"<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Keyes|first=Charles|date=2006|title=Tug of War for Merit: Cremation of a Senior Monk|url=https://www.academia.edu/9228114/Tug_of_War_for_Merit_Cremation_of_a_Senior_Monk_rev|journal=Journal of the Siam Society|language=en|volume=|pages=1-21|via=}}</ref> whereby ''poy'' is a Burmese [[loanword]] meaning "festival" or "ceremony" (cf. [[Poy Sang Long]]).
== Timing == The ceremonial cremation does not necessarily occur immediately after a monk's death. In Northern Thailand, they are typically held between December and March; and in Myanmar, these ceremonies are not held during the [[Vassa]] (Buddhist lent).<ref name=":2" /> The ceremony typically lasts between 3 to 7 days, depending on the ability of worshippers to organize and finance the ceremonies.<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Keyes|first=Charles|title=Anusaranaśāsanākiarti, Phra Khrū, and Charles Keyes "Funerary Rites and the Buddhist Meaning of Death: An Interpretative Text from Northern Thailand"|url=https://www.academia.edu/8989119/Anusarana%C5%9B%C4%81san%C4%81kiarti_Phra_Khr%C5%AB_and_Charles_Keyes_Funerary_Rites_and_the_Buddhist_Meaning_of_Death_An_Interpretative_Text_from_Northern_Thailand_|journal=Journal of the Siam Society |volume=68 |issue=1 |pages=1-29 |year=1980|language=en}}</ref>
== Ceremonial rituals == Some rites have parallels to accounts of the Buddha’s own funeral found in the [[Mahaparinibbana Sutta]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.niu.edu/burma/publications/jbs/author/ijk.shtml|title=Abstracts by Author|last=|first=|date=|website=Northern Illinois University|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-05-04}}</ref> An elaborate set of ceremonies, including staged plays, ritual performances, and construction of temporary pyre structures, constitute the cremation. Immediately after the monk's death, the body is embalmed. After the cremation, the remains are collected and housed in a reliquary.<ref name=":3" />
[[File:The cremation of a pôngyi.jpg|thumb|The funerary pyre tower or ''laungdaik''.]] A temporary mortuary chapel called ''neibban kyaung'' (နိဗ္ဗာန်ကျောင်း), with a multi-tiered [[pyatthat]] roof, is constructed to house the coffin.<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=Isaacs|first=Ralph|date=2009|title=Rockets and Ashes: Pongyibyan as Depicted in Nineteenth- and Twentieth-Century European Sources|url=https://muse.jhu.edu/article/411202/summary|journal=Journal of Burma Studies|language=en|volume=13|issue=1|pages=107–136|doi=10.1353/jbs.2009.0003|issn=2010-314X}}</ref> The monk may lie in state for several months, while donations are gathered to fund the cremation ceremonies.<ref name=":4" /> A massive funerary pyre tower called ''laungdaik'' (လောင်တိုက်), representing [[Mount Meru]], along with numerous subsidiary towers, is also constructed by specialist bamboo artisans called ''sat-hsaya'' (စပ်ဆရာ).<ref name=":4" />
[[File:Indian pictures and problems (1907) (14775311334).jpg|thumb|Crematory hearse in Yangon]] Ceremonial crematory [[hearse]]s are often constructed for the cremation, often featuring mythical animals. These hearses or floats are used to transport the coffin to the funerary pyre.<ref name=":4" /> The Burmese use hearses featuring [[Hamsa (bird)|hamsa]].<ref name=":2" /> While the Shan construct hearses featuring the [[karaweik]] (a mythical bird), their Northern Thai counterparts build [[hearse]]s featuring the [[Hatsadiling|nok hatsadiling]] (นกหัสดีลิงค์), a mythical elephant-headed bird.<ref name=":1" /> The pyre is often ignited using rockets or fireworks.<ref name=":4" />
Another important ritual during the phongyibyan is a tug-of-war of the funerary pyres, called ''lun hswe'' (လွန်ဆွဲ) in Burmese, and ''lak prasat'' (ลากปราสาท, lit. "pulling of the prasat") in Thai.<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":2" /> This tug-of-war is believed to generate [[Merit (Buddhism)|merit]].<ref name=":3" /> The [[Rakhine people]] perform the ''tala aka'' (တလားအက) during the cremation ceremony, whereby around two dozen men carry the bedecked coffin using a bamboo frame, while dancing in unison to the tune of a Burmese [[hsaing waing]] orchestra.<ref>{{Citation|last=Duwun|title=ရခိုင်ရိုးရာ တလားအက|date=2018-08-15|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aH_jOJSFZOw|access-date=2018-09-05}}</ref>
A staged play called ''eiyin'' (ဧယင်), which reflects the pain of the living mourning the departed and combines the Buddhist concept of [[Rebirth (Buddhism)|rebirth]] and the monk's virtues and life, is performed from the moment the coffin leaves the monastery to the time of cremation.<ref name=":0" /> These performances are held during the daytime, generally held in temporary gilt pavilions called ''san kyaung'' (စံကျောင်း), which are erected in the monastery grounds or the village squares.<ref name=":0" />
==Gallery== <gallery> File:Burmese monk funeral carriage.jpg File:Pya-That - Burmese monk funeral car.jpg File:Myanmar - Buddhist funeral with large funeral pyre circa 1903.jpg File:Burmese Funeral procession 1900.jpg File:Burma (1900) (14593384728).jpg File:Chan Kusalo cremation 01.jpg File:Chan Kusalo cremation 04.jpg </gallery>
==References== {{reflist}}
==See also== *[[Buddhism in Burma]] *[[Buddhist funeral]]
{{Religion in Myanmar}}
[[Category:Buddhism in Myanmar]] [[Category:Buddhist practices]] [[Category:Funerals]] [[Category:Death customs]] [[Category:Cremation]] [[Category:Religion and death]] [[Category:Northern Thai culture]] [[Category:Burmese words and phrases]]
