{{Redirect|Ruby and Sapphire|the ''Steven Universe'' characters|Garnet (character)|the minerals|Corundum}} {{Use mdy dates|date=March 2016}} {{DISPLAYTITLE:''Pokémon Ruby'' and ''Sapphire''}} {{Infobox video game |title = ''Pokémon Ruby''
''Pokémon Sapphire'' |collapsible = | state = |image = File:Pokemon Ruby NA.jpg |caption = North American box art for ''Pokémon Ruby'', depicting the [[Gameplay of Pokémon#Legendary Pokémon|legendary Pokémon]] [[Groudon]]. The box art for ''Pokémon Sapphire Version'' depicts the legendary Pokémon [[Kyogre]] (not pictured). |developer = [[Game Freak]] |publisher = [[The Pokémon Company]]
[[Nintendo]] |series = ''[[Pokémon (video game series)|Pokémon]]'' |platforms = [[Game Boy Advance]] |released = {{vgrelease|JP|November 21, 2002{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/gba/rpg/pokemonrubyversion/similar.html?mode=versions|title=Pokemon Ruby Version for Game Boy|publisher=[[GameSpot]]|accessdate=June 22, 2009}}|NA|March 19, 2003|AUS|April 3, 2003}}{{vgrelease|EU|July 25, 2003}} |genre = [[Role-playing video game]] |modes = [[Single-player]], [[Multiplayer video game|multiplayer]] |director = [[Junichi Masuda]]
[[Satoshi Tajiri]] |producer = Hiroyuki Jinnai
Takehiro Izushi
Hiroaki Tsuru |artist = [[Ken Sugimori]] |writer = Toshinobu Matsumiya
Akihito Tomisawa |composer = Go Ichinose
Morikazu Aoki
Junichi Masuda |italic title = no }} {{Nihongo foot|'''''Pokémon Ruby Version''''' and '''''Sapphire Version'''''|ポケットモンスタールビー・サファイア|Poketto Monsutā Rubī & Safaia|"Pocket Monsters: Ruby & Sapphire"|lead=yes|group=lower-alpha}} are [[role-playing video game]]s developed by [[Game Freak]], published by [[The Pokémon Company]] and [[Nintendo]] for the [[Game Boy Advance]]. They are the first installments in the third generation of the [[Pokémon (video game series)|''Pokémon'' video game series]], also known as the "advanced generation". For the first time after years of Nintendo publishing the games alone in all regions, The Pokémon Company began co-publishing the games since the establishment of the company by the owners of the franchise. They were first released in Japan in late 2002 and internationally in 2003. ''[[Pokémon Emerald]]'', a special edition version, was released two years later in each region. [[video game remake|Remakes]] of the two games, titled [[Pokémon Omega Ruby and Alpha Sapphire|''Pokémon Omega Ruby'' and ''Alpha Sapphire'']], were released for the [[Nintendo 3DS]] worldwide on November 21, 2014, exactly twelve years to the date of the original ''Ruby'' and ''Sapphire'' release date, with the exception of Europe, where it was released on November 28, 2014.{{cite web|url=http://www.pokemon.com/us/pokemon-video-games/pokemon-omega-ruby-and-pokemon-alpha-sapphire/|title=Pokémon Omega Ruby and Pokémon Alpha Sapphire|date=May 7, 2014|accessdate=May 7, 2014}} The gameplay is mostly unchanged from the previous games; the player controls the main character from an [[overhead perspective]], and the controls are largely the same as those of previous games. As with previous games, the main objectives are to catch all of the Pokémon in the games and defeat the [[Elite Four]] (a group of Pokémon trainers); also like their predecessors, the games' main subplot involves the main character defeating a criminal organization that attempts to take over the region. New features, such as double battles and Pokémon abilities along with 135 new Pokémon, have been added. As the Game Boy Advance is more powerful than its predecessors, four players may be connected at a time instead of the previous limit of two. Additionally, the games can be connected to an [[Nintendo e-Reader|e-Reader]] or other advanced generation ''Pokémon'' games. ''Ruby'' and ''Sapphire'' received mostly positive reviews, though critics were divided in their assessment of the games, especially on the gameplay and graphics. Most of the complaints focused on the fact that the gameplay had not changed much since previous generations, and the connectivity issues revolving around the past generations. With the popularity of Pokémon waning at the time, the games sold less than previous generations. However, they were still critical and commercial successes; with around 16 million copies sold according to [[IGN]], they are the best-selling games for the Game Boy Advance. ==Gameplay== {{main article|Gameplay of Pokémon}} The basic mechanics of ''Ruby'' and ''Sapphire'' are largely the same as their predecessors'. As with all ''Pokémon'' games for hand-held consoles, gameplay is in [[Grammatical person|third-person]], overhead perspective and consists of three basic screens: a [[overworld|field map]], in which the player navigates the main character; a battle screen; and the menu, in which the player configures their party, items, or gameplay settings. The player begins the game with one Pokémon, and can capture more using [[Poké Ball]]s. The player can also use their Pokémon to battle other Pokémon. When the player [[random encounter|encounters a wild Pokémon]] or is challenged by a trainer to a battle, the screen switches to a [[turn-based]] battle screen where the Pokémon fight.{{cite web|url=http://gameboy.ign.com/articles/389/389660p1.html|title=Pokemon: Ruby Version|publisher=[[News Corporation]]|work=[[IGN]]|first=Craig|last=Harris|date=March 17, 2003|accessdate=August 2, 2008}} During battle, the player may [[Gameplay of Pokémon#Pokémon moves|fight]], use an item, switch their active Pokémon, or flee (the last is not an option in battles against trainers). All Pokémon have [[hit points]] (HP); when a Pokémon's HP is reduced to zero, it faints and cannot battle until it is revived. If the player's Pokémon defeats the opposing Pokémon (causes it to faint), it receives [[experience points]]. After accumulating enough experience points, it may [[experience point#Level-based progression|level up]]; most Pokémon [[Pokémon evolution|evolve]] into a new species of Pokémon when they reach a certain level.''Pokémon Sapphire Version instruction booklet'', p. 35 Apart from battling, capturing Pokémon is the most essential element of ''Pokémon'' gameplay. During battle with a wild Pokémon (other trainers' Pokémon cannot be captured), the player may use a Poké Ball on the wild Pokémon. If successful, the Pokémon will be added to the player's active party (or stored if the player already has the maximum six Pokémon in his/her party).''Pokémon Sapphire Version instruction booklet'', p. 37 Factors in the success rate of capture include the HP (and/or status effects such as Paralysis or Sleep,) of the target Pokémon and the strength of the Poké Ball used: the lower the target's HP and the stronger the Poké Ball, the higher the success rate of capture is.''Pokémon Sapphire Version instruction booklet'', p. 32 ===New gameplay features=== The most prominent change in the battle mechanics is the introduction of double battles, in which the opposing parties each use two Pokémon at the same time. Consequently, certain Pokémon [[Gameplay of Pokémon#Pokémon moves|moves]] can affect multiple combatants at once.Hollinger, p.3 Multi battles were added alongside double battles. They are identical to double battle, but there are two trainers to a side, each controlling one of the two Pokémon sent out. Also new to the games are [[Gameplay of Pokémon#Pokémon abilities|innate abilities]] and [[Gameplay of Pokémon#Pokémon natures|natures]]; the former is shared by every Pokémon of a certain species, while the latter may vary among a particular species. Abilities grant their holders certain powers in battle, such as immunity against certain [[Pokémon types|types]] of moves or strengthening a certain type of move. Natures, like innate abilities, affect the strength of Pokémon in battle; however, they affect the stats of the Pokémon rather than directly affecting the strength of the moves.Hollinger, p.6 Another stat introduced in ''Pokémon Ruby'' and ''Sapphire'' is Condition, an important factor in [[Gameplay of Pokémon#Pokémon Contests|Pokémon Contests]], mini-games in which participants perform moves before a judge. Both Pokémon and their moves have a Condition, which is increased by using Pokéblocks (candies made from berries).Hollinger, p.76 ''Ruby'' and ''Sapphire'' were the first games to have different weather conditions (sunny, rain, hail, and sandstorm), and these affected battle in unique ways.{{cite web | url=https://sg.news.yahoo.com/pokemon-omega-ruby-alpha-sapphire-speculation-bingo-130033465.html | title=Pokemon Omega Ruby and Alpha Sapphire speculation bingo | publisher=Yahoo News Network | date=May 8, 2014 | accessdate=May 8, 2014 | author=Twang, Kuyani}} Secret bases were added as a one off feature where players could open up a hole in the world and customize the place with various items picked up in game. Players who linked up with others who set up secret bases were able to battle an NPC version of that trainer within their secret base. Like [[Pokémon Gold and Silver|''Pokémon Gold'', ''Silver'']], and [[Pokémon Crystal|''Crystal'']], ''Ruby'' and ''Sapphire'' keep track of real-life time; this influences events like tides and berry plant growth. However, unlike their predecessors, ''Ruby'' and ''Sapphire'' do not differentiate between day and night. Also, due to the differences in the technical specifications of Game Boy link cables and Game Boy Advance link cables, ''Ruby'' and ''Sapphire'' cannot be linked with Pokémon games of previous generations; one cannot battle with or trade to the previous generations.''Pokémon Sapphire Version instruction booklet'', p. 50. ===Connectivity with other devices=== ''Ruby'' and ''Sapphire'' have limited [[Nintendo e-Reader|e-Reader]] support. Nintendo released Battle-e Cards, a set of e-Reader cards that contained trainer battles in which the player could see previously-hidden Pokémon.{{cite web |url=http://gameboy.ign.com/articles/437/437914p1.html|title=Pokemon Battle-e Cards|publisher=[[News Corporation]]|work=[[IGN]] |first=Craig|last=Harris|date=September 12, 2003|accessdate=August 3, 2008}} A special e-Reader card called the Eon Ticket was also released; obtained through the Mystery Gift function, the Ticket allows the player to reach a place called Southern Island. There, the player faces either [[Latios]] or [[Latias]], depending on which version the player is using.{{cite web|url=http://www.pokemon-games.com/eon.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070819201845/http://www.pokemon-games.com/eon.html|archivedate=August 19, 2007|publisher=[[Nintendo]]|work=Pokemon-games.com|title=The Pokémon Ruby & Sapphire "EON Ticket" Summer Tour is coming to Toys 'R Us!|accessdate=July 18, 2008}} ''Ruby'' and ''Sapphire'' are also able to connect to the [[Nintendo GameCube|GameCube]] games ''[[Pokémon Colosseum]]'', ''[[Pokémon XD: Gale of Darkness]]'' and ''[[#Pokémon Box: Ruby and Sapphire|Pokémon Box]]''. In the former two, once players reach a certain point in the game, they are able to transfer Pokémon between ''Colosseum''/''XD'' and ''Ruby''/''Sapphire''.{{cite web|url=http://gameboy.ign.com/articles/454/454914p1.html|title=Pokemon Colosseum Linkup Revealed|publisher=[[News Corporation]]|work=[[IGN]]|date=October 15, 2003 |accessdate=July 17, 2008}} Additionally, those who pre-ordered ''Colosseum'' were able to access the Pokémon [[Jirachi]] and see a preview of the movie ''[[Pokémon: Jirachi Wish Maker]]''. ''Box'', a so-called Pokémon "[[Microsoft Office]]", allows players to store and organize their Pokémon on the GameCube.{{cite web|url=http://cube.ign.com/articles/533/533098p1.html |title=Pokemon Box: Ruby & Sapphire|publisher=[[News Corporation]]|work=[[IGN]]|first=Craig|last=Harris|date=July 3, 2004 |accessdate=July 17, 2008}} Also, in the European version of ''[[Pokémon Channel]]'', players could receive a Jirachi at a certain point in the game, which they could then transfer over to ''Ruby''/''Sapphire''. ==Synopsis== ===Setting=== [[File:Hoenn.jpg|thumb|''Ruby'' and ''Sapphire'' are set in the Hoenn region, designed to be similar to Japan's island of [[Kyushu]].]] ''Pokémon Ruby'' and ''Sapphire'' take place in the Hoenn region, located some distance from the Kanto and Johto regions featured in previous games. The design of Hoenn was based on the Japanese island and region of [[Kyushu]]; however Hoenn is rotated 90° relative to Kyushu, as Junichi Masuda felt that it would provide a better gameplay balance.{{cite web|url=http://www.gamefreak.co.jp/blog/dir_english/?p=29|title=Hidden Power of Masuda |publisher=GameFreak|date=September 9, 2004|accessdate=August 2, 2008}} Like Kyushu, Hoenn possesses many smaller islands, and part of the region is dominated by sea routes, several of which contain areas where the player can dive underwater. ===Story=== Like other ''Pokémon'' games, ''Ruby'' and ''Sapphire'''s gameplay is [[linear gameplay|linear]]; the main events occur in a fixed order.Hollinger, p.12 The [[protagonist]] of ''Pokémon Ruby'' and ''Sapphire'' is a child who has recently moved to a small town called Littleroot Town. At the beginning of the games, the player chooses either [[Treecko]], [[Torchic]], or [[Mudkip]] to protect Professor Birch, the regional professor, from an attacking [[poochyena]]. After defending Birch, the player is taken to his lab and receives the chosen Pokémon as his or her [[Gameplay of Pokémon#Starter Pokémon|starter Pokémon]] with the choice of Mudkip, Treecko, or Torchic. After that the player encounters May, daughter of Professor Birch. The player's rival, who appears as the professor's child, is also a [[Pokémon Trainer]] and occasionally battles the player.{{cite web|url=http://guides.ign.com/guides/17508/page_6.html|title=Walkthrough: Badge #1|publisher=[[News Corporation]]|work=[[IGN]]|accessdate=August 2, 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080709011448/http://guides.ign.com/guides/17508/page_6.html|archivedate=July 9, 2008|df=mdy-all}} The games' two main goals are defeating the eight Gym Leaders, proving oneself worthy of challenging the Elite Four and Champion to become the new Champion and completing the [[Pokédex]] by capturing, evolving, and trading to obtain all 202 Pokémon (It is possible to obtain all 386 Pokémon, but this requires trading with [[Pokémon FireRed and LeafGreen|''Pokémon FireRed'' and ''LeafGreen'']]).{{cite web |url=http://guides.ign.com/guides/17508/page_14.html|title=Guides: Pokemon Ruby/Sapphire Guide (GBA) Walkthrough: Pokemon League Championship|publisher=[[News Corporation]]|work=[[IGN]]|accessdate=August 2, 2008}} In addition to the main quest of defeating the Gym Leaders, there are side quests in which the player can aid [[Non-player character|NPC]]s by fulfilling tasks, usually by obtaining items. The most prominent subplot involves [[Team Aqua and Team Magma]], crime syndicates who want to use Pokémon to alter the climate of Hoenn: in ''Ruby'', the villains, Team Magma, want to use the legendary Pokémon [[Groudon]] to dry up the oceans of Hoenn and increase the region's landmass; in ''Sapphire'', the Team Aqua are the villains and they try to use Groudon's counterpart, [[Kyogre]], to flood the landmasses of Hoenn and increase the region's ocean.{{cite web|url=http://guides.ign.com/guides/17508/page_7.html|title=Walkthrough: Badge #2|publisher=[[News Corporation]]|work=[[IGN]]|accessdate=August 2, 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080706153004/http://guides.ign.com/guides/17508/page_7.html|archivedate=July 6, 2008|df=mdy-all}} Prior to facing the eighth Gym Leader, the player has a showdown with Magma/Aqua where the team's leader uses a mystical orb that awakens the slumbering Pokémon, believing it has the power to enthrall their respective target, only for the Pokémon to become enraged and cause catastrophic, region-wide climate changes—a drought in ''Ruby'', and heavy rainfall in ''Sapphire''—until it is defeated or captured by the player.Hollinger, pp. 61–62 The player's father also introduces the player to Wally, a sickly young boy whom the player helps capture a Pokémon to be his companion as he moves away from the big city. Wally eventually overcomes his illness and becomes a successful Pokémon trainer, ultimately becoming the final challenger the player must face before the Elite Four. ==Development and release== [[File:JunichiMasudaJI1.jpg|left|thumb|Development director [[Junichi Masuda]]]] ''Pokémon Ruby'' and ''Sapphire'' were developed by [[Game Freak]] and [[Nintendo]] under the direction of [[Junichi Masuda]]. As with its predecessors, [[Ken Sugimori]] was the art director, although these were the first games in which he did not single-handedly produce all of the art.{{cite web|url=http://www.gamefaqs.com/portable/gbadvance/data/471243.html|title=Pokemon Ruby Version Info|publisher=GameFAQs|accessdate=July 18, 2008}} When asked where his design team came up with the ideas for all of the new Pokémon, Sugimori stated that they got their ideas from past experiences in their childhood involving nature, animals, and the media and then base them on insects. Even looking at the world in a different perspective sometimes provided inspiration for the creatures. "First we select an insect and after that we add essential elements to the insects to make it more like Pokemon, such as adding some hard shape to it, to be more like steel," Sugimori said, describing the process of creating a Pokémon.{{cite interview |url=http://www.computerandvideogames.com/article.php?id=91965 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070211042435/http://www.computerandvideogames.com/article.php?id=91965 |title=Nintendo Interviews: Game Freak on Pokemon! |work=[[Computer and Video Games]] |publisher=[[Future plc]] |first1=Junichi |last1=Masuda |subject-link1=Junichi Masuda |first2=Shigeki |last2=Morimoto |subject-link2=Shigeki Morimoto |first3=Ken |last3=Sugimori |subject-link3=Ken Sugimori |interviewer=Stuart Bishop |date=May 30, 2003 |accessdate=July 18, 2008 |archivedate=February 11, 2007 |deadurl=yes }} As the Game Boy Advance was able to handle newer, enhanced graphics, ''Ruby'' and ''Sapphire'' were the first games in the series that allowed up to four people to share information at one time, as opposed to the previous limit of two. However, the development team used a more basic graphics engine in order to keep the game simple and not overly confusing. The team wanted the games to appeal to a large audience, so the game was designed to be easy enough for younger generations of children to play, but new features were added to bring the veteran gamers back. Masuda stated that the basic philosophy of all ''Pokémon'' games is communication; in the ''Pokémon'' series, this is manifested in trading and battling with other people. When asked about the new concept of [[Gameplay of Pokémon#Double battles|double battles]], the developers noted that they tried to focus more on the original one-on-one battles as the main type of competition and only added the double battles as a "new challenge". They stated that if they receive positive feedback about the double battles, the feature may appear more in future generations. The games were the first in the series that did not contain all of the Pokémon from previous generations. Sugimori stated that the team tried to include all the new Pokémon as well as some from previous generations. When asked about any features that could not be included due to technical restrictions, Masuda noted that he wanted each individual Pokémon to make up to three different cries depending on its mood. Nintendo did not promote ''Ruby'' and ''Sapphire'' at the 2002 [[E3 (Electronic Entertainment Expo)|E3]] convention;{{cite news|url=http://www.gamepro.com/article/previews/25010/pokemon-ruby-and-sapphire-versions|title=Preview: Pokemon: Ruby and Sapphire Versions|date=July 15, 2002 |work=[[Gamepro]]|publisher=IDG Entertainment|accessdate=November 30, 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090414111021/http://www.gamepro.com/article/previews/25010/pokemon-ruby-and-sapphire-versions|archivedate=April 14, 2009}} however, it launched a [[U.S. dollar|USD]] $7 million promotional campaign that lasted from March to May 2003.{{cite news|last=Elkin|first=Tobi |url=http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-23085650_ITM|title=Pokemon grows up with its demographic; Nintendo puts $7 mil behind latest versions.|publisher=[[Advertising Age]], [[Bnet]]|date=March 2003|accessdate=July 17, 2008|archiveurl=http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-23085650_ITM|archivedate=April 14, 2009}}(Registration required to view article.) In addition to rewarding pre-orders of the games with merchandise, Nintendo held a contest in which participants submitted videos of themselves singing the Pokémon theme song with their own re-written lyrics; the grand prize for that event was a [[Lugia]] [[PT Cruiser]].{{cite web|url=http://gameboy.ign.com/articles/389/389147p1.html|title=Pokemon Hit the Road|accessdate=July 18, 2008|date=March 12, 2003|publisher=[[News Corporation]]|work=[[IGN]]|first=Craig|last=Harris|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080117214241/http://gameboy.ign.com/articles/389/389147p1.html|archivedate=January 17, 2008|df=mdy-all}}{{cite web|url=http://gameboy.ign.com/articles/385/385760p1.html|title=Pokemon Pre-Sell Goodies|date=February 11, 2003|publisher=[[News Corporation]]|work=[[IGN]]|accessdate=July 18, 2008|first=Craig|last=Harris}} Later that year, Nintendo launched the EON Ticket Summer Tour, in which 125 [[Toys 'R' Us]] stores across the United States offered the Eon Ticket e-Card in stores from July 19 to September 1.{{cite web |url=http://gameboy.ign.com/articles/435/435984p1.html|title=Nintendo Celebrates Pokemoniversary|accessdate=July 18, 2008 |date=August 29, 2003|first=Craig|last=Harris|publisher=[[News Corporation]]|work=[[IGN]]}} Nintendo aired two [[television advertisement]]s, "Faces" and "Names", on prime-time network, cable, and syndication. "Faces" featured Pokémon juxtaposed with human look-alikes; "Names" featured people shouting out the names of Pokémon and emphasized the fact that the games introduced 100 new Pokémon. Additionally, Nintendo collaborated with United Kingdom beverage brand [[Vimto]] to promote the games.{{cite news|url=http://www.brandrepublic.com/news/183606/nintendo-teams-vimto-new-pokemon-games|title=Nintendo teams up with Vimto for new Pokemon games|date=June 24, 2003|work=Brand Republic|publisher=[[Haymarket Group]]|accessdate=December 2, 2008}} ==Audio== {{Infobox album | italic_title = no | name = ''Pokémon Ruby'' and ''Sapphire'' soundtrack | type = studio | artist = Junichi Masuda, Go Ichinose and Morikazu Aoki | cover = | alt = | released = April 26, 2003 | recorded = | venue = | studio = | genre = [[Video game music]], [[soundtrack]], [[Content (media)|audio]] | length = | label = Mediafactory | producer = Unknown | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = | next_year = }} The audio of ''Ruby'' and ''Sapphire'' consists entirely of game music; all dialogue is on-screen. The music, composed by Junichi Masuda, Go Ichinose and Morikazu Aoki, is completely instrumental except for two tracks with vocals, "Trick Master" and "Slateport City". The soundtrack of the game was released under the Mediafactory label in Japan on April 26, 2003; the album reached #297 on the [[Oricon]] charts and charted for one week.{{cite web|url=http://www.oricon.co.jp/music/release/d/506402/1/|title=Pokemon Ruby & Sapphire Super Complete Music|publisher=[[Oricon]] |accessdate=November 26, 2008|language=ja}} Junichi Masuda wrote only battle tunes, Go Ichinose wrote most of the town, route, fanfare & 'Spotted' tunes, whereas Morikazu Aoki did the remainder. The soundtrack is noted for its heavy use of [[trumpet]]s.{{cite web |title=The Internet Reacts To The New Pokémon Remakes |url=http://www.kotaku.com.au/2014/05/the-internet-reacts-to-the-new-pokmon-remakes/ |date=May 8, 2014 |publisher=Kotaku}} {| class="collapsible collapsed" border="0" style="width:70%" ! style="width:12em; text-align:left" | DISC 1 ! | |- | colspan="2" | {| class="wikitable" |- !colspan="5"|Disc 1 |- ! No. ! Track Title (Japanese) ! Track Title (English Translation) ! Composer ! Arranger |- | 53 | TRICK MASTER | TRICK MASTER | Go Ichinose | Go Ichinose |- | 54 | SLATEPORT CITY | SLATEPORT CITY | Go Ichinose | Go Ichinose |- | 55 | STEVEN STONE | STEVEN STONE | Junichi Masuda | Junichi Masuda |} |} ==Reception== ===Critical response=== {{Video game reviews | GR = 84% (55 reviews){{cite web|url=http://www.gamerankings.com/htmlpages4/471243.asp|title=Pokemon Ruby Version Reviews |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]|work=[[GameRankings]]|accessdate=August 2, 2008}}{{cite web |url=http://www.gamerankings.com/htmlpages4/563596.asp|title=Pokemon Sapphire Version Reviews|publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]|work=[[GameRankings]]|accessdate=August 2, 2008}} | MC = 82% (33 reviews){{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/games/platforms/gba/pokemonsapphire|title=Pokemon Sapphire Reviews|publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]|work=[[Metacritic]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080504025052/http://www.metacritic.com/games/platforms/gba/pokemonsapphire|archivedate=May 4, 2008 |accessdate=July 17, 2008}}{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/games/platforms/gba/pokemonruby|title=Pokemon Ruby Reviews|publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]|work=[[Metacritic]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080504025047/http://www.metacritic.com/games/platforms/gba/pokemonruby |archivedate=May 4, 2008 |accessdate=July 17, 2008}} | 1UP = B- | CVG = 9/10 | EuroG = 7/10 | Fam = 34/40''ゲームボーイアドバンス - ポケットモンスター ルビー・サファイア''. Weekly Famitsu. No.915 Pt.2. Pg.120. June 30, 2006. | GSpot = 8.1/10 (Ruby) | GameZone = 9.5/10 (Ruby) | IGN = 9.5/10 (Ruby){{cite web|url=http://gameboy.ign.com/objects/017/017508.html|title=IGN: Pokemon Ruby Version|publisher=[[News Corporation]]| work=[[IGN]]|accessdate=October 13, 2008}} }} The games met with mostly positive reviews. [[IGN]] gave them an "Amazing" 9.5 out of 10 rating and awarded them the Editor's Choice Award; in 2007, the games were collectively named the tenth best Game Boy Advance game of all time in an IGN article.{{cite web|first=Craig|last=Harris|date=March 16, 2007|url=http://gameboy.ign.com/articles/772/772284p4.html|title=Top 25 Game Boy Advance Games of All Time|publisher=[[News Corporation]]|work=[[IGN]]|accessdate=March 18, 2007}} GameZone also gave the games a 9.5 out of 10 rating and gave the games an Outstanding Award. [[GamePro]] gave the games 5 out of 5 stars and named them Editor's Choices. [[ComputerAndVideoGames.com]] gave the games a 9 of 10, and [[GameSpot]] gave the games 8.1 out of 10. [[Eurogamer]] and [[1UP.com]] were less enthusiastic about the games, however; Eurogamer gave the games 7 out of 10, and 1UP gave the games a B-. Reviewers were divided in their critiques of the games, especially concerning the gameplay and graphics. IGN praised the "deep design" and noted that the addition of features such as double battles greatly increased the strategic aspect of the games. GamePro also thought that the addition of double battles "add[ed] challenge" and "made the harder battles far more strategic than before—the way the game should be".{{cite web|url=http://www.gamepro.com/nintendo/gameboy_advance/games/reviews/28564.shtml|title=Review: Pokemon: Ruby and Sapphire Versions|publisher=IDG Entertainment|work=[[GamePro]]|date=March 17, 2003|accessdate=July 17, 2008|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http://www.gamepro.com/nintendo/gameboy_advance/games/reviews/28564.shtml&date=2008-07-17+18:20:28|archivedate=July 17, 2008}} Likewise, ComputerAndVideoGames.com called the gameplay "incredibly compelling and addictive".{{cite web|url=http://www.computerandvideogames.com/article.php?id=90745|title=Review: Pokémon Ruby & Sapphire|first=Maura|last=Sutton|publisher=[[Future Publishing]]|work=[[ComputerAndVideoGames.com]]|accessdate=November 13, 2008|date=May 8, 2003}} GameZone noted that the gameplay was more refined and challenging than that of previous titles.{{cite web|url=http://gameboy.gamezone.com/gzreviews/r20800_GBA.htm|title=Pokemon Ruby Review|publisher=Gamezone Online|work=GameZone|first=Louis|last=Bedigian |accessdate=November 13, 2008|date=March 24, 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081104011045/http://gameboy.gamezone.com/gzreviews/r20800_GBA.htm |archivedate=November 4, 2008}} However, GameSpot called the games "a cakewalk from start to finish" and claimed that ''Ruby'' and ''Sapphire'' "don't offer much of a challenge".{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/gba/rpg/pokemonrubyversion/review.html?om_act=convert&om_clk=gssummary&tag=summary%3Breview&page=2|title=Pokemon Ruby Version |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]|work=[[GameSpot]]|date=March 18, 2003|first=Greg|last=Kasavin|accessdate=July 17, 2008}} Eurogamer also felt that the mechanics "[get] very tired, very fast".{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/article.php?article_id=53163|title=Pokemon Ruby & Sapphire Review|first=Martin|last=Taylor|work=[[Eurogamer]] |accessdate=November 13, 2008|date=September 8, 2003}} 1UP.com also felt that the games were formulaic and that double battles were underused.{{cite web|url=http://www.1up.com/do/reviewPage?cId=3103339&p=19&sec=REVIEWS|title=Pokemon Ruby and Sapphire Review|date=January 1, 2000|work=[[1UP.com]]|publisher=[[Ziff Davis Media]]|accessdate=November 26, 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/610tVc0Jx?url=http://www.1up.com/reviews/pokeacutemon-ruby-sapphire_2|archivedate=August 17, 2011|df=mdy-all}} ComputerAndVideoGames.com was enthusiastic over the graphics, calling them "gorgeous". Other reviewers were less enthusiastic, however. GamePro felt that the graphics were only "a fair bit prettier" than those of the Game Boy color games; GameZone said that the games "still [use] the simple animations and basic character designs that were created for the original, color-less Game Boy". IGN and 1UP.com noted that the graphics had received only a minor upgrade, and Eurogamer felt that the graphics had been upgraded to a "functional level at best". The audio was generally well-received: GameZone and GameSpot both felt the audio was catchy; GameZone gave the audio an 8 out of 10 score, saying that while the music "was annoying at times, [...] it's also very good. [...] I found myself humming the music when I wasn't playing". Other complaints included the removal of the time system of ''Gold'' and ''Silver'' and the inability to import Pokémon from the games of previous generations.{{cite web|url=http://gameboy.ign.com/articles/389/389660p3.html|title=IGN: Pokemon Ruby Version Review|last=Harris|first=Craig |date=March 17, 2003|work=[[IGN]]|publisher=[[News Corporation]]|page=3|accessdate=November 26, 2008}} ===Sales=== ''Pokémon Ruby'' and ''Sapphire'' were highly anticipated.{{cite news |url=http://www.gamepro.com/article/news/27187/japan-catches-a-light-case-of-pokemania|title=Japan Catches A Light Case of Pokemania|date=December 21, 2002|work=[[Gamepro]]|publisher=IDG Entertainment|accessdate=December 2, 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090414113254/http://www.gamepro.com/article/news/27187/japan-catches-a-light-case-of-pokemania|archivedate=April 14, 2009}}{{cite news |url=http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-22709780_ITM|title=America Braces for Next Huge Pokemon Wave; Pokemon Ruby, Pokemon Sapphire for Game Boy Advance Give New Game-Play and Learning Experience|work=[[AccessMyLibrary]] |accessdate=November 30, 2008|publisher=[[Business Wire]] | date=March 17, 2003}} (Registration required to view article) In Japan, they sold 1.25 million units within the first four days of release and were the best-selling games of the 2002 holiday season;{{cite magazine |url=https://www.wired.com/techbiz/media/news/2002/12/56928?currentPage=2|title=EU Wraps Up Microsoft Inquiry|date=December 19, 2002|magazine=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]|publisher=[[Condé Nast Publications]]|accessdate=November 30, 2008|agency=[[Associated Press]] and [[Reuters]]}} sales totaled around 4.4 million within six weeks of release. They also became the first games to sell 2 million copies in Japan since 2001's ''[[Final Fantasy X]]'' and the first games for a hand-held console to do so since 2000's ''Yu-Gi-Oh! Duel Monsters 4''.{{cite news|url=http://www.gamepro.com/article/news/27520/top-30-japanese-video-games-12-08-02|title=Top 30 Japanese Video Games 12/08/02|date=December 18, 2002|work=[[Gamepro]]|publisher=IDG Entertainment|accessdate=November 30, 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090414113259/http://www.gamepro.com/article/news/27520/top-30-japanese-video-games-12-08-02|archivedate=April 14, 2009}}{{efn|If the two games are counted as one}} In North America, Nintendo sold 2.2 million units by April 2003 (within one month of the games' North American release) in the region alone.{{cite web|url=http://gameboy.ign.com/articles/392/392355p1.html |title=Nintendo Makes Money|date=April 4, 2003|publisher=[[News Corporation]]|work=[[IGN]]|accessdate=July 17, 2008}} ''Ruby'' and ''Sapphire'' were the second and third best-selling games, respectively, of 2003.{{cite news |url=http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-7679844_ITM|title=2003's top video games.|date=March 9, 2004|work=[[AccessMyLibrary]]|publisher=[[The Charlotte Observer]]|accessdate=November 30, 2008|agency=[[Knight Ridder|Knight-Ridder/Tribune]]}} The games enjoyed success in Europe as well. They were the second best-selling games of the holiday season in 2002;{{cite news|url=http://www.gamepro.com/article/news/31990/game-boy-advance-shipments-hit-10-million-in-europe|title=Game Boy Advance shipments hit 10 million in Europe|date=December 9, 2003|work=[[Gamepro]]|publisher=IDG Entertainment |accessdate=November 30, 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090414111015/http://www.gamepro.com/article/news/31990/game-boy-advance-shipments-hit-10-million-in-europe|archivedate=April 14, 2009}} even before release, European retailers imported cartridges from the United States to meet the high demand for the games.{{cite news|url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2003/04/28/importers_warned_over_gba_pokemon/ |title=Importers warned over GBA Pokemon titles|date=April 28, 2003|work=[[The Register]]|publisher=Situation Publishing Ltd |accessdate=November 30, 2008}} With around 16 million units sold worldwide, the games are the best-selling titles ever for the Game Boy Advance.{{cite web|url=http://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/202366/Pokemon_X__Y_sell_4M_copies_in_first_weekend.php|title=Pokemon X & Y sell 4M copies in first weekend|last=Rose|first=Mike|date=October 15, 2013|work=[[Gamasutra]]|publisher=Think Services|accessdate=October 16, 2013}} However, analysts noted that with "young kids...gravitating toward [[Yu-Gi-Oh!]]" at the time, Pokémon's popularity was waning.{{cite news |url=http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-22555674_ITM|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090112035729/http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-22555674_ITM|title=Pokemon pundits see luster fading: new games seen a solid, no record breakers|date=February 24, 2003|work=[[AccessMyLibrary]]|publisher=Video Business|accessdate=November 30, 2008|archivedate=January 12, 2009 |deadurl=yes}} This was reflected in the games' sales compared to those of previous generations: [[Pokémon Red and Blue|''Red'' and ''Blue'']] sold nearly 27 million units worldwide,{{cite web|url=http://hdl.handle.net/10022/AC:P:28|format=PDF|title=Pokemania: Secrets Behind the International Phenomenon|publisher=Columbia Business School|author=Safier, Joshua|author2=Nakaya, Sumie |date=February 7, 2000|accessdate=August 5, 2011}} and [[Pokémon Gold and Silver|''Gold'' and ''Silver'']] sold over 23 million units.{{cite web|url=http://www.the-magicbox.com/Chart-JPPlatinum.shtml |title=Japan Platinum Chart Games|publisher=The Magic Box|accessdate=July 5, 2008}}{{cite web|url=http://www.the-magicbox.com/Chart-USPlatinum.shtml|title=US Platinum Chart Games|publisher=The Magic Box|accessdate=July 5, 2008}} ==Related games== ===''Pokémon Emerald''=== {{main article|Pokémon Emerald}} {{nihongo4|'''''Pokémon Emerald Version'''''|ポケットモンスター エメラルド|Poketto Monsutā Emerarudo|lit "Pocket Monsters: Emerald"}} is an enhanced version of ''Pokémon Ruby'' and ''Sapphire'', developed by [[Game Freak]], published by [[The Pokémon Company]] and [[Nintendo]] for the [[Game Boy Advance]]. It was released in Japan on September 16, 2004, North America on May 1, 2005, Australia on June 9, 2005, and Europe on October 21, 2005.{{cite web|url=http://www.gamefaqs.com/portable/gbadvance/data/921905.html|title=Pokemon Emerald Info |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]|work=[[GameFAQs]]|accessdate=August 2, 2008}} Although the gameplay is as that of ''Ruby'' and ''Sapphire'', ''Emerald'' introduces new features. The plot is modified; both Team Magma and Aqua are villains who are locked in a constant gang war and awaken Groudon and Kyogre, respectively. When the two [[Gameplay of Pokémon#Legendary Pokémon|legendary Pokémon]] begin to battle each other, the protagonist must unleash the legendary Pokémon [[Rayquaza]] (pictured on the box cover) to calm them. Some of the game mechanics are changed as well. Though double battles were clearly marked in ''Ruby'' and ''Sapphire'', in ''Emerald'', two separate trainers might unite to battle as a pair (fixed in games thereafter). After the [[List of Elite Four members|Elite Four]] is defeated, the player may re-battle Gym Leaders in a double battle if they are called on their PokéNav. Also, Pokémon [[sprite (computer graphics)|sprites]] are animated in battle like they were in ''Pokémon Crystal''. Probably the most significant addition is the [[Battle Frontier]], an expanded version of the [[Battle Tower]] in ''Ruby'' and ''Sapphire''. Another change made in ''Emerald'' is the addition of Team Magma's base on the side of Mt. Chimney; moreover, the legendary Pokémon Groudon is found here, rather than in the Seafloor Cavern. Even though the locations of the legendary Pokémon are different, Team Magma still makes the mistake of taking the blue orb to Groudon, while Team Aqua still makes the mistake of taking the red orb to Kyogre. A new character named Scott is also introduced in this game. Unknown to the player, he is the creator of the Battle Frontier. He follows the player throughout the game, watching them battle each Gym Leader and even meeting up with them when they get to the Battle Frontier. ''Emerald'' has been generally well received.{{cite web|title=IGN: Reader Reviews For: Pokémon Emerald Version|publisher=[[News Corporation]]|work=[[IGN]]|accessdate=September 9, 2007|url=http://rr.gameboy.ign.com/rrobj/pocket/object/692344/|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713004608/http://rr.gameboy.ign.com/rrobj/pocket/object/692344/|archivedate=July 13, 2011|df=mdy-all}}{{cite web|title=Pokémon Emerald Reader Reviews at Game Rankings|publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]|work=[[GameRankings]] |accessdate=September 9, 2007|url=http://www.gamerankings.com/comments/921905}} The game has an aggregate rating of 77% on [[GameRankings]].{{cite web|title=Pokémon Emerald Reviews at Game Rankings|publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]|work=[[GameRankings]]|accessdate=September 9, 2007|url=http://www.gamerankings.com/htmlpages2/921905.asp}} [[GameSpot]] gave it a 7.5 out of 10;{{cite web|title=Gamespot Summary of Pokémon Emerald|publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]|work=[[GameSpot]] |accessdate=September 9, 2007|url=http://www.gamespot.com/search.html?type=11&stype=all&tag=search%3Bbutton&om_act=convert&om_clk=search&qs=pokemon+emerald}} [[IGN]] gave it an "Impressive" rating of 8.0 out of a possible 10.{{cite web|title=IGN: Pokémon Emerald Version|publisher=[[News Corporation]]|work=[[IGN]] |accessdate=September 9, 2007|url=http://gameboy.ign.com/objects/692/692344.html}} [[Eurogamer]], however, gave ''Emerald'' a score of 6 out of 10. Though it praised ''Emerald'' for looking better than either ''Ruby'' or ''Sapphire'' and for having harder and longer gameplay, it criticized the game for not even being a "half changed update [...] but more of a director's cut".{{cite web|title=Review - Pokémon Emerald // GBA /// Eurogamer|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/article.php?article_id=60250|work=[[Eurogamer]]|accessdate=September 9, 2007}} ''Emerald'' was the second best-selling game in the United States of {{vgy|2005}}; it sold 6.32 million copies, making it the third-best selling game for the Game Boy Advance.{{cite web|title=AOL Games: Pokémon Emerald|publisher=[[AOL]]|work=AOL Games|date=August 3, 2005|url=http://videogames.aol.com/game_news?gameID=19532&articleID=316614|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060418213050/http://videogames.aol.com/game_news?gameID=19532&articleID=316614|archivedate=April 18, 2006 |accessdate=March 24, 2006}} In 2011, it was reported that the game was still selling in Japan in 2010 with approximately 7,724 units sold that year.{{Cite web|url=http://kotaku.com/#!5795281/yes-people-still-buy-this-game-boy-advance-game|title=Yes, People Still Buy This Game Boy Advance Game|publisher=[[Kotaku]]|date=April 25, 2011}} ===''Pokémon Box: Ruby and Sapphire''=== '''''Pokémon Box: Ruby and Sapphire''''', or simply '''''Pokémon Box''''', is a [[Spin-off (media)|spin-off]] ''Pokémon'' game for the [[GameCube]] console, bundled with a [[Nintendo GameCube – Game Boy Advance link cable]] and a [[Memory Card]] 59.{{cite web|url=http://cube.ign.com/articles/532/532019p1.html|title=IGN: Pokemon Box: Ruby and Sapphire Preview|publisher=[[News Corporation]]|work=[[IGN]]|first=Craig|last=Harris|date=July 20, 2004|accessdate=September 28, 2008}} It was released in Japan on May 30, 2003 and in North America on July 11, 2004,{{cite web|url=http://www.gamefaqs.com/console/gamecube/data/914971.html|title=Pokemon Box: Ruby and Sapphire Release Information for GameCube|publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]|work=[[GameFAQs]]|accessdate=September 28, 2008}} but only through the [[New York City|New York]] [[Pokémon Center]] and its online store. It is no longer available in either location. The game was released in some parts of Europe as '''''Pokémon Memory Magic''''' due to translation problems,{{cite web|url=http://n-europe.com/news.php?nid=4558|title=N-Europe: News: Pokémon Name Change|publisher=N-Europe|author=Tim|date=September 28, 2008|accessdate=February 15, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/610tdBJMg?url=http://n-europe.com/news.php?nid=4558|archivedate=August 17, 2011|df=mdy-all}} and Europeans only could get the game by using points from Nintendo of Europe's loyalty program, or by buying the ''Pokémon Colosseum Mega Pack''.{{cite web|url=http://n-europe.com/news.php?nid=6515|title=N-Europe: News: Pokémon Box Gets Starring Role|publisher=N-Europe|first=Ashley|last=Boyd|date=May 15, 2004|accessdate=September 28, 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/610teBcGI?url=http://n-europe.com/news.php?nid=6515|archivedate=August 17, 2011|df=mdy-all}} The game is essentially a storage system for the [[Game Boy Advance]] ''Pokémon'' games that allows players to trade and store Pokémon that they have caught in ''Ruby'', ''Sapphire'', ''[[#Pokémon Emerald|Emerald]], ''[[Pokémon FireRed and LeafGreen|''FireRed'', and ''LeafGreen'']] onto a GameCube memory card. Players can then organize and interact with their Pokémon on the GameCube, such as allowing them to breed. Unique Pokémon can also be acquired. Another feature allows the games to be played on the television via the GameCube Game Boy Advance Cable. Options such as taking [[screenshot]]s of the game are available in this mode.{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/gamecube/puzzle/pokemonbox/news.html?sid=6029812&mode=previews|title=Pokémon Box Ruby and Sapphire Impressions|publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]|work=[[GameSpot]]|date=July 10, 2003 |accessdate=September 28, 2008}} Another addition is the "Showcase", where players can create and display game pieces of Pokémon. Nintendo referred to the game as "the most exclusive Pokémon software ever offered to North American Pokémon fans," but it was generally considered to be unnecessary, receiving a score of 50% on [[GameRankings]] from 1 review.{{cite web|url=http://www.gamerankings.com/htmlpages2/914971.asp|title=Pokemon Box: Ruby and Sapphire Reviews |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]|work=[[GameRankings]]|accessdate=September 28, 2008}} Craig Harris of [[IGN]] gave the game a "[[Wiktionary:Meh|Meh]]" rating of 5.0 out of 10, praising the interface, which makes the organization of Pokémon much easier as compared to the Game Boy Advance interface, as well as the emulator which allows ''Ruby'' and ''Sapphire'' to be played on the GameCube. He also stated that the game was a good deal due to the inclusion of a Memory Card and Cable. However, Harris cited the "Showcase" as "entirely unnecessary and completely out of place," and said that overall the game lacked much to do. He wrote, "It's targeted specifically for the truly die-hard Pokemon fan, but it requires so many specific elements to actually be useful to anyone."{{cite web|url=http://cube.ign.com/articles/533/533098p1.html|title=IGN: Pokemon Box: Ruby and Sapphire Review|publisher=[[News Corporation]]|work=[[IGN]]|first=Craig|last=Harris|date=July 23, 2004 |accessdate=September 28, 2008}} [[Allgame]] gave the game three and a half out of five stars.{{cite web|url=http://www.allgame.com/cg/agg.dll?p=agg&sql=1:43616|title=Pokémon Box > Overview|publisher=[[Macrovision Corporation]]|work=[[Allgame]]|first=Scott Alan|last=Marriott|accessdate=September 28, 2008}} ===''Pokémon Omega Ruby'' and ''Alpha Sapphire''=== {{main article|Pokémon Omega Ruby and Alpha Sapphire}} On May 7, 2014, Nintendo announced that a remake of ''Ruby'' and ''Sapphire'', titled ''Omega Ruby'' and ''Alpha Sapphire'', and it was released for the [[Nintendo 3DS]] on November 21, 2014 worldwide, with the exclusion of Europe, where it was released on November 28, 2014.{{cite web|url=http://www.pokemon.com/us/pokemon-video-games/pokemon-omega-ruby-and-pokemon-alpha-sapphire/|title=Pokémon Omega Ruby and Pokémon Alpha Sapphire|date=May 7, 2014|accessdate=May 7, 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.pokemon.com/us/pokemon-video-games/pokemon-omega-ruby-and-pokemon-alpha-sapphire/|title=Pokémon Omega Ruby and Pokémon Alpha Sapphire|publisher=[[Nintendo]]|accessdate=May 7, 2014}}{{cite web | url=http://www.shacknews.com/article/84410/pokemon-omega-ruby-and-alpha-sapphire-announced | title=Pokemon: Omega Ruby and Alpha Sapphire announced | publisher=Shacknews LTD | date=May 7, 2014 | accessdate=May 7, 2014 | author=Watts, Steve}} ==Notes== {{notelist}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{refbegin}} * {{cite video game|title=Pokémon Ruby|developer=[[Game Freak]]|publisher=[[Nintendo]]|date=March 19, 2003}} * {{cite video game|title=Pokémon Sapphire|developer=[[Game Freak]]|publisher=[[Nintendo]]|date=March 19, 2003}} * {{cite book|title=Pokémon Sapphire Version instruction booklet|publisher=Nintendo|year=2003}} * {{cite book|publisher=[[Prima Games]]|year=2003|title=Pokémon Ruby Version [and] Sapphire Version: Prima's Official Strategy Guide|location=USA|first=Elizabeth M.|last=Hollinger|ISBN=0-7615-4256-6}} {{refend}} ==External links== * {{official website|https://www.pokemon.com/us/pokemon-video-games/pokemon-ruby-version-and-pokemon-sapphire-version/}} *[http://bulbapedia.bulbagarden.net/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_Ruby_and_Sapphire_Versions Games] and [http://bulbapedia.bulbagarden.net/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_Ruby_%26_Pok%C3%A9mon_Sapphire:_Super_Music_Collection soundtrack] on [[Bulbapedia]] {{Pokémon}} {{Portal bar|Pokémon|Nintendo|Video games}} {{Good article}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Pokemon Ruby And Sapphire}} [[Category:2002 video games]] [[Category:Game Boy Advance games]] [[Category:Game Boy Advance-only games]] [[Category:Game Freak games]] revision.comment: Alice Zhang Mengping moved page [[Potenciano Alino]] to [[Potenciano Aliño]]: correct name
[[User:JCW-CleanerBot#Logic|task]], replaced: Progress in neuro-psychopharmacology & biological psychiatry → Progress in Neuro-Psychopharmacology & Biological Psychiatry
revision.text:
{{Infobox medical intervention | name = Pulsed electromagnetic field therapy | image = Rhumart MBI 3000 RESC Controller.JPG | caption = Drolet's 1990 [[Rhumart]] system, a PEMF device. | alt = | pronounce = | synonyms = pulsed magnetic therapy, pulse magnetotherapy (PEMF) | ICD10 = | ICD9 = | ICD9unlinked = | CPT = | MeshID = | LOINC = | other_codes = | MedlinePlus = | eMedicine = }} '''Pulsed electromagnetic field therapy''' ('''PEMFT'''), also known as '''low field magnetic stimulation''' ('''LFMS'''), and '''tumor treating fields''' ('''TTF''') uses [[electromagnetic field]]s in an attempt to heal non-union fractures, glioblastomas (brain tumors) <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.accessdata.fda.gov/scripts/cdrh/cfdocs/cfpma/pma.cfm?id=P100034|title=Premarket Approval (PMA)|website=www.accessdata.fda.gov|accessdate=21 May 2018}}</ref> and depression.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Martiny|first1=K|last2=Lunde|first2=M|last3=Bech|first3=P|title=Transcranial low voltage pulsed electromagnetic fields in patients with treatment-resistant depression.|journal=Biological Psychiatry|date=15 July 2010|volume=68|issue=2|pages=163–9|pmid=20385376|doi=10.1016/j.biopsych.2010.02.017}}</ref> By 2007 the FDA had cleared several such stimulation devices.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Markov, Marko S|title=Expanding Use of Pulsed Electromagnetic Field Therapies|journal=Electromagnetic Biology & Medicine |volume=26|issue=3 |year=2007|pages=257–274|pmid=17886012|doi=10.1080/15368370701580806}}</ref>
In 2013 the U.S. [[Food and Drug Administration]] (FDA) warned a manufacturer for promoting the device for unapproved uses such as [[cerebral palsy]] and [[spinal cord injury]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Warning Letters - Curatronic Ltd. 1/9/13|url=https://www.fda.gov/ICECI/EnforcementActions/WarningLetters/ucm335343.htm|website=www.fda.gov|accessdate=7 January 2018|language=en}}</ref>
== Use ==
=== Delayed- and non-union fractures ===
[[File:Nonunion2010.JPG|thumb|An old fracture with [[Pseudarthrosis|nonunion]] of the fracture fragments.]] The mechanism of [[osteogenesis]] is not clear.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Pulsed electromagnetic field (PEMF) treatment for fracture healing |journal=Current Orthopaedic Practice |volume=20 |issue=4 |pages=423–428 |date=August 2009 |doi=10.1097/BCO.0b013e318198e8b2 |last1=Boopalan |first1=PRJVC |last2=Chittaranjan |first2=Samuel B |last3=Balamurugan |first3=Ramadass |last4=Nandakumar |first4=NS |last5=Sabareeswaran |first5=A |last6=Mohanty |first6=Mira |displayauthors=1}}</ref> While PEMF therapy is claimed to offer some benefit in the treatment of fractures, the evidence is inconclusive and is insufficient to inform current clinical practice.<ref name=Grif2011>{{cite journal|last1=Griffin|first1=XL|last2=Costa|first2=ML|last3=Parsons|first3=N|last4=Smith|first4=N|title=Electromagnetic field stimulation for treating delayed union or non-union of long bone fractures in adults.|journal=The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews|date=13 April 2011|issue=4|pages=CD008471|pmid=21491410|doi=10.1002/14651858.CD008471.pub2}}</ref>
== History ==
Electromagnetic field therapy has been in use since the invention of electricity. It was widely adopted in East and Western Europe but its use was restricted to animals in North America until recently.{{When|date=March 2018}}<ref>{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=258YfTJpgl4C&pg=RA2-PA342&dq=electromagnetic+therapy+animals+in+North+America#v=onepage&q=electromagnetic%20therapy%20animals%20in%20North%20America&f=false | title=AUDIOLOGY, 3-Volume Set: Diagnosis, Treatment and Practice Management | publisher=Thieme |author1=Ross Roeser |author2=Michael Valente | year=2007 | location=342 | pages=2000 | isbn=1604066970}}</ref> Veterinarians became the first health professionals to use PEMF therapy, usually to heal broken legs in racehorses.<ref name=bcbs>{{cite web |url=http://bcbsms.com/index.php/index.php?id=200&action=viewPolicy&path=%2Fpolicy%2Femed%2FElectrical+Stimulation+of+the+Spine+as+an+Adjunct+to+Spinal+Fusion+Procedures.html&source=emed |publisher=Blue Cross & Blue Shield of Mississippi |title=Electrical stimulation of the spine as an adjunct to spinal fusion procedures |quote=Pulsed electromagnetic field systems with FDA PMA include the EBI Bone Healing System from Electrobiology, Inc., which was first approved in 1979 and indicated for nonunions, failed fusions, and congenital pseudarthroses; and the Cervical-Stim from Orthofix, which was approved in 2004 as an adjunct to cervical fusion surgery in patients at high risk for non-fusion. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402122818/http://www.bcbsms.com/index.php/index.php?id=200&action=viewPolicy&path=%2Fpolicy%2Femed%2FElectrical+Stimulation+of+the+Spine+as+an+Adjunct+to+Spinal+Fusion+Procedures.html&source=emed |archivedate=2015-04-02 |df= }}</ref> In 2004, a pulsed electromagnetic field system was approved by the FDA as an adjunct to cervical fusion surgery in patients at high risk for non-fusion.<ref name=bcbs/> On 13 October 2015 the FDA reclassified PEMF devices from the Class 3 category to a Class 2 status. PEMF devices that have been FDA cleared to make health claims that require a doctor's prescription for use.<ref name=lowrisk />
Although electricity’s potential to aid bone healing was reported as early as 1841, it was not until the mid-1950s that scientists seriously studied the subject. During the 1970s, Bassett and his team introduced a new approach for the treatment of delayed fractures, a technique that employed a very specific biphasic low frequency signal<ref>{{cite journal|author=Bassett CA, Pawluk RJ, Pilla AA|title=Acceleration of fracture repair by electromagnetic fields. A surgically noninvasive method |journal=Ann N Y Acad Sci |year=1974|volume=238|pages=242–62|bibcode=1974NYASA.238..242B|doi=10.1111/j.1749-6632.1974.tb26794.x|pmid=4548330|last2=Pawluk |last3=Pilla }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author=Bassett CA, Pawluk RJ, Pilla AA|title=Augmentation of Bone Repair by Inductively Coupled Electromagnetic Fields|journal=Science|year=1974|volume=184|pages=575–7|bibcode=1974Sci...184..575B|doi=10.1126/science.184.4136.575|pmid=4821958|issue=4136|last2=Pawluk|last3=Pilla}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author=Bassett CA, Pilla AA, Pawluk RJ|title= A non-operative salvage of surgically-resistant pseudarthroses and non-unions by pulsing electromagnetic fields. A preliminary report |journal=Clin Orthop |year=1977|volume=124|pages=128–43|pmid=598067|issue=124|doi=10.1097/00003086-197705000-00017|last2= Pilla |last3= Pawluk }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author=Bassett CA, Mitchell SN, Norton L, Pilla A |title=Repair of non-unions by pulsing electromagnetic fields |journal=Acta Orthop Belg |year=1978|volume=44|pages=706–24|pmid=380258|issue=5|last2=Mitchell |last3=Norton |last4=Pilla }}{{medrs|date=December 2013}}</ref> to be applied for non-union/delayed fractures. The use of electrical stimulation in the [[Vertebral column|lumbosacral]] region was first attempted by Alan Dwyer of Australia. In 1974, he reported successful initiation of graft incorporation in 11 of 12 fusion patients.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Mackenzie, Donald, Francis D Veninga|title=Reversal of delayed union of anterior cervical fusion treated with pulsed electromagnetic field stimulation: case report |journal=Southern Medical Journal |volume=97|issue=5 |year=2004|pages=519–524|pmid=15180031|doi=10.1097/00007611-200405000-00021|last2=Veninga }}{{medrs|date=December 2013}}</ref><ref> {{cite journal |author=Bose, B |title=Outcomes after posterolateral lumbar fusion with instrumentation in patients treated with adjunctive pulsed electromagnetic field stimulation |journal=Advances in Therapy |volume=18|issue=1 |year=2001|pages=12–20|doi=10.1007/BF02850247|pmid=11512529}}{{medrs|date=December 2013}}</ref>
== Wellness devices ==
The original PEMF devices consisted of a [[Helmholtz coil]] which generated a magnetic field. The patient's body was placed inside the magnetic field to deliver treatment. Today, the majority of PEMF wellness devices resemble a typical yoga mat in dimensions but are slightly thicker to house several flat spiral coils to produce an even electromagnetic field. A [[Signal generator|frequency generator]] is then used to energize the coils to create a pulsed electromagnetic field. A wide variety of professional and consumer PEMF devices are sold and marketed as FDA registered wellness devices.<ref name=lowrisk>{{cite web |url=http://www.fda.gov/downloads/medicaldevices/deviceregulationandguidance/guidancedocuments/ucm429674.pdf |title=General Wellness: Policy for Low Risk Devices - Guidance for Industry and Food and Drug Administration Staff |publisher=[[U.S. Food and Drug Administration]] |accessdate=16 February 2016 |date=29 July 2016 }}</ref> The majority are manufactured in Germany, Austria and Switzerland and are imported into North America as electric massagers or full body electric yoga mats. They are either placed on a massage table for clinical use or directly on the floor in the home to practice simple yoga postures. The companies that sell and manufacture them as "general wellness products" are not permitted to make medical claims of effectiveness in treating disease.<ref name=lowrisk />
==Research== ===Knee osteoarthritis=== A 2013 review found that evidence was of very low quality, there might be a benefit for improved function, and there was no evidence for benefit for pain.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Negm|first1=A|last2=Lorbergs|first2=A|last3=Macintyre|first3=NJ|title=Efficacy of low frequency pulsed subsensory threshold electrical stimulation vs placebo on pain and physical function in people with knee osteoarthritis: systematic review with meta-analysis.|journal=Osteoarthritis and cartilage|date=September 2013|volume=21|issue=9|pages=1281–9|doi=10.1016/j.joca.2013.06.015|pmid=23973142}}</ref>
=== Depression === Use of pulsed electromagnetic field therapy has been studied for depression.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=van Belkum|first1=SM|last2=Bosker|first2=FJ|last3=Kortekaas|first3=R|last4=Beersma|first4=DG|last5=Schoevers|first5=RA|title=Treatment of depression with low-strength transcranial pulsed electromagnetic fields: A mechanistic point of view.|journal=Progress in Neuro-Psychopharmacology & Biological Psychiatry|date=3 November 2016|volume=71|pages=137–43|doi=10.1016/j.pnpbp.2016.07.006|pmid=27449361}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Electromagnetic therapy (alternative medicine)|Electromagnetic Therapy (alternative medicine)]] * [[Pulsed radiofrequency#Therapeutic uses]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== *{{Cite journal|title = Effectiveness of pulsed electromagnetic field therapy in the management of osteoarthritis of the knee: a meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials|url = https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmedhealth/PMH0027512/|journal = Journal of Rehabilitation Medicine|date = 2009-05-01|issn = 1651-2081|pmid = 19479151|pages = 406–411|volume = 41|issue = 6|doi = 10.2340/16501977-0374|first = Patrick|last = Vavken|first2 = Ferdi|last2 = Arrich|first3 = Othmar|last3 = Schuhfried|first4 = Ronald|last4 = Dorotka}} {{Medicine}} {{Bone and cartilage}}
[[Category:Analgesics]] [[Category:Neurotechnology]] [[Category:Electrotherapy]] [[Category:Bioelectromagnetic-based therapies]] [[Category:Pain management]]

{{Infobox saint |name= Bl. Robert Anderton |birth_date= circa 1560 |birth_place= Lancashire |death_date= 25 April 1586 |death_place= Isle of Wight |venerated_in= Roman Catholicism |beatified_date= 1929 |beatified_by= Pius XI |feast_day= 25 April}}
'''Robert Anderton''' (c. 1560 – 25 April 1586) was an English [[Roman Catholic]] priest and martyr. He has been declared [[beatification|'Blessèd']] by the [[Roman Catholic Church]]. His [[Calendar of Saints|feast day]] is 25 April.
==Anderton== Robert Anderton was born in [[Lancashire]] about 1560.<ref name=stanton>[https://archive.org/stream/menologyofenglan00stanrich#page/182/mode/2up Stanton SJ, Richard, ''A Menology of England and Wales'', Burns & Oates, Ltd., London, 1892]</ref> around 1560. He probably attended [[Brasenose College, Oxford|Brasenose College]] and graduated from [[Oxford University]] in 1578.<ref name=Wainewright>[https://archive.org/stream/livesofenglishma01burtuoft#page/202/mode/2up Wainewright, John Bannerman. "Venerable Robert Anderton", ''Lives of the English Martyrs'', (Edwin H. Burton and J. H. Pollen eds.), London. Longmans, Green and Co., 1914]</ref> While at [[Reims]], Anderton was regarded as an excellent preacher, and a gifted teacher. He was ordained 31 March 1585.
==William Marsden== William Marsden was also born in Lancashire, and probably attended [[St Mary Hall, Oxford]].<ref name=Wainewright/>
Anderton and Marsden were friends from early youth and attended Oxford together, although at different colleges. The two travelled to Douai, where they converted to Roman Catholicism. They entered the [[English College, Douai|English College at Reims]] in 1580. The two were ordained to the priesthood there,<ref name=ryan>[http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/01467c.htm Ryan, Patrick W.F. "Ven. Robert Anderton." The Catholic Encyclopedia. Vol. 1. New York: Robert Appleton Company, 1907. 13 March 2013]</ref> and made prefects over the junior school.
Upon finishing their studies, Anderton and Marsden set out for England on 4 February 1586. They were caught in a storm while crossing the English Channel and prayed to die on land rather than at sea. Their ship being driven ashore by the storm onto the [[Isle of Wight]], they were quickly seized by the local authorities. In court, they pleaded that they had not violated the law by landing in England, as their landing was involuntary, being forced ashore by the storm.<ref name=ryan/>
This led to their being summoned to London, where they were given the opportunity to take the [[Oath of Supremacy]], acknowledging [[Elizabeth I of England|Elizabeth]] as the [[Supreme Governor of the Church of England]]. Although they acknowledged Elizabeth as their lawful queen in all secular affairs, they would not swear the Oath. As failure to take the oath was considered [[treason]] under the [[Act of Supremacy 1559|Second Act of Supremacy]], Anderton and Marsden were found guilty of treason. The sentence was then confirmed, and a proclamation was published, explaining their guilt. They were taken back to the Isle of Wight near the spot where they had landed and executed by [[hanging, drawing, and quartering]] on 25 April 1586.<ref name=ryan/>
He was beatified by [[Pope Pius XI]] in 1929.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [https://archive.org/stream/actsofenglishmar00polluoft#page/66/mode/2up Pollen SJ, John Hungerford, ''Acts of the English Martyrs'', Chap. IV, Burns & Oates, Ltd., London, 1891]
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Anderton, Robert}} [[Category:Year of birth unknown]] [[Category:Date of birth unknown]] [[Category:1586 deaths]] [[Category:English beatified people]] [[Category:Converts to Roman Catholicism]] [[Category:Alumni of Brasenose College, Oxford]] [[Category:16th-century English Roman Catholic priests]] [[Category:English College, Reims alumni]] [[Category:People executed under the Tudors for treason against England]] [[Category:16th-century Roman Catholic martyrs]] [[Category:16th-century venerated Christians]] [[Category:Executed people from Lancashire]] [[Category:People executed under Elizabeth I of England by hanging, drawing and quartering]] [[Category:Year of birth uncertain]] [[Category:Catholic martyrs of England and Wales]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2015}} {{Infobox clergy | name = Roger E. Hedlund | image = | imagesize = | caption = | pseudonym = | birthname = | birth_date = 1935Hedlund, Roger, "Roger Hedlund ARC2012 -002 - Finding Aid" (2012). Finding Aids. Book 18.[http://place.asburyseminary.edu/findingaids/18] | birth_place = [[Minnesota]] | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = [[Pastor]] | nationality = English-[[United States|American]] | ordained = | writings = | congregations = | offices_held = | title = The Reverend Doctor | parents = | footnotes = }} '''Roger E. Hedlund''' is a Pastor who has spent more than three decades in [[India]] as a theological teacher and researcher with major contribution to [[Missiology]] with special reference to Indian ethos. Hedlund taught at the [[Union Biblical Seminary]], both at [[Yeotmal]] and at [[Pune]]Roger E. Hedlund, ''Response to Persecution and Suffering in the History of Christian Mission'' in Mark T. B. Laing (Edited), ''Persecution and Suffering: Christian Reflections and Responses'', published for the Centre for Mission Studies, [[Union Biblical Seminary]], Pune by the ISPCK, New Delhi, 2007. during 1974-1978 and also at the [[Serampore College]], a constituent College of the nation's first University, the [[Senate of Serampore College (University)]] from 1994-1997. At present he is associated with the ''Dharma Deepika: A South Asian Journal of Missiological Research'' and with the Mylapore Institute for Indigenous Studies, [[Chennai]]. Hedlund edited the ''Oxford Encyclopedia of South Asian Christianity''. ==Studies== Hedlund studied at the [[Upland College]] in 1957 and thereafter undertook theological studies at the [[Denver Conservative Baptist Seminary]] where he was awarded the graduate degree of [[Bachelor of Divinity]] (B.D.) in 1961. After serving as a missionary in [[Italy]], Hedlund pursued postgraduate and doctoral studies at the [[Fuller Theological Seminary]], [[Pasadena, California|Pasadena]] between 1970-1974. In 2004, Hedlund pursued another doctorate at the State-run [[University of Madras]] ==Contribution and writings== Roger E. Hedlund has been prominent in the theological circles in India and known in the Catholic, Orthodox, Protestant and Charismatic circles serving the cause of missiological research. The papers and correspondence of Roger E. Hedlund have been preserved and made digitally available[http://place.asburyseminary.edu/rogerhedlund/ Asbury Theological Seminary, Kentucky, Papers of Roger E. Hedlund] by the [[Asbury Theological Seminary]], [[Kentucky]]. ===Articles=== * In 1985, ''Caste and the Bible'',Roger E. Hedlund, ''Caste and the Bible'', ICGQ, Volume 7, Number 2 (April–June, 1985). [https://books.google.co.in/books?id=p3W9uAAACAAJ&dq=inauthor:%22Roger+E.+Hedlund%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CDwQ6AEwB2oVChMI9Yz7_8GhxwIVTRiOCh0PIwHd] * In 1993, ''William Carey's Universal Significance'',Roger E. Hedlund, ''William Carey's Universal Significance'' in Roger E. Hedlund, J. T. K. Daniel (Edited), ''Carey's Obligation and India's Renaissance'', Serampore, 1993, pp.96-113. Cited in Klaus Koschorke (Edited), ''in Transcontinental Links in the History of Non-Western Christianity'', Otto Harrassowitz, Wiesbaden, 2002. [https://books.google.co.in/books?id=WP2hxYZ0rkwC&pg=PA273&lpg=PA273&dq=India+church+growth+roger+e.+hedlund&source=bl&ots=mk35BbrENa&sig=65F1VSVhq4iy4_Ys3Kz1JMJY82s&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CEkQ6AEwCGoVChMI4rvK48ehxwIVio-OCh2GqQry#v=onepage&q=hedlund&f=false] * In 1998, ''Christian History from the Under Side: Indian Instituted Churches and Indigenous Christianity'',Roger E. Hedlund, ''Christian History from the Under Side: Indian Instituted Churches and Indigenous Christianity'', Keynote address, Conference on Subaltern Perspectives on Seminary Training, Centre for Dalit Solidarity, Dharmaram College, Bangalore, 23 October 1998, Cited in P. Solomon Raj, ''The New Wine-Skins: The Story of Indigenous Mission in Andhra Pradesh'', India, ISPCK/MIIS, New Delhi/Madras, 2003, p.157. [https://books.google.co.in/books?id=Bxdu1WT-_X8C&pg=PA157&lpg=PA157&dq=new+wine+skins+roger+e.+hedlund&source=bl&ots=CbiYF2MaL0&sig=6x4wJAkkkyYT2vyGVhc9UXMKWEw&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CB0Q6AEwAGoVChMI1vCg7dOhxwIVggaOCh1czwsj#v=onepage&q=hedlund&f=false] * In 1999, ** ''Indian Christians of indigenous origins and their solidarity with original groups'',Roger E. Hedlund, ''Indian Christians of indigenous origins and their solidarity with original groups'', Journal of Dharma, 24 (1):13-27 (1999). [http://philpapers.org/rec/HEDICO] ** ''Indian Instituted Churches: Indigenous Christianity Indian Style'',Roger E. Hedlund, ''Indian Instituted Churches: Indigenous Christianity Indian Style'', Mission Studies, Volume XVI-I, 31, 1999:26-41. Cited in P. Solomon Raj, ''The New Wine-Skins: The Story of Indigenous Mission in Andhra Pradesh'', India, ISPCK/MIIS, New Delhi/Madras, 2003, p.157. [https://books.google.co.in/books?id=Bxdu1WT-_X8C&pg=PA157&lpg=PA157&dq=new+wine+skins+roger+e.+hedlund&source=bl&ots=CbiYF2MaL0&sig=6x4wJAkkkyYT2vyGVhc9UXMKWEw&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CB0Q6AEwAGoVChMI1vCg7dOhxwIVggaOCh1czwsj#v=onepage&q=hedlund&f=false] * In 2002, ''Emerging Indigenous Christianity in India and Asia (19th and 20th Centuries)'',Roger E. Hedlund, ''Emerging Indigenous Christianity in India and Asia (19th and 20th Centuries)'' in Klaus Koschorke (Edited), ''in Transcontinental Links in the History of Non-Western Christianity'', Otto Harrassowitz, Wiesbaden, 2002. [https://books.google.co.in/books?id=WP2hxYZ0rkwC&pg=PA273&lpg=PA273&dq=India+church+growth+roger+e.+hedlund&source=bl&ots=mk35BbrENa&sig=65F1VSVhq4iy4_Ys3Kz1JMJY82s&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CEkQ6AEwCGoVChMI4rvK48ehxwIVio-OCh2GqQry#v=onepage&q=hedlund&f=false] * In 2003, ''The Importance of the Study of India's New Christian Movements'',Roger E. Hedlund, ''The Importance of the Study of India's New Christian Movements'' in P. Solomon Raj, ''The New Wine-Skins: The Story of Indigenous Mission in Andhra Pradesh'', India, ISPCK/MIIS, New Delhi/Madras, 2003, , pp.163-170. [https://books.google.co.in/books?id=Bxdu1WT-_X8C&pg=PA157&lpg=PA157&dq=new+wine+skins+roger+e.+hedlund&source=bl&ots=CbiYF2MaL0&sig=6x4wJAkkkyYT2vyGVhc9UXMKWEw&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CB0Q6AEwAGoVChMI1vCg7dOhxwIVggaOCh1czwsj#v=onepage&q=hedlund&f=false] * In 2004, ''The Witness of New Christian Movements in India''Roger E. Hedlund, ''The Witness of New Christian Movements in India'', August 2004, Paper for the IAMS Assembly in Malaysia. [http://missionstudies.org/archive/conference/1papers/fp/Roger_Hedlund_Full_Paper.pdf] * In 2005, ''Indigenous Pentecostalism in India'',Roger E. Hedlund, ''Indigenous Pentecostalism in India'' in Allan Anderson, Edmond Tang (Edited), ''Asian and Pentecostal: The Charismatic Face of Christianity in Asia'', Regnum Books, Baguio, 2005. [https://books.google.co.in/books?id=LDZgKELq7AoC&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false] * In 2008, ''Hindus and Christians for 2000 years''Roger E. Hedlund, ''Hindus and Christians for 2000 years'', January 2008, Global Missiology.[http://ojs.globalmissiology.org/index.php/english/article/view/245/685] * In 2010, ** ''Present-day Independent Christian Movements: A South Asian Perspective’’Roger E. Hedlund, ‘’ Present-day Independent Christian Movements: A South Asian Perspective’’ in Michael Nai-Chiu Poon (Edited), ‘’Christian Movements in Southeast Asia: A Theological Exploration’’, Genesis Books and Trinity Theological College, Singapore, 2010, pp.39-58. [https://books.google.co.in/books?id=wr-sG0rWilEC&pg=PT38&lpg=PT38&dq=Roger+e.+hedlund&source=bl&ots=CjzVAeT5O3&sig=Aae1HLnO7cPHekeMJA0GC0Kavxc&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CEoQ6AEwCTgKahUKEwiykJLPh5_HAhUQCI4KHaOlBRw#v=onepage&q=Roger%20e.%20hedlund&f=false] **''Understanding Southeast Asian Christianity’’Roger E. Hedlund, ‘’ Understanding Southeast Asian Christianity’’ in Michael Nai-Chiu Poon (Edited), ‘’Christian Movements in Southeast Asia: A Theological Exploration’’, Genesis Books and Trinity Theological College, Singapore, 2010, pp.59-100. [https://books.google.co.in/books?id=wr-sG0rWilEC&pg=PT38&lpg=PT38&dq=Roger+e.+hedlund&source=bl&ots=CjzVAeT5O3&sig=Aae1HLnO7cPHekeMJA0GC0Kavxc&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CEoQ6AEwCTgKahUKEwiykJLPh5_HAhUQCI4KHaOlBRw#v=onepage&q=Roger%20e.%20hedlund&f=false] * In 2012, with Sebastian Kim and Rajkumar Boaz Johnson, ''Indian and Christian: The Life and Legacy of Pandita Ramabai'',Roger E. Hedlund, Sebastian Kim and Rajkumar Boaz Johnson, ''Indian and Christian: The Life and Legacy of Pandita Ramabai'', Religious Studies Review, Volume 38, Issue 2, page 104, June 2012. [http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1748-0922.2012.01604_2.x/citedby] ===Books (authored)=== * In 1970, ''The Protestant Movement in Italy: Its Progress, Problems, and Prospects'',Roger E. Hedlund, ''The Protestant Movement in Italy: Its Progress, Problems, and Prospects'', William Carey Library, Pasadena, 1970. [https://books.google.co.in/books?id=lNSPAAAACAAJ&dq=inauthor:%22Roger+E.+Hedlund%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CDAQ6AEwBGoVChMI9Yz7_8GhxwIVTRiOCh0PIwHd] * In 1982, ''Building the Church'',Roger E. Hedlund, ''Building the Church'', Evangelical Literature Service, Bangalore, 1982. [https://books.google.co.in/books?id=tqGkYgEACAAJ&dq=inauthor:%22Roger+E.+Hedlund%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CDQQ6AEwBWoVChMI9Yz7_8GhxwIVTRiOCh0PIwHd] * In 1985, ''Mission to Man in the Bible'',Roger E. Hedlund, ''Mission to Man in the Bible'', Evangelical Literature Service for Church Growth Research Centre, Madras, 1985. [https://books.google.co.in/books?id=nuartgAACAAJ&dq=inauthor:%22Roger+E.+Hedlund%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CBsQ6AEwADgKahUKEwjIz9zHxaHHAhUMTY4KHWN5BcE] * In 1991, ''The Mission of the Church in the World: A Biblical Theology'',Roger E. Hedlund, ''The Mission of the Church in the World: A Biblical Theology'', Wipf and Stock Publishers, 1991. [https://books.google.co.in/books?id=oyh4nQEACAAJ&dq=inauthor:%22Roger+E.+Hedlund%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CEAQ6AEwCGoVChMI9Yz7_8GhxwIVTRiOCh0PIwHd] * In 1992, ''Evangelization and Church Growth: Issues from the Asian Context'',Roger E. Hedlund, ''Evangelization and Church Growth: Issues from the Asian Context'', C.G.R.C. McGavran Institute, Madras, 1992.[https://books.google.co.in/books/about/Evangelization_and_Church_Growth.html?id=ahTkAAAAMAAJ&redir_esc=y] * In 1993, ''Roots of the Great Debate in Mission: Mission in Historical and Theological Perspective'',Roger E. Hedlund, ''Roots of the Great Debate in Mission: Mission in Historical and Theological Perspective'', Theological Book Trust, Bangalore, 1993. [https://books.google.co.in/books?id=PPQwAAAAMAAJ&q=inauthor:%22Roger+E.+Hedlund%22&dq=inauthor:%22Roger+E.+Hedlund%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CB0Q6AEwAGoVChMI9Yz7_8GhxwIVTRiOCh0PIwHd] * In 1997, ''God and the Nations: A Biblical Theology of Mission in the Asian Context'',Roger E. Hedlund, ''God and the Nations: A Biblical Theology of Mission in the Asian Context'', ISPCK, New Delhi, 1997. [https://books.google.co.in/books?id=-46WpwAACAAJ&dq=inauthor:%22Roger+E.+Hedlund%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CEUQ6AEwCWoVChMI9Yz7_8GhxwIVTRiOCh0PIwHd] * In 2000, ''Quest for Identity: India's Churches of Indigenous Origin: the "Little Tradition" in Indian Christianity'',Roger E. Hedlund, ''Quest for Identity: India's Churches of Indigenous Origin: the "Little Tradition" in Indian Christianity'', ISPCK/MIIS, New Delhi/Madras, 2000. [https://books.google.co.in/books?id=W3sGM-wp1msC&printsec=frontcover&dq=inauthor:%22Roger+E.+Hedlund%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CCIQ6AEwAWoVChMI9Yz7_8GhxwIVTRiOCh0PIwHd#v=onepage&q&f=false] * In 2012, ''William Carey's American Connections: Implications for the Serampore Mission, Indigenous Christianity and India's Renaissance'',Roger E. Hedlund, ''William Carey's American Connections: Implications for the Serampore Mission, Indigenous Christianity and India's Renaissance'', First Fruits Press, Wilmore, Kentucky, 2012. [http://place.asburyseminary.edu/rogerhedlundpapers/3/] ===Books (edited)=== * In 1977, ''Church Growth in the Third World'',Roger E. Hedlund, ''Church Growth in the Third World'', Gospel Literature Service, Bombay, 1977. [https://books.google.co.in/books?id=tuvYAAAAMAAJ&q=roger+e.+hedlund&dq=roger+e.+hedlund&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CCAQ6AEwAWoVChMIvbTFqsGhxwIVQwSOCh0tCwPb] * In 1980, with F. Hrangkhuma, ''Indigenous Missions of India'',Roger E. Hedlund, F. Hrangkhuma (Edited), ''Indigenous Missions of India'', Church Growth Centre, Madras, 1980. Cited in W. John Roxborogh, ''Situating South East Asian Christian Movements in the History of World Christianity'' in Michael Nai-Chiu Poon (Edited), ''Christian Movements in Southeast Asia: A Theological Exploration'', Genesis Books/Trinity, Singapore, 2010, p.30. [https://books.google.co.in/books?id=wr-sG0rWilEC&pg=PT34&lpg=PT34&dq=Indigenous+Missions+of+India+by+Roger+E.+Hedlund&source=bl&ots=CjzVBdP5T2&sig=23mk2Sjme5Ga7fiFKV7XyOtltpI&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CC8Q6AEwBGoVChMIl6rMlsihxwIV03KOCh2AdAHJ#v=onepage&q=Indigenous%20Missions%20of%20India%20by%20Roger%20E.%20Hedlund&f=false] * In 1982, with Beulah Herbert, ''Culture and Evangelization: A Collection of Indian Anthropological Readings''Roger E. Hedlund, Beulah Herbert (Edited), ''Culture and Evangelization: A Collection of Indian Anthropological Readings'', Church Growth Research Centre, Madras, 1982. [https://books.google.co.in/books/about/Culture_and_Evangelization.html?id=LK48AAAAYAAJ&redir_esc=y] * In 1993, with J. T. K. Daniel, ''Carey's Obligation and India's Renaissance'',Roger E. Hedlund, J. T. K. Daniel (Edited), ''Carey's Obligation and India's Renaissance'', Serampore, 1993, pp.96-113. Cited in Klaus Koschorke (Edited), ''in Transcontinental Links in the History of Non-Western Christianity'', Otto Harrassowitz, Wiesbaden, 2002. [https://books.google.co.in/books?id=WP2hxYZ0rkwC&pg=PA273&lpg=PA273&dq=India+church+growth+roger+e.+hedlund&source=bl&ots=mk35BbrENa&sig=65F1VSVhq4iy4_Ys3Kz1JMJY82s&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CEkQ6AEwCGoVChMI4rvK48ehxwIVio-OCh2GqQry#v=onepage&q=hedlund&f=false] * In 2000, ''Christianity is Indian: The Emergence of an Indigenous Community'',Roger E. Hedlund (Edited), ''Christianity is Indian: The Emergence of an Indigenous Community'', ISPCK, New Delhi, 2000. Cited in Klaus Koschorke (Edited), ''in Transcontinental Links in the History of Non-Western Christianity'', Otto Harrassowitz, Wiesbaden, 2002. [https://books.google.co.in/books?id=WP2hxYZ0rkwC&pg=PA273&lpg=PA273&dq=India+church+growth+roger+e.+hedlund&source=bl&ots=mk35BbrENa&sig=65F1VSVhq4iy4_Ys3Kz1JMJY82s&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CEkQ6AEwCGoVChMI4rvK48ehxwIVio-OCh2GqQry#v=onepage&q=hedlund&f=false] * In 2004, with Paul Bhakiaraj, ''Theological Trends in Mission in the 20th Century’’Roger E. Hedlund, Paul Bhakiaraj (Edited), ''Theological Trends in Mission in the 20th Century'', ISPCK, New Delhi, 2004. * In 2012, with Jesudas Athyal, Joshua Kalapati and Jessica Richard, ''The Oxford Encyclopedia of South Asian Christianity'',Roger E. Hedlund, ''The Oxford Encyclopedia of South Asian Christianity'', Oxford University Press, New Delhi, 2012. [http://www.euppublishing.com/doi/abs/10.3366/swc.2013.0063] {{S-start}} {{s-aca}} {{Succession box| before=-| title=Professor,
[[Serampore College]], [[West Bengal]]| after=-| years=1994-1997}} {{S-end}} ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hedlund, Roger E.}} [[Category:Indian Christian theologians]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:University of Madras alumni]] [[Category:Fuller Theological Seminary alumni]] [[Category:Baptist writers]] [[Category:1935 births]] [[Category:Missional Christianity]] [[Category:Senate of Serampore College (University) faculty]]
