{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2016}} {{Use Australian English|date=May 2016}} {{Infobox military person |name= Sir Talbot Hobbs |image= Lieutenant General Talbot Hobbs.jpg |image_size= 250px |alt= |caption= Lieutenant General Talbot Hobbs in 1928 |nickname= |birth_date= {{Birth date|1864|08|24|df=yes}} |birth_place= [[London]], England |death_date= {{Death date and age|1938|04|21|1864|08|24|df=yes}} |death_place= At sea |placeofburial= |allegiance= United Kingdom
Australia |branch= [[British Army]] (1883–87)
[[Australian Army]] (1887–1927) |serviceyears= 1883–1927 |rank= [[Lieutenant general (Australia)|Lieutenant General]] |unit= |commands= [[Australian Corps]] (1918–19)
[[5th Division (Australia)|5th Division]] (1916–18, 1921–27)
1st Division Artillery (1914–16)
22nd Infantry Brigade (1913–14)
Western Australian Mixed Brigade (1908–13)
1st (Western Australian) Field Battery (1903–08) |battles= First World War * [[Gallipoli Campaign]] ** [[Landing at Anzac Cove]] * [[Western Front (World War I)|Western Front]] ** [[Battle of Pozières]] ** [[Battle of Mouquet Farm]] ** [[Battle of Passchendaele]] ** [[Second Battle of Villers-Bretonneux]] ** [[Hundred Days Offensive]] |awards= [[Knight Commander of the Order of the Bath]]
[[Knight Commander of the Order of St Michael and St George]]
[[Colonial Auxiliary Forces Officers' Decoration]]
[[Mentioned in Despatches]] (8)
[[Order of the White Eagle (Serbia)|Commander of the Order of the White Eagle]] (Serbia)
[[Croix de Guerre 1914–1918 (France)|Croix de Guerre]] (France) |relations= |laterwork= Architect }} [[Lieutenant general (Australia)|Lieutenant General]] '''Sir Joseph John Talbot Hobbs''', {{postnominals|country=AUS|size=100|sep=,|KCB|KCMG|VD}} (24 August 1864 – 21 April 1938){{cite book |url=http://www.adb.online.anu.edu.au/biogs/A090322b.htm |title=Hobbs, Sir Joseph John Talbot (1864–1938) |accessdate=2009-07-30 |author=Hill, A. J. |work=[[Australian Dictionary of Biography]] |volume=Vol. 9 |publisher=[[Melbourne University Press]] |year=1983 |pages=315–317}} was an Australian architect and First World War general. ==Early life== Hobbs was born in [[London]], the son of Joseph and his wife Frances Ann Hobbs (née Wilson). Educated at St Mary's church school, [[London Borough of Merton|Merton]], [[Surrey]], Hobbs joined the volunteer artillery in 1883. He also worked as [[technical drawing|draughtsman]] for a builder, John Hurst. In 1886, he emigrated with Hurst to [[Western Australia]] and established an architectural practice in [[Perth]] in 1887. Hobbs designed many of the well known public buildings in Perth and [[Fremantle, Western Australia|Fremantle]], including the [[Weld Club]], the [[Savoy Hotel, Perth|Savoy Hotel]] and the Perth Masonic Lodge. Hobbs was treasurer of the Western Australian Institute of Architects in 1896, and later became the institute's president from 1909 to 1911. From 1905, he was senior partner in the firm of architects, Hobbs, Smith & Forbes. Hobbs also designed a number of private residences. The first of these is believed to be Samson House in Fremantle, an example of late 19th century colonial style, which was built in two stages between 1888 and 1890. The house is registered with the [[National Trust of Australia|National Trust]], and is in the [[Register of the National Estate]].{{cite web |url=http://register.heritage.wa.gov.au/PDF_Files/S%20Reg/Samson%20House%20(I).PDF |title=Register of Heritage Places – Interim Entry – Samson House |accessdate=2007-10-05 |date=1992-03-06 |format=pdf |publisher=Heritage Council of Western Australia |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070901151850/http://register.heritage.wa.gov.au/PDF_Files/S%20Reg/Samson%20House%20(I).PDF |archivedate=1 September 2007 |df=dmy-all }} ==Military career== In 1887, Hobbs joined the volunteer artillery in Perth as a gunner, was commissioned in 1889, and rose to the command of the 1st (Western Australian) Field Battery in 1903. In 1906 he was a lieutenant colonel commanding a Western Australian mixed brigade, and in 1913 a colonel commanding the 22nd Infantry Brigade. On four occasions he went to England and did intensive courses in artillery training with the British Army. He was thus thoroughly equipped when war broke out and, on 8 August 1914 was selected by Major General [[William Bridges (general)|William Bridges]] to command the 1st Australian Divisional Artillery.{{cite web|url=http://discoveringanzacs.naa.gov.au/browse/person/122905 |title=First World War Service Record – Joseph John Talbot Hobbs |publisher=[[National Archives of Australia]] |accessdate=8 October 2014}} After training in Egyp], he was at the [[Landing at Anzac Cove|landing at Gallipoli]] on 25 April 1915 and was soon ashore searching for positions for his guns. Hobbs clashed with Bridges over the placement of the guns. Hobbs was in command of the artillery until 9 November 1915 when he was struck down with dysentery and invalided to [[Cairo]] despite his protests. Hobbs was then promoted brigadier general and made a [[Companion of the Order of the Bath]]. In March 1916 he went with the 1st Australian Division to France, and was in command of the Australian artillery when [[Battle of Pozières|Pozières]] was captured. In December 1916 he assumed command of the [[5th Division (Australia)|5th Australian Division]] and was made a [[major general]] in January. This division was in the thick of the fighting in the spring of 1917, and in September distinguished itself at Polygon Wood. The staff worked well together, and achieved a great victory. Hobbs was created both a [[Knight Commander of the Order of the Bath]] and [[Knight Commander of the Order of St Michael and St George]] on 1 January 1918. At the end of April his division fought at the [[Second Battle of Villers-Bretonneux]], which probably contributed to the abandonment of the German operations towards Amiens. Towards the end of May, Lieutenant General [[John Monash|Sir John Monash]] was placed in command of the [[Australian Corps]], and Hobbs became the senior divisional commander in the corps. His division was then given a well-earned rest but took a share in the great counterattack which began on 8 August. It did not take a leading part in the capture of Mont St Quentin, but Monash, in his ''The Australian Victories in France'', stated that he was "concerned ... that the fine performance of the Fifth Division should not be underrated. The circumstances under which general Hobbs was called upon to intervene in the battle, at very short notice, imposed upon him, personally, difficulties of no mean order". One of his tasks it may be mentioned was the crossing of the Somme in the face of strong opposition, and when Hobbs sent a message to the men of his war-worn division on its beginning a rest period on 8 September, he was able to say that they had "earned imperishable fame for their gallantry and valour".{{cn|date=May 2018}} It was but a short rest, for they were in the line again later on in the same month, and Hobbs was making careful plans for the attack on the Hindenburg line which was successfully breached by the 3rd and 5th divisions on 30 September and 1 October. Monash was put in charge of the repatriation and demobilisation of the Australian troops, and Hobbs succeeded him in the command of the Australian Corps until May 1919. ==Post-war== After the [[Armistice]], Hobbs decided to return to his former profession; architecture. With a keen interest in the construction of war memorials, Hobbs was responsible for designing the Western Australian War Memorial in [[Kings Park, Western Australia|Kings Park]], Perth, St George's College, Crawley and the Temperance and General and Royal Insurance buildings. Hobbs died at sea of a [[myocardial infarction|heart attack]] while en route to the unveiling of the [[Villers–Bretonneux Australian National Memorial]], built to the design of English architect [[Edwin Lutyens|Sir Edwin Lutyens]]. ==Legacy== [[File:Public art- Talbot Hobbs, Perth2.jpg|thumb|Sir Talbot Hobbs Memorial at [[Esplanade Reserve|The Esplanade]], [[Perth]]]] Hobbs was a short and slight man, whose civilian life was that of a successful citizen who had a full realisation of his responsibilities to the society of which he was a member. Hobbs was capable, self-sacrificing and measured his life by high standards. Monash said of Hobbs that he "succeeded fully as the Commander of a Division by his sound common sense and his sane attitude towards every problem that confronted him". The eulogy of Lieutenant General [[Brudenell White|Sir Brudenell White]] was "he was not only a soldier, he was also a great citizen, and a great Christian gentleman ... who knew none other than the straight path".{{cn|date=May 2018}} The ''Lieut. General Sir J. J. Talbot Hobbs Memorial'', better known as the ''Talbot Hobbs memorial'', was proposed and constructed just prior to the Second World War.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article76062709 |title=MEMORIAL TO SIR TALBOT HOBBS?. |newspaper=[[The Mirror (Western Australia)|The Mirror]] |location=Perth |date=14 January 1939 |accessdate=7 March 2012 |page=10 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article46733918 |title=SIR TALBOT HOBBS MEMORIAL. |newspaper=[[The West Australian]] |location=Perth |date=23 August 1940 |accessdate=7 March 2012 |page=16 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}{{cite web|url=http://www.anzac.dpc.wa.gov.au/index0f1d.html|archive-url=http://pandora.nla.gov.au/pan/43108/20080815-0049/www.anzac.dpc.wa.gov.au/index0f1d.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2008-08-15|title=ANZAC – A Grateful State Remembers – :RE:|author=S Dodds|work=nla.gov.au}} The memorial is made of [[Donnybrook stone]] with a bronze bust of Hobbs on top, and placed against a background of [[Phoenix canariensis|Canary Island Palms]]{{cite web|title=02089 Talbot Hobbs|url=http://register.heritage.wa.gov.au/PDF_Files/K-L%20Reg/02089%20Talbot%20Hobbs%28P%29.PDF|work=Register of Heritage places, permanent entry|publisher=Heritage Council of Western Australia|accessdate=10 March 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090924075549/http://register.heritage.wa.gov.au/PDF_Files/K-L%20Reg/02089%20Talbot%20Hobbs(P).PDF|archivedate=24 September 2009|df=dmy-all}} on the [[The Esplanade (Perth)|Perth Esplanade]]. Since it was built the memorial has been the receiving point for the salute during [[Anzac Day]] parade, it was also the location from where [[Elizabeth II|Queen Elizabeth II]] took the salute during the 1954 Royal visit. The memorial was placed on the Western Australian Heritage register on 18 March 2005. The [[Elizabeth Quay|2012 redevelopment plans]] for the Perth Esplanade include relocation of the memorial.{{cite web|url=http://citygatekeepers.com.au/the-esplanade-heritage-and-history/j-j-talbot-hobbs-memorial/|title=J.J. Talbot Hobbs memorial|publisher=The City Gatekeepers|accessdate=22 March 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130409012608/http://citygatekeepers.com.au/the-esplanade-heritage-and-history/j-j-talbot-hobbs-memorial/|archivedate=9 April 2013|df=dmy-all}} {{As of|April 2014}} the memorial was being moved to the Supreme Court Gardens.{{cite web|url=http://www.mra.wa.gov.au/News/21833/Talbot-Hobbs-memorial-on-the-move|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140413130631/http://www.mra.wa.gov.au/News/21833/Talbot-Hobbs-memorial-on-the-move|dead-url=yes|archive-date=13 April 2014|title=Talbot Hobbs memorial on the move|publisher=Metropolitan Redevelopment Authority|date=4 April 2014|accessdate=12 April 2014}} ==See also== * [[List of buildings designed by Talbot Hobbs]] ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==Further reading== * {{cite book|last=Coombes|first=David|year=2007|title=The Lionheart: A Life of Lieutenant General Sir Talbot Hobbs|place=Loftus, New South Wales|publisher=Australian Military History Publications|isbn=9780980379624}} * {{cite book|last=Taylor|first=John J.|year=2014|title=Between Duty and Design: The Architect Soldier Sir J.J. Talbot Hobbs|place=Crawley, Western Australia|publisher=UWA Publishing|isbn=9781742586205}} ==External links== {{commonscat|Talbot Hobbs memorial statue}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20050620085145/http://www.diggerhistory.info/pages-leaders/ww1/hobbs.htm Digger History] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060504004530/http://www.unsw.adfa.edu.au/~rmallett/Generals/hobbs.html General Officers of the 1st AIF: Talbot Hobbs] * {{Dictionary of Australian Biography|First=Joseph John Talbot |Last=Hobbs|shortlink=0-dict-biogHi-Hu.html#hobbs1}} * {{cite web|url=http://discoveringanzacs.naa.gov.au/browse/person/122905 |title=First World War Service Record – Joseph John Talbot |publisher=[[National Archives of Australia]] |accessdate=8 October 2014}} * [http://www.defence.gov.au/defencemagazine/editions/200708_08/anzac_france.pdf Defence Magazine Issue 8 2007/08] {{Australian Generals of World War I}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hobbs, Joseph John Talbot}} [[Category:1864 births]] [[Category:1938 deaths]] [[Category:Architects from Western Australia]] [[Category:Australian generals]] [[Category:Australian Knights Commander of the Order of St Michael and St George]] [[Category:Australian Knights Commander of the Order of the Bath]] [[Category:Australian military personnel of World War I]] [[Category:Commanders of the Order of the White Eagle (Serbia)]] [[Category:English emigrants to Australia]] [[Category:Federation architects]] [[Category:People from London]] [[Category:People who died at sea]] [[Category:Recipients of the Croix de Guerre 1914–1918 (France)]] [[Category:Royal Artillery soldiers]]

revision.text:
{{terrorism}} '''Terrorism insurance''' is [[insurance]] purchased by property owners to cover their potential losses and liabilities that might occur due to [[terrorism|terrorist]] activities.
It is considered to be a difficult product for insurance companies, as the odds of terrorist attacks are very difficult to predict and the potential liability enormous. For example, the [[September 11, 2001 attacks]] resulted in an estimated $31.7 billion loss.{{citation needed|date=December 2014}} This combination of uncertainty and potentially huge losses makes the setting of [[insurance premium|premiums]] a difficult matter. Most insurance companies therefore exclude terrorism from coverage in [[Casualty insurance|casualty]] and [[property insurance]], or else require endorsements to provide coverage.
==Industry needs== Concentration of risk is another factor in determining availability for terrorism insurance. Due to the concentrated losses of the [[World Trade Center (1973–2001)|World Trade Center]], carriers were hit with large losses in one centralized location. Insurers seek to spread the coverage over a wider geographic area than as with other aggregate perils, such as flood.
==Modelling the risks==
Insurance companies are using an approach that is similar to that used with natural catastrophe risks. A Swiss report{{Citation needed|date=November 2010}} suggested that in this case where demand is greater than the supply for terrorism coverage that a short-term solution is possible: a mix of government and private resource to make easy the transition. In this situation, the government would serve two functions: to establish rules to overcome the capacity shortage and to be the insurer of last resort.
==By country==
===Netherlands=== [[Insurance]] payments related to [[terrorism]] are restricted to a billion euro per year for all insurance companies together{{Citation needed|date=November 2007}}. This regards property insurance, but also life insurance, medical insurance, etc.
===United States===
In 2002, the [[US Congress]] enacted the [[Terrorism Risk Insurance Act]], in which the government shared the cost of large insurance losses.<ref name="auto">{{cite web|title=Expiring terrorism insurance program alarms Md. industries|url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/news/maryland/bs-md-terrorism-insurance-20141227-story.html#page=1|publisher=Baltimore Sun|accessdate=28 December 2014}}</ref>
On December 26, 2007, the President of the United States signed into law the Terrorism Risk Insurance Program Reauthorization Act of 2007 which extends the [[Terrorism Risk Insurance Act|Terrorism Risk Insurance Act (TRIA)]] through December 31, 2014. The law extends the temporary federal Program that provides for a transparent system of shared public and private compensation for insured losses resulting from acts of terrorism.<ref>[http://www.treas.gov/offices/domestic-finance/financial-institution/terrorism-insurance/ U.S. Treasury - Office of Domestic Finance - Terrorism Risk Insurance Program<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071114045440/http://www.treas.gov/offices/domestic-finance/financial-institution/terrorism-insurance/ |date=2007-11-14 }}</ref>
Some economists have supported U.S. government subsidies of terrorism insurance. Soon after the 9/11 terrorist attacks, economist [[Edwin Mills (economist)|Edwin Mills]] expressed concern over whether private developers could build real estate without subsidies for insurance.<ref>Edwin Mills, Terrorism and US real estate, Journal of Urban Economics 51 (2002) 198–204.</ref> Economist [[David R. Barker]] argued that properly structured subsidies could increase overall economic efficiency.<ref>David Barker, Terrorism insurance subsidies and social welfare, Journal of Urban Economics 54 (2003) 328–338</ref> Other economists have argued against these subsidies.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Terrorism Risk Insurance Act: Time to End the Corporate Welfare|url=http://object.cato.org/sites/cato.org/files/pubs/pdf/pa736_web_1.pdf|publisher=Cato Institute|accessdate=27 April 2014}}</ref><ref>Dwight Jaffee and Thomas Russell, Public Insurance and Private Markets, 2010, pp. 86-114, Washington, D.C.: AEI Press; distributed by Rowman and Littlefield, Lanham, Md.</ref>
The United States insurance market offers coverage to the majority of large companies which ask for it in their policies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pciaa.net/sitehome.nsf/lcpublic/|title=Property Casualty Insurers Association of America|publisher=|accessdate=12 February 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120909014736/http://www.pciaa.net/sitehome.nsf/lcpublic/|archivedate=9 September 2012|df=}}</ref> The price of the policy depends on where the clients are residing and how much limit they buy.
[[Image:UA Flight 175 hits WTC south tower 9-11.jpeg|thumb|right|[[9/11|Attack]] on the [[World Trade Center (1973–2001)|World Trade Center]]]] According to ''The Economist''{{Citation needed|date=November 2007}}, one of the best studies to understand TRIA has been the one undertaken in 2005 by the Center for Risk Management at the Wharton Business School ("TRIA and Beyond"; available on their website below).
In mid-2007 the idea of another extension to TRIA was tabled and is officially known as TRIREA{{Citation needed|date=November 2007}}, (Terrorism Risk Insurance Revision and Extension Act). Initially TRIREA contained several new provisions including a mandatory 'make available' clause for NCBR coverage (Nuclear, Chemical, Biological and Radiological) and the ending of the distinction between domestic and foreign events.
The act expired on December 31, 2014, but was renewed at the start of the next congress, with Obama signing the extension of the TIRA through 2020 on January 12, 2015.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sddt.com/Construction/article.cfm?SourceCode=20150116czm&_t=TRIA+reauthorized+with+several+tweaks#.V4fRhPkrLDc|title=TRIA reauthorized with several tweaks|date=2015-01-19|access-date=2016-07-14}}</ref> Up until the 2014 expiration, many experts warned that "construction projects could be stalled and commercial loans on shopping malls, utilities and skyscrapers could be in jeopardy." In addition, according to the [[Baltimore Sun]], the [[National Football League]] denied rumors that it would cancel the [[Super Bowl]] over the issue.<ref name="auto"/>
===Iraq=== The [[New York Times]] reports that in Baghdad personal terrorism insurance is available. One company offers such insurance for $90, and if the customer is a victim of terrorism in the next year, it pays the heirs $3,500.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/03/21/international/middleeast/21insurance.html?_r=1|title=New Business Blooms in Iraq: Terror Insurance|publisher=|accessdate=12 February 2015}}</ref>
===United Kingdom=== In the [[United Kingdom|UK]], following the [[Baltic Exchange bomb|Baltic Exchange bomb in 1992]], all UK insurers stopped including terrorism coverage on their commercial insurance policies with effect from 1 January 1993 (home insurance policies were unaffected). As a consequence, the government and insurance industry established the [[Pool Re|Pool Reinsurance Company Ltd (Pool Re)]]. Primarily funded by premiums paid by policyholders, the government guarantees the fund although any such support must be repaid from future premiums. To date, despite paying over £600 million in relation to thirteen separate claims, no government support has been necessary.<ref>{{cite web|title=About the Company|url=https://www.poolre.co.uk/|website=Pool Reinsurance|accessdate=26 February 2015}}</ref>
===France=== In [[France]], a pool of insurers and reinsurers was set up on 1 January 2002 under the name Gestion de l'Assurance et de la RÉassurance des risques attentats et Actes de Terrorisme (GAREAT). GAREAT is constituted upon the principle of mutuality between its Members, all of whom are jointly liable, and relies on the support given to GAREAT by international reinsurers as well as by the French State which provides unlimited coverage to the GAREAT programme via unlimited treaties reinsured 100% by [[:fr:Caisse centrale de réassurance|Caisse Centrale de Réassurance (CCR)]]. As a non-profit-making Economic Interest Grouping mandated by its Members, GAREAT returns to the latter that part of the premiums which are not used to finance the reinsurance coverage at the close of each year.<ref>{{cite web|title=Who are we?|url=http://www.gareat.com/en|website=GAREAT|accessdate=16 February 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Gestion de l'assurance et de la réassurance des risques attentats et actes de terrorisme|url=https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gestion_de_l%27assurance_et_de_la_r%C3%A9assurance_des_risques_attentats_et_actes_de_terrorisme|website=Wikipédia (French)|accessdate=16 February 2017}}</ref>{{Better source|reason=per WP:CIRCULAR|date=February 2017}}
==Countries with long-term terrorism insurance programmes== According to the [https://web.archive.org/web/20060908135329/http://www.rer.org/politicalaction/index.cfm policy agenda] of [[The Real Estate Roundtable]], long-term terrorism insurance is available in the following countries:
#[[Australia]] #[[Austria]] #[[Finland]] #[[France]] #[[Germany]] #[[Israel]] #[[Namibia]] #[[Netherlands]] #[[Russia]] #[[South Africa]] #[[Spain]] #[[Switzerland]] #[[Turkey]] #[[United Kingdom]] #[[India]]
==See also== *[[Security]] *[[Geneva Association]] (also known as the International Association for the Study of Insurance Economics) *[[Pool Re]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.iii.org/facts_statistics/terrorism.html Terrorism] from the [[Insurance Information Institute]] * [https://archive.is/20130117130725/http://www.atypon-link.com/AEAP/doi/pdf/10.1257/0895330042632717 Policy Watch: Challenges for Terorrism Risk Insurance in the United States] (Wharton's authors) * [http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0BJK/is_8_13/ai_89018180/ Terrorism Insurance: Where's the coverage?] * [https://www.forbes.com/2005/07/12/terrorism-insurance-security-cz_jl_0712opinion_print.html America Needs Terrorism Insurance] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070414213214/http://www.cato.org/pubs/regulation/regv28n1/v28n1-8.pdf Terrorism Insurance: Where Do We Go from Here?] (Wharton's authors) *[http://www.insureagainstterrorism.org CIAT: Coalition to Insure Against Terrorism] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070217132851/http://opim.wharton.upenn.edu/risk/projects/terrorins.html Wharton Risk Center on Terrorism Insurance Markets]
{{Insurance}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Terrorism Insurance}} [[Category:Types of insurance]] [[Category:Terrorism|insurance]]

revision.text:
{{Merge from | Death-positive movement |discuss=Talk:The Order of the Good Death#Merger discussion|date=March 2018 }} '''The Order of the Good Death''' is a [[Death anxiety (psychology)|death acceptance]] organization founded in 2011 by mortician and author [[Caitlin Doughty]].<ref name=Coye2014/><ref name=OConnor2013/><ref name=Washburn2013/> The group advocates for [[natural burial]] and embracing human mortality.<ref>{{citation|title=Natural Burial|publisher=The Order of the Good Death|url=http://www.orderofthegooddeath.com/naturalburial|accessdate=2017-05-08}}</ref>
Along with Doughty, members include Sarah Chavez<ref>http://www.orderofthegooddeath.com/members</ref>, Director of The Order of the Good Death, Megan Rosenbloom, Director of Death Salon, and Amber Carvaly, Director of Undertaking LA. Other notable members are artist and monument-maker [[Greg Lundgren]], [[TED (conference)|TED speaker]] Jae Rhim Lee, alternative funeral home director Jeff Jorgenson, artist [[Landis Blair]],<ref>http://www.orderofthegooddeath.com/members</ref> and other death professionals, artists and academics.<ref name=Gross2014/><ref name=Kiley2014a/><ref name=Kiley2014b/><ref name=Sayles2014/><ref>{{citation|title=Members: Death Professionals|publisher=The Order of the Good Death|url=http://www.orderofthegooddeath.com/members/death-professionals|accessdate=2014-12-26}}</ref><ref name=Pompilio2013/>
The group held its first "death [[salon (gathering)|salon]]" in Los Angeles in 2013.<ref name=Hayasaki2013/><ref name=OConnor2013/><ref name=Courtland2014/><ref name=Kellogg2013/><ref name=deathsalon/> Another salon was held in 2014 at [[St Bartholomew's Hospital]] Pathology Museum in London by museum curator Carla Valentine.<ref name=Sherwin2014/>
The group took its name from the Brazilian [[Order of Our Lady of the Good Death]].<ref>{{citation|title=About us|publisher=The Order of the Good Death|url=http://www.orderofthegooddeath.com/about|accessdate=2014-12-27|quote=The Order was inspired by several historical concepts of the good death, including the medieval Ars Moriendi (Art of Dying) and the Tibetan Bardo Thodol. The name itself is taken from the 19th century Brazilian sisterhood of African slaves, Irmandade da Nossa Senhora da Boa Morte, or, Sisterhood of Our Lady of the Good Death.}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|30em|refs=
<ref name=Coye2014> {{citation|title=Seven Sacraments for Everyone | first=Dale F. |last=Coye | publisher=FriesenPress | year=2014 | isbn=9781460231555 | p=199 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EjhHAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA199}}</ref>
<ref name=OConnor2013> {{citation| title=The Death-Positive Movement | author=Kim O'Connor | date=May 16, 2013 |journal=[[Pacific Standard]] | url=https://psmag.com/social-justice/the-death-positive-movement-57768}}</ref>
<ref name=Washburn2013> {{citation|title=Decomposure | first=Michael | last=Washburn | journal=University of Chicago Magazine | date=March–April 2013 | url=http://mag.uchicago.edu/decomposure}}</ref>
<ref name=Kiley2014a> {{Citation |last= Kiley |title= It's Time to Think About Your Demise; An Interview with Caitlin Doughty, Author of Smoke Gets in Your Eyes and Doyenne of Death |first= Brendan |newspaper= [[The Stranger (newspaper)|The Stranger]] |date= September 17, 2014 |url= http://www.thestranger.com/seattle/its-time-to-think-about-your-demise/Content?oid=20613253 |accessdate= September 18, 2014 }}</ref>
<ref name=Kiley2014b> {{citation|title=Enough Talk About Your Youth—Let's Talk About Your Death: Seattle Is at the Forefront of Innovative Thinking About What to Do with Dead Bodies|first=Brendan|last=Kiley|newspaper= [[The Stranger (newspaper)|The Stranger]] |date= September 17, 2014 |url=http://www.thestranger.com/seattle/enough-talk-about-your-youthandmdashlets-talk-about-your-death/Content?oid=20607997}}</ref>
<ref name=Gross2014> {{Citation |url= https://www.npr.org/templates/transcript/transcript.php?storyId=352765943 |title= A Mortician Talks Openly About Death, And Wants You To, Too [interview transcript] |publisher=[[NPR]] |last= Gross |first= Terry |authorlink=Terry Gross |date= October 8, 2014 |accessdate= October 29, 2014 }}</ref>
<ref name=Hayasaki2013> {{citation|title=Death Is Having a Moment—Fueled by social networking, the growing "death movement" is a reaction against the sanitization of death that has persisted in American culture since the 1800s" | first=Erika | last=Hayasaki | date=October 25, 2013 | journal=[[The Atlantic]] | url=https://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2013/10/death-is-having-a-moment/280777/}}</ref>
<ref name=Courtland2014> {{citation|title=Caitlin Doughty: The Millennial's Mortician | first=Emma |last=Courtland |date=May 14, 2014 | journal=[[LA Weekly]] | url=http://www.laweekly.com/informer/2014/05/14/caitlin-doughty-the-millennials-mortician}}</ref>
<ref name=Kellogg2013> {{citation|title=It's not too late to get to the Death Salon | date=October 19, 2013| author=Carolyn Kellogg | newspaper=[[The Los Angeles Times]] | url=http://articles.latimes.com/2013/oct/19/entertainment/la-et-jc-death-salon-20131017}}</ref>
<ref name=deathsalon> {{citation|title=Death Salon|publisher=The Order of the Good Death|url=http://www.orderofthegooddeath.com/death-salon|accessdate=2014-12-27}}</ref>
<ref name=Sherwin2014> {{citation|title=To die for: Death Salon mortality conference - the event meant to help you go out with a bang | newspaper=[[The Independent]] | author=Adam Sherwin | date=April 11, 2014 | url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/to-die-for-death-salon-mortality-conference--the-event-meant-to-help-you-go-out-with-a-bang-9255118.html}}</ref>
<ref name=Sayles2014> {{citation|title=Hot topics: Hey funeral directors, move out of the way! | editor=Damon Sayles | work=Funeral Home and Cemetery Executive Briefing|date=December 16, 2014|url=http://www.multibriefs.com/briefs/MV-FuneralEB/MV-FUNERALEB121614.php|accessdate=2014-12-26}}</ref>

revision.text:
[[File:SNIC.png|thumb|250px|Dynamics of the theta model on the unit circle. Blue denotes a stable fixed point; Green denotes an unstable fixed point. By varying the input parameter, the two equilibria collide and form a stable limit cycle; Gray arrows indicate that the points are attracting in <math>\mathbb{R}^2</math>; Black arrows indicate the direction of movement along the unit circle.]] The '''theta model''', or '''Ermentrout–Kopell [[canonical form|canonical]] model''', is a [[biological neuron model]] originally developed to model neurons in the animal [[Aplysia]], and later used in various fields of [[computational neuroscience]]. The model is particularly well suited to describe neuron [[bursting]], which are rapid oscillations in the [[membrane potential]] of a neuron interrupted by periods of relatively little oscillation. Bursts are often found in [[neurons]] responsible for controlling and maintaining steady rhythms. For example, breathing is controlled by a small network of bursting neurons in the brain stem. Of the three main classes of bursting [[neurons]] ([[Bursting#Square-wave burster|square wave bursting]], [[parabolic bursting]], and [[elliptic bursting]]),<ref>{{cite journal |author=Lee |title=Stability Analysis Of Bursting Models |journal=Journal of the Korean Mathematical Society |volume=42 |issue=4 |pages=827–45 |year=2005 |doi=10.4134/jkms.2005.42.4.827}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author=Vries G. De. |title=Multiple Bifurcations in a Polynomial Model of Bursting Oscillations |journal=Journal of Nonlinear Science |volume=8 |issue=3 |pages=281–316 |year=1998 |doi=10.1007/s003329900053}}</ref> the theta model describes [[parabolic bursting]]. [[Parabolic bursting]] is characterized by a series of bursts that are regulated by a slower external oscillation.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Ermentrout B, Kopell, N |title=Parabolic bursting in an [[excitable system]] coupled with a slow oscillation |journal=SIAM Journal of Applied Mathematics | volume=46 |pages=233–253 |year=1986 |doi=10.1137/0146017}}</ref> This slow oscillation changes the frequency of the faster oscillation so that the frequency curve of the burst pattern resembles a parabola.
The model has just one [[state variable]] which describes the membrane voltage of a neuron. In contrast, the [[Hodgkin–Huxley model]] consists of four state variables (one voltage variable and three gating variables) and the [[Morris–Lecar model]] is defined by two state variables (one voltage variable and one gating variable).<ref>{{cite book |vauthors=Ermentrout B, Terman DH |title=Mathematical Foundations of Neuroscience |publisher=Springer |location=New York |year=2010 |isbn=978-0-387-87707-5 }}</ref> The single [[state variable]] of the theta model, and the elegantly simple [[equations]] that govern its behavior allow for [[analytical expression|analytic]], or [[Closed-form expression|closed-form]] solutions (including an explicit expression for the [[phase response curve]]). The [[dynamical system|dynamics]] of the model take place on the [[unit circle]], and are governed by two [[cosine]] functions and a real-valued input [[function (mathematics)|function]].<ref>{{cite journal |author=Ermentrout B, Kopell, N |title=Parabolic bursting in an excitable system coupled with a slow oscillation |journal=SIAM Journal of Applied Mathematics | volume=46 |pages=233–253 |year=1986 |doi=10.1137/0146017}}</ref>
Similar models include the [[quadratic integrate and fire]] (QIF) model, which differs from the theta model by only by a [[change of variables]]<ref>{{cite journal |author=Brunel, Nicolas, Latham |title=Firing Rate of the Noisy Quadratic Integrate-and-Fire Neuron |journal=Neural Computation | volume=15 | issue=10 |pages=2281–306 |year=2003 |doi=10.1162/089976603322362365}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author=Ermentrout B. |title=Ermentrout–Kopell Canonical Model |journal=Scholarpedia | volume=3 | issue=3 |pages=1398 |year=2008 |doi=10.4249/scholarpedia.1398}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author=Gielen, Stan, Krupa, Zeitler |title=Gamma Oscillations as a Mechanism for Selective Information Transmission |journal=Biological Cybernetics | volume=103 | issue=2 |pages=151–65 |year=2010 |doi=10.1007/s00422-010-0390-x}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author=Latham, P. E., B. J. Richmond, P. G. Nelson, and S. Nirenberg. |title=Intrinsic Dynamics in Neuronal Networks. I. Theory. |journal=Journal of Neurophysiology | volume=88 | issue=2 |pages=808–27 |year=2000}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author=Richardson, M., J. E. |title=Spike-train Spectra and Network Response Functions for Non-linear Integrate-and-fire Neurons |journal=Biological Cybernetics | volume=99 | issue=4 |pages=381–92 |year=2008 |doi=10.1007/s00422-008-0244-y}}</ref> and [[Plant's model]],<ref>{{cite journal |author=Plant, R. Kim, M. |title=Mathematical Description of a Bursting Pacemaker Neuron by a Modification of the Hodgkin–Huxley Equations |journal=Biophysical Journal | volume=16 | issue=3 |pages=227–44 |year=1976 |doi=10.1016/s0006-3495(76)85683-4 |pmid=1252578 |pmc=1334834}}</ref> which consists of Hodgkin–Huxley type equations and also differs from the theta model by a series of coordinate transformations.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Soto-Treviño, C., N. Kopell, and D. Watson |title=Parabolic Bursting Revisited |journal=Journal of Mathematical Biology | volume=35 | issue=1 |pages=114–28 |year=1996 |doi=10.1007/s002850050046}}</ref>
Despite its simplicity, the theta model offers enough complexity in its [[dynamical system|dynamics]] that it has been used for a wide range of [[theoretical neuroscience]] research<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Börgers C. |author2=Epstein S. |author3=Kopell N. |last-author-amp=yes |title=Gamma Oscillations Mediate Stimulus Competition and Attentional Selection in a Cortical Network Model|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America | volume=105 | issue=46 |pages=18023–18028 |year=2008 |doi=10.1073/pnas.0809511105 |pmid=19004759 |pmc=2584712}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author1=Osan R. |author2=Rubin J. |author3=Ermentrout B. |last-author-amp=yes |title=Regular Traveling Waves in a One-Dimensional Network of Theta Neurons |journal=SIAM Journal on Applied Mathematics | volume=62 | issue=4 |pages=1197–1221 |year=2002 |doi=10.1137/s0036139901387253|citeseerx=10.1.1.83.2413 }}</ref> as well as in research beyond [[biology]], such as in [[artificial intelligence]].<ref>{{cite journal |author=McKennoch, S., Voegtlin T., and Bushnell L. |title=Spike-Timing Error Backpropagation in Theta Neuron Networks |journal=Neural Computation | volume=21 | issue=1 |pages=9–45| doi=10.1162/neco.2009.09-07-610 |year=2008}}</ref>
==Background and history== [[File:pbc burst.png|left|thumb|250px|A model of [[pre-Bötzinger complex]] (pBC) [[neuron]]. The pre-Bötzinger complex is a region in the [[brain stem]] responsible for maintaining breathing rhythms. This is an example of a [[square-wave burster]].<ref>{{cite journal |author=Lee |title=Stability Analysis Of Bursting Models |journal=Journal of the Korean Mathematical Society |volume=42 |issue=4 |pages=827–45 |year=2005 |doi=10.4134/jkms.2005.42.4.827}}</ref> In a slice preparation of the pBC complex, the neurons burst periodically and synchronize as long as they receive a continual, external, noisy input.]]
Bursting is "an oscillation in which an observable [part] of the system, such as [[voltage]] or [[chemical concentration]], changes periodically between an active phase of rapid [[action potential|spike]] oscillations (the fast sub-system) and a phase of quiescence".<ref>{{cite journal |author=Bertram, R., M. Butte, T. Kiemel, and A. Sherman. |title=Topological and Phenomenological Classification of Bursting Oscillations |journal=Bulletin of Mathematical Biology |volume=57 |issue=3 |pages=413–39 |year=1995 |doi=10.1016/s0092-8240(05)81776-8}}</ref> Bursting comes in three distinct forms: [[square wave bursting]], [[parabolic bursting]], and [[elliptic bursting]].<ref>{{cite journal |author=Lee |title=Stability Analysis Of Bursting Models |journal=Journal of the Korean Mathematical Society |volume=42 |issue=4 |pages=827–45 |year=2005 |doi=10.4134/jkms.2005.42.4.827}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author=Vries G. De. |title=Multiple Bifurcations in a Polynomial Model of Bursting Oscillations |journal=Journal of Nonlinear Science |volume=8 |issue=3 |pages=281–316 |year=1998 |doi=10.1007/s003329900053}}</ref> There exist some models that do not fit neatly into these categories by qualitative observation, but it is possible to sort such models by their [[topology]] (i.e. such models can be sorted "by the structure of the fast subsystem").<ref>{{cite journal |author=Bertram, R., M. Butte, T. Kiemel, and A. Sherman. |title=Topological and Phenomenological Classification of Bursting Oscillations |journal=Bulletin of Mathematical Biology |volume=57 |issue=3 |pages=413–39 |year=1995 |doi=10.1016/s0092-8240(05)81776-8}}</ref>
All three forms of bursting are capable of beating and periodic bursting.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Plant, R. Kim, M. |title=Mathematical Description of a Bursting Pacemaker Neuron by a Modification of the Hodgkin–Huxley Equations |journal=Biophysical Journal | volume=16 | issue=3 |pages=227–44 |year=1976 |doi=10.1016/s0006-3495(76)85683-4 |pmid=1252578 |pmc=1334834}}</ref> Periodic bursting (or just bursting) is of more interest because many phenomena are controlled by, or arise from, bursting. For example, bursting due to a changing [[membrane potential]] is common in various neurons, including but not limited to [[Cerebral cortex|cortical]] chattering neurons, [[thalamacortical]] neurons,<ref>{{cite journal |author=Izhikevich, E.M. |title=Bursting |journal=Scholarpedia | volume=1 | issue=3 |pages=1300 |year=2006 |doi=10.4249/scholarpedia.1300}}</ref> and [[pacemaker neurons]]. Pacemakers in general are known to burst and [[synchronize]] as a population, thus generating a robust rhythm that can maintain repetitive tasks like breathing, walking, and eating.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Marder, E. |author2=R. L. Calabrese. |lastauthoramp=yes |title=Principles of Rhythmic Motor Pattern Generation |journal=Physiol. Rev. | volume=76 |pages=687–717 |year=1996}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |author=Stein, P., S. Grillner, A. Selverston, and D. Stuart |title=Neurons, Networks, and Motor Behavior |publisher=MIT Press | ISBN=0-262-19390-6 |year=1997}}</ref> Beating occurs when a [[cell (biology)|cell]] bursts continuously with no periodic quiescent periods,<ref>{{cite journal |author=Lechner, H. A., D. A. Baxter, J. W. Clark, and J. H. Byrne |title=Bistability and Its Regulation By Serotonin in the Endogenously Bursting Neuron Rl5 in Aplysia |journal=Journal of Neurophysiology | volume=75 | issue=2 |pages=957–62 |year=1996}}</ref> but beating is often considered to be an extreme case and is rarely of primary interest.
Bursting cells are important for motor generation and synchronization.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Izhikevich, E.M. |title=Bursting |journal=Scholarpedia | volume=1 | issue=3 |pages=1300 |year=2006 |doi=10.4249/scholarpedia.1300}}</ref> For example, the [[pre-Bötzinger complex]] in the [[mammal]]ian [[brain stem]] contains many bursting neurons that control autonomous breathing rhythms.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Butera, J. R., J. Rinzel, and J. C. Smith. |title=Models of Respiratory Rhythm Generation in the Pre-Bötzinger Complex. I. Bursting Pacemaker Neurons |journal=J. Neurophysiol. | volume=82 |pages=398–415 |year=1999 |doi=10.1152/jn.1999.82.1.398}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author1=Del Negro |author2=C. A. |author3=C. G. Wilson |author4=R. J. Butera |author5=J. C. Smith |last-author-amp=yes |title=Periodicity, Mixed-mode Oscillations, and Quasiperiodicity in a Rhythm-generating Neural Network |journal=Biophys. J. | volume=82 |pages=206–14 |year=2002 |doi=10.1016/s0006-3495(02)75387-3 |bibcode=2002BpJ....82..206D}}</ref> Various [[Neocortex|neocortical neurons]] (i.e. cells of the [[neocortex]]) are capable of bursting, which "contribute significantly to [the] network behavior [of neocortical neurons]".<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Connors, B. |author2=M. Gutnick |lastauthoramp=yes |title=Intrinsic Firing Patterns of Diverse Neocortical Neurons |journal=Trends in Neurosciences | volume=13 | issue=3 |pages=99–104 |year=1990 |doi=10.1016/0166-2236(90)90185-d}}</ref> The [[R15 neuron]] of the [[abdominal ganglion]] in ''Aplyisa'', hypothesized to be a [pneurosecretory[] cell (i.e. a cell that produces hormones), is known to produce bursts characteristic of neurosecretory cells.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Adams, W. |author2=J. A. Benson |lastauthoramp=yes |title=The Generation and Modulation of Endogenous Rhythmicity in the Aplysia Bursting Pacemaker Neurone R15 |journal=Progress in Biophysics and Molecular Biology | volume=46 | issue=1 |pages=1–49 |year=1985 |doi=10.1016/0079-6107(85)90011-2}}</ref> In particular, it is known to produce parabolic bursts.
Since many biological processes involve bursting behavior, there is a wealth of various bursting models in scientific literature. For instance, there exist several models for [[interneurons]]<ref>{{cite journal |author=Erisir, A., D. Lau, B. Rudy, and S. Leonard |title=Function of Specific K+ Channels in Sustained High-frequency Firing of Fast-spiking Neocortical Cells |journal=J. Neurophysiol. | volume=82 |pages=2476–489 |year=1999 |doi=10.1152/jn.1999.82.5.2476}}</ref> and [[Cerebral cortex|cortical]] [[spiking neuron]]s.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Izhikevich, E.M. |title=Which Model to Use for Cortical Spiking Neurons? |journal=IEEE Transactions on Neural Networks | volume=15| issue=5 |pages=1063–070 |year=2004 |doi=10.1109/tnn.2004.832719}}</ref> However, the literature on parabolic bursting models is relatively scarce.
Parabolic bursting models are [[mathematical models]] that mimic parabolic bursting in real biological systems. Each [[bursting|burst]] of a [[parabolic burster]] has a characteristic feature in the burst structure itself – the frequency at the beginning and end of the burst is low relative to the frequency in the middle of the burst.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Lee |title=Stability Analysis Of Bursting Models |journal=Journal of the Korean Mathematical Society |volume=42 |issue=4 |pages=827–45 |year=2005 |doi=10.4134/jkms.2005.42.4.827}}</ref> A [[frequency]] plot of one burst resembles a [[parabola]], hence the name "parabolic burst". Furthermore, unlike elliptic or square-wave bursting, there is a slow modulating wave which, at its peak, excites the cell enough to generate a burst and inhibits the cell in regions near its minimum. As a result, the neuron periodically transitions between bursting and quiescence.
Parabolic bursting has been studied most extensively in the R15 neuron, which is one of six types of neurons of the ''Aplysia'' abdominal ganglion<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Faber D, Klee M |title=Membrane Characteristics of Bursting Pacemaker Neurons in Aplysia |journal=Nature New Biology |volume=240 |pages=29–31 |year=1972 |doi=10.1038/newbio240029a0}}</ref> and one of thirty neurons comprising the [[abdominal ganglion]].<ref>{{cite journal |author=Kandel, E. R., W. T. Frazier, R. Waziri, and R. E. Coggeshall |title=Direct and Common Connections Among Identified Neurons in Aplysia |journal=J. Neurophysiol. |volume=30 |issue=6 |pages=1352–376 |year=1967 |doi=10.1152/jn.1967.30.6.1352}}</ref> The ''Aplysia'' abdominal ganglion was studied and extensively characterized because its relatively large neurons and proximity of the neurons to the surface of the ganglion made it an ideal and "valuable preparation for cellular [[electrophysical]] studies".<ref>{{cite journal |author=Frazier, W. T., E. R. Kandel, Irving Kupfermann, Rafiq Waziri, and R. E. Coggeshall. |title=Morphological and Functional Properties of Identified Neurons in the Abdominal Ganglion of Aplysia Californica |journal=J. Neurophysiol. |volume=30 |issue=6 |pages=1288–1351 |year=1967 |doi=10.1152/jn.1967.30.6.1288}}</ref>
Early attempts to model parabolic bursting were for specific applications, often related to studies of the R15 neuron. This is especially true of R. E. Plant<ref>{{cite journal |author=Plant, R. Kim, M. |title=Mathematical Description of a Bursting Pacemaker Neuron by a Modification of the Hodgkin–Huxley Equations |journal=Biophysical Journal | volume=16 | issue=3 |pages=227–44 |year=1976 |doi=10.1016/s0006-3495(76)85683-4 |pmid=1252578 |pmc=1334834}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author=Plant, R. |title=The Effects of Calcium++ on Bursting Neurons. A Modeling Study |journal=Biophysical Journal | volume=21 | issue=3 |pages=217–37 |year=1978 |doi=10.1016/s0006-3495(78)85521-0 |bibcode=1978BpJ....21..217P}}</ref> and Carpenter,<ref>{{cite journal |author=Carpenter, Gail A. |title=Bursting Phenomena in Excitable Membranes |journal=SIAM Journal on Applied Mathematics | volume=36 | issue=2 |pages=334–372 |year=1979 |doi=10.1137/0136027}}</ref> whose combined works comprise the bulk of parabolic bursting models prior to Ermentrout and Kopell's canonical model.
Though there was no specific mention of the term "parabolic bursting" in Plant's papers, [http://www.scholarpedia.org/article/Plant_model Plant's model(s)] do involve a slow, modulating oscillation which control bursting in the model(s).<ref>{{cite journal |author=Plant, R. Kim, M. |title=Mathematical Description of a Bursting Pacemaker Neuron by a Modification of the Hodgkin–Huxley Equations |journal=Biophysical Journal | volume=16 | issue=3 |pages=227–44 |year=1976 |doi=10.1016/s0006-3495(76)85683-4 |pmid=1252578 |pmc=1334834}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author=Plant, R. |title=The Effects of Calcium++ on Bursting Neurons. A Modeling Study |journal=Biophysical Journal | volume=21 | issue=3 |pages=217–37 |year=1978 |doi=10.1016/s0006-3495(78)85521-0 |bibcode=1978BpJ....21..217P}}</ref> This is, by definition, parabolic bursting. Both of Plant's papers on the topic involve a model derived from the [[Hodgkin–Huxley equations]] and include extra conductances, which only add to the complexity of the model.
Carpenter developed her model primarily for a square wave burster.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Carpenter, Gail A. |title=Bursting Phenomena in Excitable Membranes |journal=SIAM Journal on Applied Mathematics | volume=36 | issue=2 |pages=334–372 |year=1979 |doi=10.1137/0136027}}</ref> The model was capable of producing a small variety of square wave bursts and produced parabolic bursts as a consequence of adding an extra [[Electrical conductance|conductance]]. However, the model applied to only spatial propagation down [[axons]] and not situations where oscillations are limited to a small region in space (i.e. it was not suited for "space-clamped" situations).
The lack of a simple, generalizable, space-clamped, parabolic bursting model motivated Ermentrout and Kopell to develop the theta model.
==Characteristics of the model==
===General equations=== It is possible to describe a multitude of parabolic bursting cells by deriving a simple mathematical model, called a canonical model. Derivation of the Ermentrout and Kopell canonical model begins with the general form for parabolic bursting, and notation will be fixed to clarify the discussion. The letters <math>f</math>, <math>g</math>, <math>h</math>, <math>I</math> are reserved for functions; <math>x</math>, <math>y</math>, <math>\theta</math> for state variables; <math>\varepsilon</math>, <math>p</math>, and <math>q</math> for [[Scalar (mathematics)|scalars]].
In the following generalized system of equations for parabolic bursting, the values of <math>f</math> describe the membrane potential and ion channels, typical of many [http://www.scholarpedia.org/article/Conductance-based_models conductance-based] biological neuron models. Slow oscillations are controlled by <math>h</math>, and ultimately described by <math>y</math>. These slow oscillations can be, for example, slow fluctuations in calcium concentration inside a cell. The function <math>g</math> couples <math>\dot{y}</math> to <math>\dot{x}</math>, thereby allowing the second system, <math>\dot{y}</math>, to influence the behavior of the first system, <math>\dot{x}</math>. In more succinct terms, "<math>x</math> generates the spikes and <math>y</math> generates the slow waves".<ref>{{cite journal |author=Ermentrout B, Kopell, N |title=Parabolic bursting in an excitable system coupled with a slow oscillation |journal=SIAM Journal of Applied Mathematics | volume=46 |pages=233–253 |year=1986 |doi=10.1137/0146017}}</ref> The equations are:
: <math>\dot{x} = f(x) + \varepsilon^2 g(x,y,\varepsilon),</math>
: <math>\dot{y} = \varepsilon h(x,y,\varepsilon),</math>
where <math>x</math> is a vector with <math>p</math> entries (i.e. <math>x \in \mathbb{R}^p</math>), <math>y</math> is a vector with <math>q</math> entries (i.e. <math>y \in \mathbb{R}^q</math>), <math>\varepsilon</math> is small and positive, and <math>f</math>, <math>g</math>, <math>h</math> are [[Smooth function|smooth]] (i.e. infinitely differentiable).<ref>{{cite journal |author=Ermentrout B, Kopell, N |title=Parabolic bursting in an excitable system coupled with a slow oscillation |journal=SIAM Journal of Applied Mathematics | volume=46 |pages=233–253 |year=1986 |doi=10.1137/0146017}}</ref> Additional constraints are required to guarantee parabolic bursting. First, <math>\dot{x}=f(x)</math> must produce a circle in [[phase space]] that is [[Invariant (mathematics)|invariant]], meaning it does not change under certain [[Transformation (function)|transformations]]. This circle must also be [[Attractor|attracting]] in <math>\mathbb{R}^2</math> with a [[Critical point (mathematics)|critical point]] located at <math>x = 0</math>. The second criterion requires that when <math>\dot{y}=h(0,y,0)</math>, there exists a stable [[limit cycle]] solution. These criteria can be summarized by the following points:
#When <math>\varepsilon = 0</math>, <math>\dot{x}=f(x)</math> "has an attracting invariant circle with a single critical point", with the critical point located at <math>x=0</math>, and #When <math>x = 0</math>, <math>\dot{y}=h(0,y,0)</math> has a stable limit cycle solution.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Ermentrout B, Kopell, N |title=Parabolic bursting in an excitable system coupled with a slow oscillation |journal=SIAM Journal of Applied Mathematics | volume=46 |pages=233–253 |year=1986 |doi=10.1137/0146017}}</ref>
The theta model can be used in place of any parabolic bursting model that satisfies the assumptions above.
=== Model equations and properties ===
The theta model is a reduction of the generalized system from the previous section and takes the form,
: <math>\frac{d\theta}{dt}=1-\cos\theta+(1+\cos\theta)I(t), \qquad \theta \in S^1.</math>
This model is one of the simplest excitable neuron models.<ref>{{cite journal |author=McKennoch, S., Voegtlin T., and Bushnell L. |title=Spike-Timing Error Backpropagation in Theta Neuron Networks |journal=Neural Computation | volume=21 | issue=1 |pages=9–45| doi=10.1162/neco.2009.09-07-610 |year=2008}}</ref> The state variable <math>\theta</math> represents the angle in [[radian]]s, and the input function, <math>I(t)</math>, is typically chosen to be [[Periodic function|periodic]]. Whenever <math>\theta</math> reaches the value <math>\theta = \pi</math>, the model is said to produce a spike.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Ermentrout B. |title=Ermentrout–Kopell Canonical Model |journal=Scholarpedia | volume=3 | issue=3 |pages=1398 |year=2008 |doi=10.4249/scholarpedia.1398}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author=McKennoch, S., Voegtlin T., and Bushnell L. |title=Spike-Timing Error Backpropagation in Theta Neuron Networks |journal=Neural Computation | volume=21 | issue=1 |pages=9–45| doi=10.1162/neco.2009.09-07-610 |year=2008}}</ref>
The theta model is capable of a single [[Saddle-node bifurcation|saddle-node]] [[Bifurcation theory|bifurcation]] and can be shown to be the "[[Normal form (mathematics)|normal form]] for the saddle-node on a limit cycle bifurcation" ([http://www.scholarpedia.org/article/Saddle-node_bifurcation_on_invariant_circle SNIC]).<ref>{{cite journal |author=Ermentrout B. |title=Ermentrout-Kopell Canonical Model |journal=Scholarpedia | volume=3 | issue=3 |pages=1398 |year=2008 |doi=10.4249/scholarpedia.1398}}</ref> When <math>(I < 0)</math>, the system is excitable, i.e., given an appriate [[Perturbation (biology)|perturbation]] the system will produce a spike. Incidentally, when viewed in the [[plane (geometry)|plane]] (<math>\mathbb{R}^2</math>), the [[unstable]] critical point is actually a [[saddle point]] because <math>S^1</math> is attracting in <math>\mathbb{R}^2</math>. When <math>(I > 0)</math>, <math>\dot{\theta}</math> is also positive, and the system will give rise to a limit cycle. Therefore, the bifurcation point is located at <math>I(t) = 0</math>.
Near the bifurcation point, the theta model resembles the [[quadratic integrate and fire]] model:
: <math>\frac{dx}{dt} = x^2 + I.</math>
For I > 0, the solutions "blow up" rather quickly. By resetting the trajectory <math>x(t) </math> to <math>-\infty</math> when it reaches <math>+\infty</math>, the total period is then
: <math>T = \frac{\pi}{\sqrt{I}}.</math>
Therefore, the period diverges as <math>I \rightarrow 0^+</math> and the frequency converges to zero.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Ermentrout B. |title=Ermentrout–Kopell Canonical Model |journal=Scholarpedia | volume=3 | issue=3 |pages=1398 |year=2008 |doi=10.4249/scholarpedia.1398}}</ref>
====Example==== When <math>I(t)</math> is some slow wave which can be both negative and positive, the system is capable of producing parabolic bursts. Consider the simple example <math>I(t) := \sin(\alpha t)</math>, where <math>\alpha</math> is relatively small. Then for <math>\alpha t \in (0, \pi)</math>, <math>I(t)</math> is strictly positive and <math>\theta</math> makes multiple passes through the angle <math>\pi</math>, resulting in multiple bursts. Note that whenever <math>\alpha t</math> is near zero or <math>\pi</math>, the theta neuron will spike at relatively a low frequency, and whenever <math>\alpha t</math> is near <math>\alpha t = \pi/2</math> the neuron will spike with very high frequency. When <math>\alpha t = \pi</math>, the frequency of spikes is zero since the period is infinite since <math>\theta</math> can no longer pass through <math>\theta = \pi</math>. Finally, for <math>\alpha t \in (\pi, 2\pi)</math>, the neuron is excitable and will no longer burst. This qualitative description highlights the characteristics that make the theta model a parabolic bursting model. Not only does the model have periods of quiescence between bursts which are modulated by a slow wave, but the frequency of spikes at the beginning and end of each burst is high relative to the frequency at the middle of the burst.
===Derivation=== The derivation comes in the form of two [[Lemma (mathematics)|lemmas]] in Ermentrout and Kopell (1986). Lemma 1, in summary, states that when viewing the general equations above in a subset <math>S^1 \times \mathbb{R}^2</math>, the equations take the form:
: <math>\dot{x_1} = \overline{f}(x_1) + \varepsilon^2 \overline{g}(x_1, y, \varepsilon) \qquad x_1 \in S^1,</math>
: <math>\dot{y} = \varepsilon \overline{h}(x_1, y, \varepsilon) \;\;\;\;\;\; y \in \mathbb{R}^q.</math>
By lemma 2 in Ermentrout and Kopell 1986, "There exists a change of coordinates... and a constant, c, such that in new coordinates, the two equations above [[Pointwise convergence|converge pointwise]] as <math>\varepsilon \rightarrow 0</math> to the equations
: <math>\dot{\theta} = (1-\cos\theta) + (1 + \cos\theta)\overline{g}(0,y,0),</math>
: <math>\dot{y} = \frac{1}{c} \overline{h}(0,y,0),</math>
for all <math>\theta \neq \pi</math>. Convergence is [[Uniform convergence|uniform]] except near <math>\theta = \pi</math>." (Ermentrout and Kopell, 1986). By letting <math>I(t) := \overline{g}(0,y,0)</math>, resemblance to the theta model is obvious.
===Phase response curve=== [[File:theta-prc.png|right|thumb|250px|The phase response curve of the theta model with K = 1. Since perturbations always result in a phase advance, this is a type 1 PRC.]]
In general, given a scalar phase model of the form
: <math>\dot{\theta} = f(\theta) + g(\theta)S(t),</math>
where <math>S(t)</math> represents the perturbation current, a closed form solution of the [[phase response curve]] (PRC) does not exist.
However, the theta model is a special case of such an oscillator and happens to have a closed-form solution for the PRC. The theta model is recovered by defining <math>f</math> and <math>g</math> as
: <math>f(\theta) = (1-\cos\theta) + I(1+\cos\theta),</math>
: <math>g(\theta) = (1 + \cos\theta).</math>
In the appendix of Ermentrout 1996, the PRC is shown to be <math>Z(\theta) = K(1+\cos\theta)</math>.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Ermentrout, B. |title=Type I Membranes, Phase Resetting Curves, and Synchrony |journal=Neural Computation | volume=8 | issue=5 |pages=979–1001| year=1996 | doi=10.1162/neco.1996.8.5.979 | pmid=8697231}}</ref>
==Similar models==
===Plant's model=== The authors of Soto-Treviño et al. (1996) discuss in great detail the similarities between Plant's (1976) model and the theta model. At first glance, the mechanisms of bursting in both systems are very different: In Plant's model, there are two slow oscillations – one for conductance of a specific current and one for the concentration of calcium. The calcium oscillations are active only when the membrane potential is capable of oscillating. This contrasts heavily against the theta model in which one slow wave modulates the burst of the neuron and the slow wave has no dependence upon the bursts. Despite these differences, the theta model is shown to be similar to Plant's (1976) model by a series of coordinate transformations. In the process, Soto-Trevino, et al. discovered that the theta model was more general than originally believed.
===Quadratic integrate-and-fire===
The quadratic integrate-and-fire (QIF) model was created by Latham et al. in 2000 to explore the many questions related to networks of neurons with low firing rates.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Latham, P. E., B. J. Richmond, P. G. Nelson, and S. Nirenberg. |title=Intrinsic Dynamics in Neuronal Networks. I. Theory. |journal=Journal of Neurophysiology | volume=88 | issue=2 |pages=808–27 |year=2000}}</ref> It was unclear to Latham et al. why networks of neurons with "standard" parameters were unable to generate sustained low frequency firing rates, while networks with low firing rates were often seen in biological systems.
According to Gerstner and Kistler (2002), the [http://www.scholarpedia.org/article/Quadratic_integrate_and_fire_neuron quadratic integrate-and-fire (QIF) model] is given by the following differential equation:
: <math>\tau \dot{u} = a_0(u-u_\text{rest})(u-u_c) + R_m I,</math>
where <math>a_0</math> is a strictly positive scalar, <math>u</math> is the membrane potential, <math>u_\text{rest}</math> is the resting potential <math>u_c</math> is the minimum potential necessary for the membrane to produce an action potential, <math>R_m</math> is the membrane resistance, <math>\tau</math> the membrane time constant and <math>u_c > u_\text{rest}</math>.<ref>{{cite book | title=Spiking Neuron Models. Single Neurons, Populations, Plasticity |author1=W. Gerstner |author2=W. Kistler |lastauthoramp=yes |publisher=Cambridge University Press | year=2002 }}</ref> When there is no input current (i.e. <math>I = 0</math>), the membrane potential quickly returns to rest following a perturbation. When the input current, <math>I</math>, is large enough, the membrane potential (<math>u</math>) surpasses its firing threshold and rises rapidly (indeed, it reaches arbitrarily large values in finite time); this represents the peak of the action potential. To simulate the recovery after the action potential, the membrane voltage is then reset to a lower value <math>u_r</math>. To avoid dealing with arbitrarily large values in simulation, researchers will often set an upper limit on the membrane potential, above which the membrane potential will be reset; for example Latham et al. (2000) reset the voltage from +20 mV to −80 mV.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Latham, P. E., B. J. Richmond, P. G. Nelson, and S. Nirenberg. |title=Intrinsic Dynamics in Neuronal Networks. I. Theory. |journal=Journal of Neurophysiology | volume=88 | issue=2 |pages=808–27 |year=2000}}</ref> This voltage reset constitutes an action potential.
The theta model is very similar to the QIF model since the theta model differs from the QIF model by means of a simple coordinate transform.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Brunel, Nicolas, Latham |title=Firing Rate of the Noisy Quadratic Integrate-and-Fire Neuron |journal=Neural Computation | volume=15 | issue=10 |pages=2281–306 |year=2003 |doi=10.1162/089976603322362365}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author=Latham, P. E., B. J. Richmond, P. G. Nelson, and S. Nirenberg. |title=Intrinsic Dynamics in Neuronal Networks. I. Theory. |journal=Journal of Neurophysiology | volume=88 | issue=2 |pages=808–27 |year=2000}}</ref> By scaling the voltage appropriately and letting <math>\Delta I</math> be the change in current from the minimum current required to elicit a spike, the QIF model can be rewritten in the form
: <math>\dot{u} = u^2 + \Delta I.</math>
Similarly, the theta model can be rewritten as
: <math>\dot{\theta} = 1-\cos\theta + (1+\cos\theta) \Delta I.</math>
The following proof will show that the QIF model becomes the theta model given an appropriate choice for the coordinate transform.
Define <math>u(t) = \tan(\theta/2)</math>. Recall that <math>d\tan(x)/dx = 1/\cos^2(x)</math>, so taking the derivative yields
: <math>\dot{u} = \frac 1 {\cos^2\left(\frac \theta 2\right)} \frac 1 2 \dot{\theta} = u^2 + \Delta I.</math>
An additional substitution and rearranging in terms of <math>\theta</math> yields
: <math>\dot{\theta} = 2\left[ \cos^2\left(\frac\theta2\right)\tan^2 \left(\frac\theta2\right) + \cos^2\left(\frac\theta2\right)\Delta I \right] = 2\left[ \sin^2 \left(\frac \theta 2\right) + \cos^2 \left ( \frac \theta 2\right)\Delta I \right].</math>
Using the trigonometric identities <math>\cos^2(x/2) = \frac{1+\cos(x)}{2}</math>, <math>\sin^2(x/2) = \frac{1-\cos(x)}{2}</math> and <math>\dot{\theta}</math> as defined above, we have that
: <math>\dot{\theta} = 2 \left[ \frac{1-\cos\theta} 2 + \left(\frac{1+\cos\theta}{2}\right) \Delta I \right] = 1-\cos\theta + (1+\cos\theta)\Delta I.</math>
Therefore, there exists a change of coordinates, namely <math>u(t) = \tan(\theta/2)</math>, which transforms the QIF model into the theta model. The reverse transformation also exists, and is attained by taking the inverse of the first transformation.
==Applications==
===Neuroscience===
====Lobster stomatogastric ganglion==== Though the theta model was originally used to model slow cytoplasmic oscillations that modulate fast membrane oscillations in a single cell, Ermentrout and Kopell found that the theta model could be applied just as easily to systems of two electrically coupled cells such that the slow oscillations of one cell modulates the bursts of the other.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Ermentrout B, Kopell, N |title=Parabolic bursting in an excitable system coupled with a slow oscillation |journal=SIAM Journal of Applied Mathematics | volume=46 |pages=233–253 |year=1986 |doi=10.1137/0146017}}</ref> Such cells serve as the central pattern generator (CPG) of the [[Pylorus|pyloric]] system in the lobster stomatograstic ganglion.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Marder, E. |author2=Eisen, J. S. |lastauthoramp=yes |title=Transmitter identification of pyloric neurons: electrically coupled neurons use different neurotransmitters |journal=J. Neurophysiol. |year=1984a}}</ref> In such a system, a slow oscillator, called the anterior burster (AB) cell, modulates the bursting cell called the pyloric dilator (PD), resulting in parabolic bursts.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Ermentrout B, Kopell, N |title=Parabolic bursting in an excitable system coupled with a slow oscillation |journal=SIAM Journal of Applied Mathematics | volume=46 |pages=233–253 |year=1986 |doi=10.1137/0146017}}</ref>
====Visual cortex==== A group led by Boergers,<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Börgers C. |author2=Epstein S. |author3=Kopell N. |last-author-amp=yes |title=Gamma Oscillations Mediate Stimulus Competition and Attentional Selection in a Cortical Network Model|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America | volume=105 | issue=46 |pages=18023–18028 |year=2008 |doi=10.1073/pnas.0809511105 |pmid=19004759 |pmc=2584712}}</ref> used the theta model to explain why exposure to multiple simultaneous stimuli can reduce the response of the visual cortex below the normal response from a single (preferred) stimulus. Their computational results showed that this may happen due to strong stimulation of a large group of inhibitory neurons. This effect not only inhibits neighboring populations, but has the extra consequence of leaving the inhibitory neurons in disarray, thus increasing the effectiveness of inhibition.
===Theta networks=== Osan et al. (2002) found that in a network of theta neurons, there exist two different types of waves that propagate smoothly over the network, given a sufficiently large coupling strength.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Osan R. |author2=Rubin J. |author3=Ermentrout B. |last-author-amp=yes |title=Regular Traveling Waves in a One-Dimensional Network of Theta Neurons |journal=SIAM Journal on Applied Mathematics | volume=62 | issue=4 |pages=1197–1221 |year=2002 |doi=10.1137/s0036139901387253|citeseerx=10.1.1.83.2413 }}</ref> Such traveling waves are of interest because they are frequently observed in pharmacologically treated brain slices, but are hard to measure in intact animals brains.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Osan R. |author2=Rubin J. |author3=Ermentrout B. |last-author-amp=yes |title=Regular Traveling Waves in a One-Dimensional Network of Theta Neurons |journal=SIAM Journal on Applied Mathematics | volume=62 | issue=4 |pages=1197–1221 |year=2002 |doi=10.1137/s0036139901387253|citeseerx=10.1.1.83.2413 }}</ref> The authors used a network of theta models in favor of a network of leaky integrate-and-fire (LIF) models due to two primary advantages: first, the theta model is continuous, and second, the theta model retains information about "the delay between the crossing of the spiking threshold and the actual firing of an action potential". The LIF fails to satisfy both conditions.
===Artificial intelligence===
====Steepest gradient descent learning rule==== The theta model can also be applied to research beyond the realm of biology. McKennoch et al. (2008) derived a steepest [[gradient descent]] [[Association rule learning|learning rule]] based on theta neuron dynamics.<ref>{{cite journal |author=McKennoch, S., Voegtlin T., and Bushnell L. |title=Spike-Timing Error Backpropagation in Theta Neuron Networks |journal=Neural Computation | volume=21 | issue=1 |pages=9–45| doi=10.1162/neco.2009.09-07-610 |year=2008}}</ref> Their model is based on the assumption that "intrinsic neuron dynamics are sufficient to achieve consistent time coding, with no need to involve the precise shape of postsynaptic currents..." contrary to similar models like SpikeProp and [[Tempotron]], which depend heavily on the shape of the [[postsynaptic potential]] (PSP). Not only could the multilayer theta network perform just about as well as Tempotron learning, but the rule trained the multilayer theta network to perform certain tasks neither SpikeProp nor Tempotron were capable of.
==Limitations== According to Kopell and Ermentrout (2004), a limitation of the theta lies in its relative difficulty in electrically coupling two theta neurons. It is possible to create large networks of theta neurons – and much research has been done with such networks – but it may be advantageous to use Quadratic Integrate-and-Fire (QIF) neurons, which allow for electrical coupling in a "straightforward way".<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Kopell N. |author2=Ermentrout B. |lastauthoramp=yes |title=Chemical and Electrical Synapses Perform Complementary Roles in the Synchronization of Interneuronal Networks |journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences |volume=101 |issue=43 |pages=15482–5487 |year=2004 |doi=10.1073/pnas.0406343101 |pmid=15489269 |pmc=524455}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Biological neuron model]] *[[Computational neuroscience]] *[[FitzHugh–Nagumo model]] *[[Hodgkin–Huxley model]] *[[Neuroscience]]

==Further reading== * Ermentrout, Bard, and David H. Terman. Mathematical Foundations of Neuroscience. New York: Springer, 2010. {{ISBN|978-0-387-87707-5}} * Ermentrout B, Kopell N. "Parabolic bursting in an excitable system coupled with a slow oscillation." SIAM-J.-Appl.-Math, 1986 * Keener, James P., and James Sneyd. Mathematical Physiology. New York: Springer, 2009. {{ISBN|978-0-387-98381-3}} * {{cite journal | author = Plant R., Kim M. | year = 1976 | title = Mathematical Description of a Bursting Pacemaker Neuron by a Modification of the Hodgkin–Huxley Equations | journal = Biophysical Journal | volume = 16 | issue = 3| pages = 227–44 | doi=10.1016/s0006-3495(76)85683-4 | pmid=1252578 | pmc=1334834}} * Stein, P., S. Grillner, A. Selverston, and D. Stuart. "Neurons, Networks, and Motor Behavior." MIT Press (1997). {{ISBN|978-0-262-69227-4}}
